description:
Decent breakfast joint. Tired the corned beef omelette, good helping of meat and cheese. Hash was like warm and the toast we tepid at best Service was a bit slow but as I run around this town I'm figuring out restaurants don't move fast if it isn't tourist season.

The real highlight are the cookies and pastries in the front window delight your inner fat kid and jump on the almond bar it's amazing!
author: Ikaika F.

description:
I went to dinner here while staying at the Hilton, despite the poor reviews (which I do not really understand).  It is nice diner with a 1950's feel to it.

I sat at the counter.  The menu was what you would expect for a delicatessen.  I ordered the pastrami sandwich with fries.

The sandwich was really good.  The pastrami itself was really tasty with that great flavor.  The bread was also good.

I liked the fries.  I had a house wine to drink that was fine.

I am not sure what people ordered that led to such poor reviews, but you cannot go wrong with the pastrami.
author: Edward S.

description:
A real old gem, this is a great place for a good honest breakfast, brunch or lunch. It's a little nostalgic 1960s feel and plays jazz as you sit around a retro bar. It's really relaxing and reasonably priced. The staff are also polite.
We are the omelettes, the excellent sandwiches and also pancakes while we stayed in the Clift hotel next door.
We walked around several different places and this one was consistently without a line. It's not hipster so that's probably why (I don't understand why people have to queue up for everything these days).
Good old fashioned food at a good price that doesn't disappoint.
author: Rich V.

description: Traditional New York Deli in San Francisco with a cultural blend of German, Jewish, and American cuisine.  They have their own bakery in house with a multitude of sweet choices. Large selection of sandwiches (I got the pastrami). You can even get two half's of different sandwiches on one plate. They have full dinner entrees, soups, and salads.The prices are very reasonable considering it's San Francisco. The portions are large enough to split.The atmosphere is quiet, but they do have additional seating where they have live music. Overall a great place to eat and ruminate
author: Rob W.

description:
Listen - I don't have to tell you that some of the best finds happen when you're just out for a walk. This is how Mr. E found this spot - and it was the scrumptious pastries in the window that drew him in. He had placed an order for two charbroiled burgers at another location (that I will name in a separate review), and decided to take a walk while he waited. BAM! David's happened!  Also known as David's Bakery - Patisserie - please put this place on your list.

When Mr. E came back to the hotel, he was raving about what he'd seen in the window at David's. We went there the next day and were not disappointed. I wanted to find David and slap him! (that's a good thing, btw)  I got the aptly named "Chocolate Decadence", and Mr. E had the "7 layers Marzipan" - both are indescribable. The language is inadequate - or my English hasn't reached the heights where I can do justice to the 6th dimension of flavor to which these delectable treats transported us.

I was able to think before I took my first bite, and captured "Chocolate Decadence" before I devoured it (with no shame). I didn't get a chance to take a pic of the "7 layers Marzipan" - it's all a blur. Except for the ecstasy that lingers - like a dream you want to go back to sleep and have again. And again.
author: Bridget E.

description:
Traditional Jewish Delicatessen 

Cute neighborhood diner. Fun old school counter and booth seating. Great customer service!! 

I vered away from my normal breakfast routine of corn beef hash and tried a traditional Jewish meal. I had a dish called the Shakshuka. This dish was prepared and served in a mini cast iron skillet. It was made up of three poached eggs on top of a spicy stew of tomatoes, onions and peppers. My meal came with two thick slicesof kosher toast. This was truly delicious and worth trying. 

When we visit the area again we will be returning customers to try other deli favorites.
author: Beverly V.

description:
Unsure why this is an aggregate 2 stars as of January 2018. 

It's a diner! What do you expect? 

Personally, I loved it. I took a breakfast business meeting here at 7AM and the space was private enough to speak about highly confidential matters in louder than hushed tones. 

My colleagues both had the mushroom and cheddar omelet with side of hash browns for $10.95. Obscenely inexpensive. 

Nobody got food poisoning, which is a plus. The two stars are egregiously misleading. I encourage you to give this place a try for breakfast.
author: Spartevan V.

description: This place is a total rip off. Overpriced and the food is mediocre at best. I had a sad bagel sandwich with some inedible fruit and coffee for $20. There are countless better places to eat in the vicinity. Hard pass.
author: Yelena N.

description:
Our omelette was ok and the rest of our food was ok as well. Just ok. However, the entire restaurant is in dire need of a deep cleaning. The staff seems more interested in horsing around than doing business. 

What drew us in is that it resembles a 1960's diner. Awesome wrap around counter, seats are attached to the base of counter and swivel. I'm almost certain it's original equipment; however, after a longer look, everything needs to replaced, repaired and most definitely deep cleaned. 

One and done. We won't be back.
author: Guy S.

description:
The low reviews are bogus.  The entire staff hustled hard the entire time I was there and it's very clean for an old building.

It's in a premium location, what do you expect to pay for breakfast when their rent is probably $15k a month?
author: Darrell R.

description:
Almost perfect.

Breakfast was wonderful two days running and the efficient but not intrusive service was just what I want pre-coffee. No muss, no fuss, just latkes and matzo brei and a quiet place to wake up.
author: Susie R.

description:
Over priced low quality tourist trap.

12 buck for eggs sausage hash 
7 for an eclair 
3 for coffee 

Holy crap that's expensive
author: Charlie T.

description:
5 starz for the fact they let me order even tho they where in the process of closing...when I walked in they said politely sorry but closing...i kindly replied can I please place an order to go..they pondered the thought for a few checked with the chef and said ok

Ordered a Turkey sandwich and a corn beef sandwich...very good
author: Jesse C.

description: We stopped into David's for a dessert & coffee. The desserts in the store front window looked fresh and delicious. We were the only guests in at the time. Service was great, however our food wasn't. My husband had an apple turnover that was a bit hard and cold. I had a chocolate mousse cake that seemed old, definitely was not made recently if made at the restaurant. My latte was not very good either. Would not recommend, too many other great options.
author: Brittney S.

description: Disappointing breakfast experience. My wife wanted the blintzes. No blintzes. I ordered an omelette with cheddar and mushrooms. Way over cooked and dry, served with hash browns (the shredded potato type) that were raw. I complained. They brought out hash browns a touch less undercooked. There's a retro charm to the place. Time hasn't touched this place for over 40 years now. This place appears to be surviving on unsuspecting tourists. Stay away!
author: Peter S.

description: This is a gem hidden in plain sight. Let's get the obvious out of the way 1) its a deli and it has great deli food, not a fancy restaurant good; it's hardly, delicious but not everyone. Come on with an open mind. 2) Yes, the owner seemed rude, sorry, no American fake smiles, just to the point action. With that out of the way, food is pretty darn good, prices are excellent, especially for downtown. When we were there, a local jazz band was playing! What an unexpected surprise! Definitely coming back and you should too
author: Ilya K.

description:
Bought cookies to go. The almond and coconut macaroon. Both were super flavorful, had exterior crunch and were delicious. 
4 stars due to high prices- $4 a cookie.
author: Lindsey H.

description: Bad food and dirty place. Sad because you can see that is must have been cool a loooooong time ago.
author: jake c.

description: They are racist. I walked in and the guy working the deli stared us down before leaving the counter never to return again to provide us with any assistance. All we wanted was to try a jewish deli for the first time, I am not jewish or white but I am cultured, educated and well connected in this city. I will not be stepping into this place ever again, I have never felt so awkwardly disrespected in my life specially by a food server.
author: Karlos G.

description: Delightful! Great pastries and friendly staff. Located near Union square so it's nice for a quick snack or meal. Try the chocolate cake or cinnamon roll, very yummy!!
author: Addie D.

description:
We finally paid David's a visit after walking by the beautiful assortment of sweets they have on display for months before deciding to stop in. 

The interior design was charming and whisked us back a few decades. 

Thank God all we got was dessert. After reading some of the other reviews, I don't want to think about the horror that would have ensued had we gotten anything made to order. 

The black and white cookie was delicious! The Black Forest cake and the 7-layer marzipan cake - not so much. Is restaurant-grade sponge cake supposed to taste gritty and as if it had been sitting out on display for a week? 

The service we received was great. His manager was not. She seemed rude in rushing him to hurry up and take our order because she needed him for a translation.
author: Monica R.

description:
We had breakfast here twice while in San Francisco for a few days. For the life of me, I don't know why we went there the 2nd time, maybe because it was close to our hotel? For a Deli, it's pretty disappointing.

The place is old, which is fine by me, but very dirty, food is mediocre, kinda cold, slow service, eggs were just OK, pancakes, nothing to write home about, prices kinda high. I guess they're lucky to be in a good location, close to good hotels and Union Square.
author: Jo S.

description: Hmmm.....Stopped in on a Saturday morning for breakfast as they had tables available.  I had scrambled eggs and bacon and shared a stack of pancakes with my husband.  The pancakes had an odd texture, almost like they were doughy.  The eggs were ok but the bacon and potatoes were well done and everything was cold.  The pastries up front looked yummy.
author: Laurie E.

description:
This is the most disgusting place.  Filthy dirty, horrible food and bad service.  I ordered the hot pastrami sandwich (it is a Jewish deli). Bread was dry, the pastrami had been heated on a grill and was all curled up dry.

Where oh where is the health department? Do not go to the bathroom, better to use the urinals on the street for the homeless.
author: Jude G.

description:
Dropped in here on a Saturday afternoon for breakfast. Slow and horrible service (waiter looked upset). No refills on coffee (milk was spoiled too!).
Food was over cooked (pancakes and omelette). Forgot to bring out some of our food too.

Wont be back here again.
author: John K.

description: Had the lox and onion omelette. Liz were a little salty. Ordered cinnamon roll and got it after breakfast was on the table. Had to beg for second cup of coffee. Business was not that busy at the time. Lesson learned.
author: Jerome B.

description: David's is a classic deli and Jewish food restaurant that's been in this location for at least 35 years.  The prices are reasonable for the large portions of food and the service was very friendly and helpful.
author: Mylin D.

description: I stopped in here because I was starving and needed a place to charge my phone. I'm glad I didn't see the reviews beforehand because I most likely would have not come in. BUT the service was excellent, food was fresh and flavorful, and I enjoyed the old New York diner atmosphere. Best pastrami and cheddar sandwich I've ever had. Thanks guys!
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Stopped for dessert on way back to hotel. Tasted like a typical Costco cookie. The macaroons were good. 1 cookie and 3 macaroons $16
author: Dana B.

description: Place is very traditionally food is super delish!!! Clean,service is great for breakfast, lunch ,dinner...
author: Jesus G.

description: I finally tried this place after walking past for many years. The counter was 90% empty, but it took over five minutes for anyone to recognize me. Employees were talking to each other and ignoring me. No one smiled. The service was very sullen. The tuna fish sandwich was adequate with a generous portion of potato salad. Maybe the staff was having a bad day.
author: Fred S.

description:
I was on my way back to Marine's Memorial Theater for another Sketchfest show, but wanted to grab a snack. On the corner is a Carl's Jr. and I accosted by a bum outside of it - he was begging for change for food; I honestly didn't have any more change because I had given it to Zebra Operation on Bart, but thanks for shouting that I must have it so nice. As you continue down Geary it is hard not to get drawn in by the beautiful bakery display cases in the window. They got me, but as it turns out they are a trap.

I walked in to a woman manning the cash register; a couple chatting, and that was it. It was honestly sad and creepy. The woman piqued up and suggested I sit anywhere, but I told her I just wanted a quick snack and she was quickly disappointed. I grabbed a Russian Teacake (as it was described as a giant rugulach) and a chocolate chip cookie (which was huge) for $7. Not exactly cheap, but whatever.

As I went up to the counter to check other baked goods, the chef(?) came by and asked if I wanted anything. I told him I was just looking at the menu (as the menu above the counter is broken and hastily fixed). He too seemed desperate for me to order.

I enjoyed my Russian Teacake - it served as a fine snack. The chocolate chip cookie is just okay. I figure I would come back for the bakery selection but probably not the deli part. And get in and get out - it was really sad inside. Granted it was a Sunday around 1, but I get the sense that David's is on it's last legs.
author: Michael C.

description:
After reading bad reviews of David's in past years, we decided to give it a try in light of recent better reviews. First, service was WONDERFUL. Waiters couldn't have been more willing to make sure we were happy.  I had the salami and eggs. After years of not finding it on menus I was pleasantly surprised; I'm glad I ordered it as the omelette was good. I would order it again. We also ordered the blueberry blintz; huge.

Anyway, I will be back. If I had a criticism, it was that the place needs upgrading, making it look depressing.  Luckily the wait staff made up for it, brightening up the restaurant.
author: Bill L.

description: Worst coffee I've had in SF. Tastes like grounds from the bottom of the pot that have been burned. They don't have Splenda or Equal, only that hideous pink shit that nobody likes. Took a packet of equal from my purse, one sugar and a half cup of creamer so I could choke it down. Just wretched. One star for understanding that well done bacon is just shy of burnt. One star for the music - Dean Martin/Sinatra mix. The music only helped being here slightly more palatable...
author: JoAnne P.

description:
Terrible!!!! 

We sat down at 1:00 (after the lunch rush) and our food took 45 minutes to come out...that's not acceptable at a diner!! Ordered 2 burgers, one was raw in the middle and they forgot the fries with it. One was cooked through but the fries were burnt. Ordered vegetable soup and it ended up being split pea soup. 

Cafeteria quality food, slow service, and very expensive for the garbage we were served. 

Don't go here. You're welcome.
author: Birdie C.

description:
I would have rated this place -100 if possible. WORST FOOD I've ever had in many years. 
We went there only because other restaurants were closed due to it being the holiday season. Lots of other breakfast places were packed, except David's (NO WONDER WHY). We had the Shakshukkah, which was supposed to be 3 poached eggs in a spicy tomato sauce (which literally consists of just tomato, onion, and pepper). The eggs were terribly cooked. The sauce was inedible. The bread was burnt. We had a couple bites and felt disgusted so we left. Other than bad food, the service wasn't great also. The worst part was this place was EXPENSIVE for NO REASON. We wish we checked Yelp before entering this place, but we were fooled by good looking bakeries in the front of the shop. 

Tip: Don't go here.
author: Pitch M.

description: Worst pastries ever- stale chocolate cake. Lesson learnt- not all pastries which look good are freshly baked.
author: Dee S.

description:
I have never given a bad yelp review, but today, this restaurant caught me by surprise. This was one of the worst diner food experience ever. 

The only reason why this gets a star is because of the overworked waiter trying to serve the entire room on his own. 

The salami sandwich was cold, the eggs were cold, the bacon was burnt, the fruits were stale. I can say the cold hashbrowns were the best out of everything. 

Also, compared to the diners i have been to, it was way overpriced. This was not worth it, i should have checked with yelp before wasting $20
author: Megan D.

description:
Haven't been to David's in over fifteen years.  Just had lunch there today.  For a Saturday afternoon it was almost empty.  I loved their pastrami on rye sandwich.  Boy was i surprise, the food was absolutely horrible.  I had a pastrami/swiss on rye and my wife had a pastrami omelette. 

Lets start with the Pastrami/Swiss on Rye.  Absolutely horrible.  I think Togo's does a better Pastrami sandwiches and cost is less than half.  The shoestring french fries was like cardboard.  I really do not know what happened to this place.  They use to have the best pastrami on rye with cheese.  This stuff was bad. 

Next, the omelette,  it was dry, seems that they used eggs from a mil carton, not fresh eggs.  The pastrami seems like day old stuff.  the hash brown was not good.  How do you screw up hash brown.?.

David it is time to come back from the grave and get these guys out of there.  Stay away.  Get a cheaper and better tasting pastrami sandwich from Togo or Subway.
author: L W.

description: I ordered a salmon onion salad and I didn't like it at all. It was just a combination of few uncooked onion pieces, salmon and 3 pieces of lettuce. I don't recommend it. And it's $14.99 plus tax? Hell no. Never again. It's even better to get a salad  from the Starbucks around it. They really should improve the quality and look of the dishes. Now I can guess why the restaurant was almost empty.
author: Jaehoon L.

description: We went here for breakfast. A few of the food items were ok, but some were terrible, and the service was very unimpressive. One of us ordered a mocha, and it took them 20 minutes to come back and tell her the machine was broken. Another two people ordered coffee, and neither could drink the coffee as it was so bitter. One person asked for a fresh cup, thinking we might have just gotten the last of the pot, but the new cup was as bad as the first. I ordered sunny-side up eggs, and had to send them back twice, since the white was still liquid. I know right around the yolk is sometimes a bit soft, but these were definitely too raw (the first egg I could almost see all the way through). I gave up after two tries and changed my order to over-easy, and they were still a bit under cooked. After I sent back the second pair, one of the waiters came up and implied I didn't know what I wanted ("so, you wanted over-medium, not sunny side up").  They could not seem to keep any of our orders straight and the food all took a long time to come out, even though they weren't that busy. When they gave us our bill, they had left the mocha on, and we had to tell the cashier we hadn't gotten it. Overall, impressive service and some pretty bad food.
author: Tii H.

description: NO CLUE WHATS UP WITH THE BAD YELPS. I just had the best sandwich of my whole life here. I had the Ruben on the rye swirly bread and a coffee. Yeah my coffee might have been just OK, and the service was whatever (I mean it's an sf deli what do you expect???) but the sandwich??? OUT OF THIS WORLD! And I put Russian sauce all over my fries, it was ridiculous. I don't know what they put in that sandwich but it was pure crack. My mom also had a blintz (I think it's called?) and it was a huge portion and she loved it. I just can't explain how flipping amazing this sandwich was. All three of us were shocked.  I highly recommend. Support local business and stop being whiny about people not kissing your butt when they bring you your food. Just enjoy your food and keep it movin!
author: Sierra B.

description:
A sad state.  A place that's truly surviving only on its iconic location

Bad service bad prices bad product

Go elsewhere
author: B P.

description: This place is the worst! I didn't even eat there because our waiter was soooooo sweaty. I then saw him touch another patrons food and then touch his sweaty temple. I was so grossed out that I had to leave immediately! If zero stars were an option I would give it. I usually check yelp before I go somewhere but this place was right around the corner from the hotel and looked really busy so I figured it was safe. NOPE!
author: Katherine C.

description: Literally ate at this resturant this morning and everyone in my party of 5 people feel sick from the crappy ass food that was served. Meals were undercooked, multiple egg shells were in my daughters scrambled eggs, and the wait was horrendously long with an almost empty dining room. Never Ever again!
author: Kristopher W.

description:
Horrible. I use to go here years ago and it was pretty good. Food and service was the worst. Seemed dirty as well. 
Sorry.
author: John R.

description:
5 ginormous stars for the retro interior! I love how this place looks--it's like time travel. 

The food though. Eek. So slow, even though there was maybe one other group in there. The latkes were disgusting--like they'd been steamed. Thick and doughy, with no flavor. The soup was incredibly bland. I was hoping the chicken noodle soup would have the thick noodles, at least, but it had fusili. Weird.

Go for the environment. Get coffee or a coke. Enjoy the vibe. Bounce.
author: Umilia M.

description: Don't eat here unless you've got time on your hands. Waited 20 minutes for someone to acknowledge us at the counter and then 10 more minutes for coffee.  Egg whites over hard was confusing for the staff. Finally received our food 30 minutes after ordering... on a Monday morning at 10 am.
author: Sira B.

description: Went in for a quick bite before the play at ACT across the street. Staff was friendly. Took awhile for the food to come out of the kitchen. DELICIOUS pea soup. I would highly recommend a soup stop. (Can't recommend the latke.) Nice dessert selection.
author: Phoebe W.

description:
I pass this place everyday on my way to work and see all the lovely desserts in the window. Finally got to try it and was sorely disappointed. Wish I had checked on Yelp first. Given their location, extensive menu/desserts, and decent seating, we were hoping to find a new fave. Sadly we were let down. 

First off, there is no sign or direction to seat yourself. After standing in the front with no help from an employee, then looking around and asking for help from a staff member (with no luck), we eventually waited in the line to pay and the woman finally said to seat ourselves. 

After choosing a seat we waited...and waited...and waited. There were 2 other tables that eventually filled up and then we still waited. A waiter then came by and the bus boy told him that we were seated first. It didn't matter and the waiter took the order of the table that had come last. We were about to get up and leave when a waitress came by and took our order.

We ended up sharing the Shakshuka (tomato stew with bell peppers and onion with 3 poached eggs). It was alright, but nothing to write home about. The challah bread was toasted and the best part of the meal. 

All the desserts looked good, but by this time we just wanted to leave. None of the other reviews rave about them anyway so I suppose we dodged a bullet.
author: Susan G.

description:
This place is so adorable! Feels like a diner your grandparents would go to for Sunday brunch! The staff is super attentive and always trying to make the customers happy. 

My friend got the salami and cheese omelet and it was great! 

Will be back for sure :)
author: Kelly M.

description:
I am glad we caught this place on a "good" day. The reviews would have likely scared me away had we not just stopped in by chance. Two stars lost for no one acknowledging we were here so we had to stand in line to ask what to do (the answer is seat yourself) and for all the tables being dirty. That being said, the poor waitress was by herself in our area and was running ragged. She was pleasant enough once we ordered. 
I had the Mediterranean breakfast which was good enough for me. He had cheese and mushroom omelette and said it was delicious. Others at the table had eggs with bacon and potato pancakes. They said the food was ok but nothing to rave about. Food came out quickly for how busy they were- we would come back. 
As for the complaints. It's a deli, folks- not Morton's Steakhouse!
author: Joy M.

description:
Are you a top-40 type of person? Do you want your fellow clientele to be annoying fedora-wearing twentysomethings who all have a bad case of FOMO? Then you probably won't like this joint.

Are you looking for a good honest breakfast? Do you like diners? Do you like a little bit of grit and personality at a restaurant? Then come here! And be sure to get the kosher corned beef hash.
author: Brandon R.

description: Very good basic food.  Slightly funky atmosphere but food we got was great..chicken soup and French toast.  Very friendly server. Ordered stollen from bakery..delicious.   for a basic deli would recommend
author: Pam S.

description: Nothing special to say, we visited Davids and had a average breakfast. The staff seemed slow and not really happy, and the restaurant was drab looking and worn. Its location is very near to Union square so its reasonable prices are good. For me if your in a rush and you need a cheap eat come here, but there are better places around.
author: Moore G.

description: David's was also a very great dining choice! The best dish was the corned beef, so fresh and flavorful! The portions was extremely generous! But wait, the almond cookies, cinnamon rolls and eclairs was beyond amazing!!! You gotta try it!
author: Rochelle Dela Cruz V.

description: I'm glad we didn't read the reviews before coming here, because we probably wouldn't have. It was right next to our hotel and walking by you see delicious looking pastries. We were told by a lady up front to sit anywhere. Our first day there we sat at the bar area and the 2nd day we sat at a table in the back. Service is quick. I wouldn't say they are the friendliest but it seemed like there were only 2 waiters in the entire restaurant and it didn't really bother us. I think we got there at 8:50 and we're out by 9:20, which was nice because we had to be finished quickly. The food is super good and the portions are huge. I would say it seemed expensive but every restaurant we went to in SF seemed expensive. For people saying it's dirty.. I never thought that. If you are looking for a quick yummy breakfast this is the place for you!
author: Ashley M.

description:
Pricey and not that great. Their chocolate cake was $7 a slice.
It was just that cake. No real chocolate taste just mediocre chocolate cake.
author: Prima Z.

description: Woman working Sunday October 29th gives terrible customer service. Was incredibly rude to my husband and I for no reason. We asked her questions about some of the items and she was short with us and rolled her eyes. Will not be back!
author: Janelle P.

description: Run of the mill breakfast spot. Kinda has a weird twin peaks vibe going on in there with things looking like they have not been updated since the 60's. But not in a cool way. Bacon egg and cheese bagel was good, but for $15 I could have bought 3 any where else for this quality. Cool place if you just want to get a coffee and read a paper.
author: Jamal J.

description:
Food was good. 

Service was awful. Started with a wait for menus or drink orders. When we ordered coffee, we received half a cup and no refills. No refills on our water either. Didn't see our waiter after he dropped off our half full coffee cups.
author: Lee L.

description: Don't know if food is good is good or not. Looked okay. Sat there at counter where others were seated after me were taken care of and I was ignored. Saw another single being given same treatment. Weird. Service reviews of this place are right on the money- sad to say.
author: Ian G.

description: Definitely deserves a better rating. Good food and good service. I would recommend if your looking for a Good old fashion type diner.
author: Tom F.

description:
This rating would be -10 if it was available.  A party of 4 rated it zero.
Lox & onion had sumps of lox and onions and the lox was salty.The hash browns were burnt. Would of never went in except it was pouring down rain and all other breakfast restaurants had lines waiting to go in.  DId not want tostandin the rain.

Davids was empty.  No woonder.  Will never go in a restaurant again without checing Yelp.

Jack H
Playa Vista
author: Jack H.

description: Classic deli from when I was a kid. Good basic food don't expect special eggs benedict or exotic breakfast combinations. This is a must stop for me every SF visit.
author: Karen J.

description:
First off, folks, it's a diner and it's been around for over 50 years. And SF is not a cheap place to run a restaurant, especially when you're in Union Square and near all the hotels and theaters. So for anyone who wrote a review about the decor being shabby or the prices absurd...I challenge you to find another diner in SF that doesn't have the same woes (Mel's food isn't better and is even more overpriced!).

And they have beer here, Stella draft, which I haven't found in many diners period. And Dr. Brown's Soda.

Food was good. It didn't knock our socks off, but it was pretty much what I'd expect from a diner. I also think you have to stick to Jewish fare if you come here. My Reuben sando was stacked full of moist pastrami on perfectly crisped rye. And the bread wasn't soggy by the time it got to me because they gave me a bottle of thousand island dressing to add --- bonus points for letting me pick my own sauce level. My boyfriend has the shakshuka which we often make at home. It was peppery, both in sauce and with extra chunks of peppers, which he enjoyed.

Service was also quick and efficient. Lots of elderly ladies who come here to read books, so it was a quiet crowd. Ideal when you came in with less than 4 hours of sleep like us.

My only complaint was that my side of cole slaw was way too small when my boyfriends extra side of potato salad was huge. 

We left satisfied overall, though - it's what I expected. I'd probably come back for the Reuben and Stella when hungover or wanting to avoid the crowded brunch scene.
author: Alita M.

description: Avoid. Looks like an interesting old coffee shop/deli..but it was very disappointing-Dirty, under staffed, poor food quality. Had to have 3 dirty coffee cups taken away (filthy- mugs had not been washed - coated inside and out with food, yet served to guests). Several groups walked out as we waited for our meal (we never received our toast). Complained to cashier-her lack of response signaled that complaints were very commonplace here.
author: Mel P.

description: Delicious strawberry-cream cheese French toast! Omelette was also excellent! Mocha and Latte were also good! Will definitely go again!!
author: Patrice H.

description:
Do not punish yourself. 

I did not read the reviews before we stopped in. My BF was drawn to the exterior. I gave in to his selection method and we both seemed to regret it after only five minutes in the place. 

Service was nonexistent. It would have taken less time for us to go in their kitchen and cook it ourselves. It took 20 minutes to order and it was practically empty. I think the wait was to make the place to look crowded or occupied in hopes of attracting others. 

Once we ordered and the food arrived, we found the appearance to be extremely disappointing and the taste was worse. Gross. 

I ordered stuff French toast. It was stuffed withed cream cheese and strawberries. It was served with bacon only. A single egg made to order was $5.95! Laughable, especially here. ------ the strawberries were very dark red which reflected that they were very ripe and too old to slap on bread. I didn't think you could mess up French toast but they managed to do it without issue. My BF's poached eggs, hash browns and corned beef hash was borderline. He liked the poached eggs, but gagged when trying to eat the hash browns. They were browned on top but uncooked below. 

When we checked out and were given a $39.97 total we could have passed out. This was not worth $12 but should not have been higher than $25. 

Do not make the mistake we did. Save your money or spend it some place else.
author: Trina K.

description: Friendly staff, generous portions, and decadent desserts. Highly recommended if you're in the area
author: Jepoy R.

description:
Visiting San Francisco and went here on the recommendation of a friend 

Coming from the east coast I understood what seating yourself means. We sat at the counter were quickly greeted and given menus 

Service was swift for drinks and the food came out rather quickly my wife was give an assortment of herbal teas to choose from 

She order the two egg sausage special and it arrived played well with a plentiful portion of hash browns. Very tasty 

I ordered buttermilk pancakes and they were very good the plate garnished with some fresh fruit 

The pastries looked delicious but we did not try them 

Overall service good and tasty but a bit on the pricey side for breakfast
author: Alex P.

description: This is a great old school New York style diner! This place seems to be one of the few places you can actually find open and have breakfast early in the morning similar to New York. If you are headed to work and want to grab a real breakfast early mornings, for some reason nothing is open in San Francisco except chains like Starbucks or maybe Subway which is crappy and not real breakfast. This place has great full blown breakfasts and great lunch entrees as well. As for breakfast, all the negative reviewers here should head on over to your chains to get your soggy, tasteless, microwaved pre-made "breakfast sandwiches". This place just has great home style real food, nothing fancy, no fancy decor, no trendy image, just great food. As it should be.
author: Peter K.

description: Worst sandwich I've had and extremely overpriced. I should have walked out the minute I saw the food. I ended up here by accident and I regret it.
author: Rosy C.

description:
I'm really upset that I didn't open yelp before walking in
I bought a chocolate chip cookie gross!!!
There was no one there that should have been a sign
author: Kelly A.

description: Ok grub.  Expensive. 16 dollars for a standard breakfast.  No Sourdough.  Coffee was good.  Bad service.  I waited 10 min for a water to even see me and then I had to ask for a menu, water and oh yea coffee.  On a positive their bakery desserts looked great....
author: Lisa H.

description: Not too many delicatessens around but this one has decent sandwiches, Mediterranean salads, at reasonable prices. Matzoh ball soup really good. Had chopped liver sandwich with potato salad on the side. Everything home made. Pleasantly surprised.
author: Jack W.

description:
Awful service, food is horrendous, and prices are high. 

For what it is, don't even bother coming to this place if you want to get sick or are really hungry try 398 Brasserie instead. Our server was really slow and the table that got there 10 mins after us ended getting their food way before ours came out.  I think that is really unacceptable and how hard is it to make a
decent scramble? Apparently, this restaurant does deserve it's bad ratings.

The tastes are not appetizing and not worth $15 bucks per dish. So, don't even bother coming here your expectations of good food will be far-fetched.
author: Sheena L.

description: They charged my credit card an extra $2 when I specifically wrote no tip for 2 takeaway slices of cake. Probably not the first time doing so! Overpriced cake that didn't even taste amazing. HOW RIDICULOUS if they think I would overlook that? THIEVES!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Stacy L.

description: Worst breakfast experience I've had in a while. Server dropped water on me and didnt even see it; we order a capuccino and they brought milk instead; I asked for  n extra plate and it came completely dirty
author: Gabriella V.

description:
I cant with this place. I wanted to like it because it was right next to my hotel and easy to hop down to. I tried it twice and gave up. First, the prices are insane for some cheap breakfast food. I get that they are in downtown SF and have to pay rent, but really. Second, the service can be slow and unfriendly. The true "diner" experience, I suppose. 

What really clenched it for me was being served undercooked food on two occasions. The first time, I ordered blueberry pancakes and they came out totally undercooked in the middle, still dripping batter. The second time I ordered french toast which was still soggy and undercooked. Add to that, it had a weird bitter taste. Either the eggs were off or, it tasted like the chemicals from the teflon coating of a non-stick pan had come off on the bread. Super weird. Either way, after paying my $20 breakfast bill, I wont be returning.
author: Angela P.

description: Everything was very good! We popped in on a whim and were not disappointed. The coffee was nice and strong, apple pancake was delicious, not too strong. Also ordered the cheese and mushroom omelette and added fresh deli turkey and it was sooo good! The servers were nice and prompt. Would come back again.
author: Salma Z.

description: This is totally just an old school deli. I'm surprised by all the negative reviews. I got some pancakes and turkey bacon to go. The guy behind the counter was so nice and the person that checked me out was super friendly too. It was ready really quickly and the price was fair. The food was tasty and I was really happy they had turkey bacon. Maybe I caught them on a good day but I really can't complain about anything!
author: Joie S.

description:
This place delivers as a Deli. My family went in and had some solid food. We had the split pea soup, borscht, and a burger. All were really good. Fresh Rye bread, good flavors in the soups, and the burger and fries were cooked to our liking. The service was spot-on, fast and friendly. 
We didn't have any of the pastries, but they looked fresh and appealing. 
 The decor is straight out of New York- a great little deli without the NY attitude. 
We will come back!
author: Thomas A.

description: The best pastrami corned beef on challah I've had in SF served with crisp shoestring french-fries made it perfect. My wife had a huge tomato fresh mozzarella salad drizzled with balsamic, which was also delicious. Will be back.
author: Steph R.

description: I like it here . I don't understand the low rating. People are nice and the food is good.
author: Ric B.

description:
I haven't been to David's Deli in a very long time but we had tickets to a show nearby and thought it might be a fun place to revisit. Not. I should have heeded my intuition when we walked in at 12:30 and the place was almost empty. 

To be fair, my husband was pleased with his pastrami on rye. I, on the other hand, was less than thrilled with my meal. I ordered scrambled eggs with lox and onions and challah toast. The eggs I got were tasty, but what I got wasn't lox. It was smoked salmon. I know. Lox is smoked salmon. But there's a lot of ways to smoke salmon. This was like a big, heavily smoked salmon fillet cut into hunks. It just kind of hung out with the eggs. Lox is pink and thinly sliced and mixes in with eggs. 

The challah toast was questionable as well. It was yellow bread but it was two perfectly uniform slices shaped just like white bread . . . not exactly challah, kind of challah-like bread.The whole meal was edible but totally inauthentic, like nobody associated with the restaurant had ever eaten at an actual Jewish deli.

And speaking of Jewish, the place says that all its breads are kosher. That means they don't make them there, whatever the menu says. Also, anything coming in kosher isn't kosher the minute it is opened there, because the place isn't kosher at all. Maybe no big deal but it struck me as a little bit disingenuous. I guess you can fool people who've never been to a Jewish style deli or an actual kosher deli, but the whole experience was a little disappointing.

I would add that the service was slow (a half hour wait from the time we sat down to the time we ate), a little offhand (oh sorry, I forgot you ordered tea), and not at all welcoming. All of this for $45. There are better places to eat.
author: Judith H.

description: Very greasy omelette and without any taste. Poor quality food, not impressive service either.  I would not recommend this place to anyone looking to experience SF great foods.
author: Vlad F.

description:
It was the cakes in the window that actually drew my attention. Every time I passed by this place I told myself I had to have a cake one day. Well today was that day!

Walked inside and its a small entrance, but opens up into a bigger eating area. We were greeted as we walked in, and chose where we wanted to sit.

I hadn't read the reviews before I came here, so I was a little scared after I saw how many bad reviews this place had. However, we ordered anyways.
I had the corned beef hash with poached eggs. It wasn't dry or tasteless like another review had said. It was actually really good. The eggs and hash browns were also good.
My friend had the blueberry pancakes with fruit and oatmeal. The oatmeal wasn't good, but the pancakes were and they had a lot of blueberries in them.
Everything is kind of expensive there for the quality of food. Our total was over $40, which is expensive for a place like that.
I would maybe go there again. I suggest trying this place is you like a wide variety of breakfast, but be prepared for a large bill.
author: Melissa S.

description: Honestly have no idea what people are complaining about. You seat yourself. It's a diner. This isn't complicated. The service was plenty speedy even as the place filled to the brim for brunch on a Sunday, and New Year's Day, no less. The food was good. Not "brag to my Jewish godmother" out of this world, but pretty damn good. Sandwiches are well toasted. Pancakes are excellent. Bacon is crispy. French fries are basically perfect. Coffee is lovely and quickly refilled. This place felt like New York, which might be why all these SF kids can't figure it out.
author: Jordan B.

description: Shocked by the bad reviews. This is probably the best Jewish deli food in San Francisco. Has an authentic feel. Food comes out pretty quick and is delicious. Not as good as what you'll find in NYC, but closest thing to it you'll find in the area.
author: David B.

description:
Insanely expensive. $11 for ONE slice of French Toast served with cheap apples and oranges. Go to Honey Honey up the road where THREE slices with fresh strawberries cost $8.25 and are way better!

Staff were stroppy and inattentive. It looks like a cool old school dinner but was rubbish and ridiculously over priced. We only came because the queue at Honey Honey was out the door. Wish we hadn't bothered. I've never left an American breakfast place still feeling hungry before, especially after spending over $30 on a small bagel, one slice of French toast and too glasses of cheap juice from concentrate.
author: Emilia F.

description:
Like so many other Yelpers, I should've checked.  I walked by here one morning and it was crowded so I just thought it must be good, but we were wrong.  We thought it was going to be crowded anywhere in Union Square, and since this was on the way, I thought we'd check it out.

No one approached us when we walked in which should've been the first sign.  Then a woman said we could sit anywhere, so we chose the dining room.  After a bit, someone approached us.  The partner ordered eggs and bacon...and here's how it went:

Waiter:  We're out of bacon, we have sausage
He: I don't like sausage.  I'll have the turkey sandwich on a kaiser roll
Waiter: We're out of kaisers.  We only have white, wheat, and rye.

We should've left at that point, but we both ordered turkey and two iced teas, and  I also ordered a side of potato salad.  Out came the smallest iced teas...at least they weren't out of lemons...LOL!  I was afraid to ask for a refill or we might've gotten charged.  The fries that came out with the sandwiches were the best thing.  There was only lettuce on the sandwiches, and no mayonnaise.  Were we suppose to ask or were they out of that too.  Luckily there was mustard on another table.  The potato salad was made with egg and I want to say Miracle Whip because it had a sweet taste to it.  

The whole meal was disappointing, which is why I didn't take any photos.  I gave this review one extra star because I felt the waiter felt bad about being out of things, and he was nice.  We should've just went to Union Square.  After we left and walked down the street, every restaurant we saw, the partner said, "I bet they have bacon."

My last lesson for 2014, "Always check Yelp first!"
author: Mikey H.

description: We have to come here every time we're in town! We stayed at The Clift our first two visits to the city, so it was conveniently right across the street...this past time, we stayed about 30 minutes (walking distance) away, and had to walk here for breakfast one morning! Everything we've tried here is good, friendly staff, and reasonably priced. Will definitely keep coming here.
author: Jessica M.

description:
We saw the bad reviews as we were sitting waiting for our food so maybe I gave this so many stars because I had low expectations. The coffee isn't the best but not horrible. I would say this is basically just diner food so I am not sure what people were thinking the food would be like? My husband got eggs and sausage and you can't screw that up. I got lox and eggs and thought it was pretty good. Someone mentioned toast being cold. Um, listen... Toast gets cold two seconds after you take it out of the toaster and they have to bring it to you. 

All in all I probably wouldn't come back but it wasn't a horrible experience if you stick to the basics. And everywhere in SF seems pricey.
author: Leslie H.

description: I would give no stars if possible. First off the place was completely empty which should've been a sign to stay away. The server we had was nice, but service was slow. I only got the side order of hash browns and a coffee. My mom however got French toast...that was made on a HAMBURGER BUN. Apparently they were out of any regular bread so..a hamburger bun was the obvious choice as a replacement, right? Sesame seeds and all. I've never seen such a thing before. Everything was overpriced. $32 for one coffee, side of hash browns, and "French toast" on a hamburger bun. Really. The cherry on top was when I saw something scuttle quickly across the floor. It was a rat. I was so disgusted I almost threw up what I ate. I still cannot believe a rat was just feet from my table. Stay away from this place. I'm not sure how it even passed any type of health inspection.
author: Ivy C.

description:
This place was absolutely horrible. The server couldn't understand us when we asked for coffee. The eggs were not real, the sausage was not cooked, the toast was cold and it was $38 for 2 meals. 

There were at least two other groups who walked out complaining as well.
author: Colleen K.

description: **so sorry this is so long***After leaving the gym I walked down the streets of San Francisco to get a salad and saw "David's Deli". I stopped in front of the cafe, took a look the menu and said ok this works! I walk into the deli and I'm not greeted by anyone at all! Finally one of the staff members walks past me turns around and ask if I need anything? I say to her yes, I would like to place an order to go please. She then walks around the counter signals to this guy who I hate to say this happens to be Asian and tells him that I want to place an order to go! He peeks around the corner takes one look at me shrugges his shoulders, rolls his eyes and ignores me. Unbeknownst to him, he didn't notice that I saw his actions towards me. Once he realized that I saw him immediately says "Hi sir, can I help". I said to him politely no thank you and then I walked out of the deli. I was extremely disappointed with the lack of service I received walking into this deli and I will never go there again! The unfortunate thing about this situation, is that this is my first visit to San Francisco and I have to say I was a bit taken back at his actions towards me. I only hope others haven't experienced this level of terrible service from this establishment. The staff was extremely rude and didn't seem to care. I walked out and spent my money elsewhere. I only felt it was right that I make this post about this terrible deli. It deserves several negative stars!
author: Victor B.

description: Visiting here from LA. This place is awesome. The pastrami sandwich is a must. Great service, clean and great food. Definitely check it out!
author: Katie G.

description: Umm I guess this place isn't interested in having customers or serving food...paid $6.51 for two cups of bad coffee and walked, cashier didn't even bat even eye.
author: Karina J.

description: This place is a totally standard, old school, Jewish deli!  I read the horrible reviews and almost didn't go, but decided to give it a chance since it was next door to my hotel.  My server was lovely, immediately offering coffee and refilling it often.  I ordered lox, eggs, and onions.  Delicious.  I'd recommend the rye bread over the challah - it was toasted and pretty dry.  Coffee was good.  Service was great.  Huge portion, so took half to go.  Don't expect a gourmet SF dining experience.  If you know a good Jewish deli, or want to experience one, give it a shot!
author: Emily G.

description: Not sure what all the fuss is about...expectations, perhaps?  Your basic diner, friendly staff.  Bad coffee in a good way.  Ordered the Cream Cheese Scrambled Eggs for $9.95.  Came with toast.  Good portion, perfectly cooked.  Sliced tomatoes were fresh, drizzled with olive oil and nice herbs.  I like the vibe here.
author: Buddy G.

description:
Don't go here, EVER!!!

I usually yelp everything before I go but that morning my friends and I were starving and after striking out getting into other places we opted for this joint as we were walking by. It wasn't until after we left that I saw it got 1 1/2 stars, it deserves far less.

It wasn't very busy for a Sunday morning yet it still took a long time to get our food.  When we did get our food it wasn't even hot!  My scrambled eggs were brown and WAY OVERCOOKED, my friends eggs were basically raw, our toast was hardly even toasted and the coffee was terrible.  I nearly fell over when we got the bill, $58 for 3 horrific meals!!!  I can't even believe this place is in business.  The only thing I'm thankful for is I didn't sick after eating here.
author: Kate S.

description: Davids is an old school deli.  First time back tonight in 15 years.  We entered about 7pm and just a few customers, I had forgotten how big this place is.  We had the chicken broth with noodle, leg of chicken (1/4 chicken baked) and I had the Reuben.  It's all real food, not the Sysco Datto MSG crap so often found in American restaurants .  My wife was raised in ROMA Italy and wiill get sick about ever third time we go out to eat in the US because of our "better living thru chemistry" approach to food.  But here she felt great.  The soup was bland but real, and fresh, a simple base, not over salted, very enjoyable.  The baked chicken 1/4 was excellent, my reuben was real corned beef, not the colored chemical fair injected with datto/MSG from Sysco which is sold everywhere.  What a treat, a normal meal, at a fair price.  Service is like Europe, sorta happens when it happens so relax and enjoy the ride.
author: Gage H.

description: The sign says kosher but you're not kesher when you cook BACON HERE! IN THE SAME PAN! I just can't... the food was decent but such a misrepresentation
author: cupcake c.

description: It's a diner with deli food. Perfect -- that's what I wanted (meatloaf special) and that's what I got.
author: Christopher E.

description:
Worst experience for breakfast in a long time.
I should've checked the reviews before hand...
1. Burnt coffe
2. Salty omelette
3. Cold toast bread
4. Quite expensive: 44 dlls for 2 people.

Avoid if you can..
author: Carlos H.

description: Unfriendly staff; sloooowwwwe service; burnt pancakes; mediocre omellets.  Good challah bread.  Go somewhere else.
author: Maria F.

description: This was a fine breakfast- there are a lot of pretentious places in the area with long lines of people waiting in lines because there's a line. The challah was delicious, eggs were cooked well and food came out quickly. Minus a star because the coffee tasted burnt and the seating process was ambiguous (seat yourself).  They definitely don't deserve a 2 star rating and this will be a fine choice for breakfast in a heavily touristy area.
author: Meg B.

description:
I should have read the Yelp reviews, but my friend suggested it and I followed like a sheep. The ambiance was nice - very 50s - and the servers were pleasant, but the food just wasn't any good. The corned beef omelette managed to be an unpleasant, unseasoned, tasteless mess. The eggs had no salt or anything, and the corned beef was pretty flavorless. Plus, the place was freezing, which would have made it hard to enjoy the food even it were good.

This place was Just. No. Good.

Skip it.
author: Deb G.

description:
Dropped in clueless of the massive negative Yelp following, just looking for a quick bite before a show. We were mostly drawn in by the bakery case - everything looked quite good, especially the house-made mini bûche de noël cakes.

Walking in, the place is pretty grimy, and not really where you'd intend to end up when searching for something delicious. They had an old-school deli menu, though, so we decided to get a pastrami sandwich on rye, to share.

Honestly, I didn't think the sandwich was that bad. The flavor was definitely in the meat, it wasn't dried out, and the bread was a nice touch. The potato side salad was pretty dismal, though, barely touched it. I think the greasy feeling that set in after a few bites of the sandwich, that lasted for hours after, is what turned me off the most. It felt like the oils from the meat were all around me, and it wasn't a very pleasant feeling.

You pay up front, not where you ate, but there's only one person who mans both the entire counter and the register, so it can be a bit of a wait to leave if there are other diners in.

If you're in a bind, and for some reason NEED a deli sandwich, this place can help you out, but I wouldn't seek this place out specifically.

Also, they apparently close at 2 pm on Mondays, which I found a little odd.
author: Claire S.

description: Horrible.  Dirty.  Service slow.  Server did not know what's poached egg was!  She said she was "new".  She and the rest of the staff barely speak English. Asked for plain yogurt, they delivered fake sweet parfait like disgusting looking old spoiled in a dirty bowl.  Fruit was I think watermelon and cantaloupe but I can't be certain.   Do not go.
author: Ronald S.

description:
The chocolate chips pancakes were really good! Served w/ fruits in bonus. Tea was ok, glass of milk for free. Just what i like! 

Les pancakes étaient bons, le thé aussi, rien à redire !
author: Anaïs D.

description:
This place needs a major overhaul. 

The food is expensive, but low quality.  I was unimpressed with the breakfast I ordered, and breakfast is a hard meal to mess up!  I ordered potato pancakes and my g/f ordered eggs and sausage.  Everything was very bland. Most notably, the eggs were possibly not even real eggs, but powdered eggs (this is based on taste and texture).  In addition, the toast was cold. Everything seemed to have originated out of a can/jar/freezer, received minimal prep and then ended up on our plates. In the end, this restaurant appeared to place no  effort into the preparation of our meal. My guess is that the cooks are poorly trained with limited experience. 

Walking into the place, there was no host, so we stood in the dining area aimlessly until a busboy told us to sit anywhere we liked.  Once we ordered, our food came out quickly.
author: Brian L.

description: I have to put zero stars because from the moment that I arrived my husband and I were completely ignored we had to ask where we could sit or we had to wait to be seated.   The hostess told us to sit at the counter and we did we waited for 10 minutes and no one gave us The menu no one took our drink order.  I told my husband to order me a coffee when I went to the bathroom and when I return my husband was still sitting there with no coffee and no menu and no one had approached us  to take in order.  We walked out pissed off because the Restaurant was not full and busy enough to use that excuse for poor customer service.
author: Bebe G.

description: Came here yesterday and had a fast and easy breakfast. I ordered bacon,eggs and coffee. The meal was out very fast and the waiter was attentive. This is a no frills kinda spot and we ate at the round table which is kind of like a sushi restaurant design with the floating plates. Basically the restaurant is a circle with the waiter in the middle. Overall it was tasty and not too pricey and I would go back.
author: Melissa M.

description: We didn't read the Yelp review for this place and soooo glad we didn't. We didn't have a bad experience with being seated or service. If you go in with expectations of having a great time then that's what you'll get. We were told by the friendly lady at the cashier to sit wherever. As soon as we sat down our waiter came and brought us water and said to let him know when we were ready to order. It wasn't crazy busy but there were a number of patrons there. We sat at the bar (though not a bar) and not at a table which gives you a chance to interact with other patrons. We ordered the chicken noodle soup w/ challah bread, meat load w/ challah bread, ice tea and pineapple juice. Our waiter was funny and everyone seemed nice. Nothing like a great traditional deli when it's cold and wet outside. Good place.
author: Rovi D.

description: Breakfast was good. Could have been great. Expected to pay San Francisco prices, so no surprise there. Although Michael ordered crispy hash browns, he didn't get what he ordered. No surprise there either. At least it is a lot better than Orphan Annie's, which probably rates as the worst omelet I've ever had.
author: Nicholas H.

description: Popped in for breakfast on a Sunday morning since it was right beneath the hotel that we were staying at. You definitely get the diner feel when you're sitting at the round counter waiting for your order to arrive. The items on the breakfast menu are a bit pricier, but then again what isn't pricey in SF. Between my friend and I, we split the stack of 3 buttermilk pancakes and the pastrami omelette. The pancakes were a disappointment as they were pretty bland and dense. The omelette was a better choice, but it was literally 75% meat and 25% egg. It was also quite salty from the pastrami overload. The whole wheat toast that came alongside was cold and the hashbrowns were mostly burnt. Salty, cold, and burned.. not a great combo to start your morning..
author: Kim D.

description:
Okay food for what I didn't order.

I ordered one of the specials drawn on the board:  Cheddar and mushroom omelette, with my addition of an extra egg.  I am a big guy.  $9.95 without ONE extra egg.

Got some kind of swiss cheese egg concoction?  I was in a hurry and couldn't wait for a correction.

Got a friend the Matzo Ball soup.  He said it was good.

My incorrect order was good, ok?  Lacking, rather.  I was looking forward to some mushrooms and Cheddar cheese.

Long story short:  Wait staff very pleasant, except cashier.  She said, "You no get special!".  I pointed to the board....

You know what...  F it.

They, the back line, F-ed up my order.  I was cool about it.  Tipped 20%.  

The cashier is a bio**h.  $28(plus 20%) for a mediocre omelette, that was not what I ordered, and Matzo Ball soup.  

I feel like it was an eighteen dollar mediocre omelette.
author: Jason R.

description: Service was horrible. Took 30 mins to get a coffee. Food was cold and average. Worst Americano I've ever seen. Ever.
author: Eric E.

description:
If I could give the place minus 5 stars I would. Lousy food, poor slow service by nice people fresh from south of the border. English is not a requirement to work here. So, unless you speak Spanish , good luck ordering or getting what you want. The place was virtually empty at 1:30 in the afternoon!!
Why oh why didn't I take that as a sine and flee for my life. David is rolling over in his grave. Other than that, it is a nice place
author: Willy L.

description: This was one of the worst dining experience in San Francisco is a long time. My wife ordered the stuffed cabbage.  She got cabbage soup.  They were out of stuff cabbage so brought the soup instead.  She ordered wine.  They brought water.  Had to ask again.  Mine was actually decent.  Had the stew.  Long cooked and well balanced over plain golden grain noodles.  It was actually eatable.  Couple next to us also had a poor experience also.  If the prices were for a dive place, then maybe it was understandable, but the prices were high for the food and the horrible service.
author: Clifford S.

description: I happened to be walking by, looked in the window and saw 3 black mice scurrying around the kitchen. Wow. I posted a photo for your viewing pleasure.
author: Anna F.

description: Not quite sure why there are so many negative reviews.  I had a pre-theater dinner at David's last night...i.e.  pastrami on toasted rye with homemade potato salad.  The pastrami was delicious...nice blend of lean and fat.  The potato salad was generous and definitely homemade. Definitely not Wexler's but a good deli.  The coffee was plentiful and tasty and the service was attentive and prompt.
author: michael N.

description:
Walking by the window almost everyday for work I've been eyeballing the eclairs for quite some time, never made it in though. Today was that day. On my walk to work I decided, heck with it, I'm going to make time. Got two very small eclairs and almost had a heart attack when the lady ringing them up told me 8.50. 8.50?? Really? 

Okay sure. I'll give you 8.50, grudgingly. I was trying to reminisce about Dianda's in the Mission and hopefully channel some of that amazingness. 

No dice. Not even effing close. 

It tastes like it was made three days ago. Hell, it might have been made three days ago. This thing is stale as $#@%. I have one left and I'm just wondering wtf I'm going to do with it. I would give it to a transient but I don't think they would even eat it. Hate to see any food go to waste but it legitimately tastes like garbage. 

Save your 8.50 and use 1.50 of it to get to 24th and Mission, get off the train and start walking towards the smaller numbers, after walking about 5 minutes step into Dianda's. Use the remaining 7.50 for an actual pastry. One that was baked with care and love by some old school Italian ladies that have probably been doing this their entire lives. 

Avoid this place like the plague. Likely one might contract the plague here. Wouldn't eat this thing if it was free. :\
author: Billy H.

description: It is open Sunday.  Breakfast was not bad. I had a Shakshuka, my wife the matzoh and eggs. These dishes tasted pretty good. The coffee and rye bread didn't. The dingy atmosphere is unappealing.
author: David H.

description: Great sandwiches. We had the hot pastrami with cheese and the Reuben were outstanding! Generous amount of meat, well seasoned and tender. Price is fair! Service was attentive and swift. Enjoyable. Glad we decided to go inside!!
author: Oshi M.

description:
We noticed this place for the pastries displayed outside. I came in one morning looking for coffee other than Starbucks, but the waitress didn't even acknowledge me, and there was no one at the to go bar, so I figured they were understaffed...

We came back a few days later for a quick breakfast. The cashier told us to sit wherever we Wanted, and the server came to take our order... The coffee was pretty average, and the servers all seem to make an effort to not talk to you. One of them right down ignores you as she puts napkins or other things on your table. 

The food came out quickly, but not very hot; due to the fact that they don't have a warmer on the pass through window. The eggs were good, but the bacon was too crispy, as were the hash browns, which to me, tasted burnt.

We noticed one of the cooks out a bagel with lox and creme cheese directly onto the bar. The waitress had to come and place it on a plate. The floor also looked like it could use some through cleanup.


Tl;dr sloppy food, unfriendly service, (the lady at the cashier was nice; the servers ranged from indifferent to rude).
author: Clau O.

description: Bad service, food and prices...sorry. We had to flag down our servers, repeat ourselves for a simple order and push through undercooked eggs and overcooked hashbrowns. The cashier did not speak English so I'm glad I married a Spanish-speaking person
author: Todd C.

description: They advertise they close at 8 and I got there at 7:50 wanting to buy 10 blintzes to go. The door was locked but a guy was inside. I knocked and he told me on Mondays we close at 3. If you close at 3 why are you still there and why don't you advertise you close at 3 on Mondays
author: Michael H.

description:
Why don't the owners of this place care enough to put a little effort into this amazing location?

I work nearby, and walk by the place a couple times per week. I was across the street picking up something, and I wanted some soup and a sandwich, so figured a "delicatessen" was what I was after.

Popped in, ordered a grilled cheese, and a chicken noodle soup to go.

Of all the things one could possibly order, these are seriously two of the most common and easiest to pull off.

#1. The total was over $20 for a grilled cheese and a bowl of soup. Already kind of annoying. $12-15? All day. $20? Better be good food.

#2. I opened the soup and could immediately tell this was quickly assembled from chicken scraps. Upon tasting, the broth was flavorless. No vegetables, just noodles at the bottom of the container, and a bunch of pulled chicken that didn't look all that appetizing. I could barely eat 1/4 of it.

#3. The grilled cheese sandwich was barely grilled on the outside. Not much butter on the bread. The cheese while EXTREMELY generous, was too generous. No one needs 7 slices of cheddar cheese on their grilled cheese sandwich. A slice of cheddar, maybe an Emmentaler, and one other would surely suffice. Again, literally inedible. 

I couldn't be more disappointed in a restaurant in the heart of Union Square. What a waste of good property. In this day and age, where SF has such a wide selection of amazing food, why on earth would such a place be so poorly managed?

The guys who worked there were both nice. The guy at the register was pleasant and courteous, and the guy behind the counter was also very pleasant. He thanked me for coming in. Seemingly surprised that I came in. They just need some guidance and someone with a bit of quality control.

If the owner would just give 1/2 of a sh*t this place could be 1000 times better.
author: Rob G.

description: Worst food ever, burned eggs, Monterey Jack omelet with no cheese actually on/in it. Pretty sure my "lox" was canned salmon. We had about 4 bites and decided we couldn't eat it. $42 is crazy. Oh and the waitress only took my order, husband had to ask her to take his order also... But he wishes he hadn't
author: Leslie P.

description: Appallingly bad.  Please stay away and help drive them out of business.  Had a basic pastrami sandwich that was ridiculously fatty and as chewy as whale blubber.  Pastrami is, of course, supposed to have some fat, which contributes to its decadent flavor.  I know all about that.  Grew up in NYC and have been to dozens of NY style delis there and elsewhere.  This was not that kind of fat -- it was thick chunks of disgusting and inedible suet.  The service was painfully slow despite the fact that the place was empty (should have been our clue to get the hell out).  Place did not look particularly clean either.  Not sure how the place survives unless it is from the modest tourist traffic that wanders in.  If you are here, walk a half a block down the street to the Jack in the Box.  That may be greasy fast food, but trust me, you will enjoy more than a meal at David's.
author: Roger S.

description: Very delicious breakfast...I had a delicious scrambled eggs with herb and cream cheese!! Cooked to perfection.. took some pastries to my clients and they loved it.. enjoy this restaurant.. not very pretty inside though, but food is fantastic and wait staff were very attentive.
author: Shawn B.

description: In San Fran one night only @ JW Marriott. Walked to Honey Honey - music too loud for early morning! So walked to couple other places. We came from east so we were up early and some were not open. Stumbled onto DD. We sat at the bar, something we wouldn't often do. It was kitschy and an experience. Now reading really harsh reviews. Wow! Hubby and I thought it was just fine. We ordered eggs over med and they were closer to over easy which is exactly what we wanted. After years of eggs not cooked properly, we now know how to order! Came with toast and hashed browns for $8. Not bad. Hubby had turkey bacon which was "good." (I just asked him.) Total bill was $32 with tax. We also had coffee, tea, & one OJ. Would have been way more at the hotel! Service was great. So, in the end I would say that David's is just fine for breakfast. I'm not sure what others expected, but our experience was very good.
author: Casey Q.

description:
Do you want to have the sensation of tasteless garbage in your mouth? How about what ashes taste like?

First off, my order took 45 minutes to make when there were only 2 other people in the place. During that time I noticed their bakery so I thought I would get a piece of black forest.

My order was cold, completely lacking any seasoning, and terrible. 

Now I get making cake can be difficult but how do you get the feeling of sawdust in your mouth and zero sweetness? They screwed up cake.

Never go to this place, even if you stay at the hotel adjoining it, go elsewhere, you will regret this place absolutely.
author: Raja C.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco for a friends memorial service and staying at The Hotel G on Geary.  For breakfast Saturday morning I sat at the counter and ordered a bagel with lox and cream cheese.  The service was good,  nice waitress at the counter and the lox was decent.

The next morning I suggested the group of 6 go there prior to catching rides to the airport.  BIG MISTAKE.  NEVER sit in the restaurant for table service.  The service was the worst I have ever experienced.  It took almost an hour for the food to arrive.  When it did my poached eggs on corned beef hash was scattered with egg shell and was inedible.  Horrible experience and if you're visiting the city avoid this place.

FEH!
author: Mark F.

description:
The 1.5 stars on this site is well deserved.

We came in to place a to-go order.  We were "greeted" (that is rudely met and rushed) after an extended wait by a nasty nasty woman behind the to-go counter.  We placed our order and paid and was told to sit and wait for the order.  I stood by the door and got yelled at by the woman and told to sit in the back area.

The back area seems to be where the staff eats as it was closed off by chairs and the tables were filthy.  The chair I sat on seemed on the verge of falling apart.

When I received my order and took it back to the hotel, half the order was missing and the half that we did receive was awful and borderline inedible.

PLEASE do yourself a favor and avoid this disaster at all costs.
author: Jonathan M.

description: A couple of months ago, I eyed the pastries with great interest. Today I returned for the prune hamentaschen. It tasted very stale.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Unfortunately we didn't check Yelp until after we were seated. Instead of getting up and leaving, we figured it couldn't be that bad. I mean, how do you screw up pancakes? We should've trusted the other reviews because the chocolate pancakes were the worst I've ever had. My sister got a bagel to go with her cream cheese. Yes, the cream cheese was thicker than the bagel and the bagel actually tasted bad. We honestly wanted to give this place a try and had hope that it didn't live up to its Yelp reputation. I questioned giving two stars because of how hard the waiter was working, but the food quality easily outweighs the good service. It's too bad the kitchen doesn't make better food for the poor guy serving it.
author: Chris C.

description: Came in today, Dec 3rd, 2014 and got corn beef hash omelette for take out. Food clerk was a bit rude when I asked if it comes with hash brown and bread. Took 15 minutes for the order. Got the food. Hash brown is little burnt and very dry like not having sex for a year. Corn beef hash is tasteless and dry as well. In a nutshell, $13.00 + $2 tip is NOT WORTH. I'm embarrassed to have eaten here :-(
author: J Phoenix B.

description: Wife had shakshura and I had corn beef hash omelette, both fine- was very good when combined.  Waiter and wait time reasonable.  Very NYC in ambiance.  Enjoyed a nice sunny day in downtown SF afterwards.
author: Gordon W.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning for breakfast and I really wish that I had Yelped it first. We got waited on pretty quickly, which was nice, but the food was so bland that not even the provided condiments could make it delicious. The food was also on the kind of  pricey side with 1 side order egg costing $6 which was almost the same price as the pancakes. 

The syrup and the French toast was equally bland and the fruit that came with it was overripe, gross, and soggy. The hash browns were completely flavorless and slightly soggy as well. I'm not even sure the eggs I got were real eggs.

In short 2 stars for decently quick but minimal and rushed service and zero stars for expensive, junk food. This restaurant was not worth the convenience at all.
author: Kaela S.

description: Feel bad writing this since the two people working were very nice, but the food is just awful. Ordered a chicken sandwich on wheat bread to go, couldn't even eat the bread because it was so soggy and gross. Chicken was gristley. "Salad" that came with it was an assortment of brown-and-yellow lettuce with some mystery mayo or something on top of it.
author: Joe F.

description: The problem with this place is that what you pay for and the quality of what you actually get does not  match up. Food tastes a day old and you can tell the owners don't care about this business as it hasn't been renovated for a modern clientele. It's very obvious this is a desperation destination eatery when every other one has a long wait. Do not spend your money here and we surely will not be coming back to this restaurant.
author: AJ D.

description:
After splitting my time between my house the Left Coast + having an apartment in Manhattan for years, and having a case of the Matzo Fever, I can say with authority that you should never eat here, daaahlink.  

What can I say?  User error:  I didn't utilize the Yelp Ratings/monacle, but the Cadet had a long day and was hungry.  Well, he's always hungry. Takes after his mother that way, this one.  

I used to eat at Katz's and The Carnegie Deli all the time.  The Pavlovian response kicks in and all of a sudden I wanted chopped chicken liver with schmaltz, lox with cream cheese on a toasted bagel, matzoh ball soup, pickles and three or four egg cream sodies.  

To start...

But a When Harry Met Sally story, this is not.

Any schmuck knows It takes but three ingredients to make an egg cream soda:  seltzer water, milk and chocolate syrup.  That is my second-place beverage vice, behind Japanese Milk Tea.  Is it so much to ask for to ask of any restaurant, these three things?

Apparently, it is.  

This was my first of many mistakes here - my tuchis should have been outta that seat and back on the street.  It's been years since I've eaten here, and I don't remember kvetching about it at all.  

The Cadet ordered Hungarian Goulash,  I had a bite.  Feh-lacid (egg?) noodles with beef and bell peppers in unmenschionable sauce that lacked even a hint of paprika, which is a mortal sin. Side of bread, which he buttered copiously,  and a Dr. Brown's  black cherry soda.  

I  followed suit with the beverage, side of pickles and chose a "Deluxe" Sandwich, the classic Corned Beef on... You're out of Rye?  

Challah...!

Even a shiksa like me knows you should never run out of rye.   The pickles were an abomination and my coleslaw was completely anemic, lacking any tanginess at all.  

The sandwich fell flat - I have no idea where they get their fatty, pre-sliced product, but it's awful.  I managed to consume a quarter of the pitiful offering and considered it a mitzvah, as our server seemed to know how bad things were.  He made an earnest effort, so I didn't skimp on the tip.  

It's amazing how much a hungry Cadet can eat, because he was willing to down the remaining 3/4 of my sandwich.  Under normal circumstances when I am confronted with abysmal food, I will simply pay my check, leave the entree and make a polite exit.  Usually, forever.  Or, I will order another full entree and ignore the first one.

I observed the other patrons at the counter, listened to the patter of the kitchen staff, and noted who appeared to be responsible for this horrendous offense of a meal.  They are charging authentic New York Deli prices for free-lunch cafeteria food.  

Goy vey.
author: Kim D.

description:
