The service would rate two stars, but the food was not good. I ordered a salami sandwich, which I thought was safe. The sandwich contained a huge portion of salami which was just a little nasty tasting; the nastiness grew on me as I ate it. However, on the bright side, it was served on excellent rye bread.

This was certainly not the place I used to visit in the 1970s. The presence of French's mustard on the table should have been a dead giveaway.
author: Donald F.

description:
Kind of surprised by the negative reviews, I stopped by here on the way to the goodwill and found it to be a decent experience.  I had the grilled cheese, fries and  a latte and found that everything tasted pretty good.  They had a nice touch by putting the latte into a glass, made it seem fancier.  

The only downside was the service.  I waited for a couple minutes without anyone looking my way.  Part of this was because I came in at an odd time, somewhat late in the afternoon for lunch, but I was the only one there.  They should have at least acknowledged me sooner and then the server barely did say a word.  

Overall it seems to be decent food for the price, but don't expect great service. If you're not in a hurry I'd say it's a good option.
author: Scott N.

description: Mediocre everything at best :/
author: Clinton C.

description: I'm not sure why the reviews are so bad for this place. It's a little overpriced, but my bagel and lox was tasty and my wife's blueberry pancakes were fine. The coffee was meh though.
author: Ross L.

description:
Only because there are no zero star reviews.
It's across the street from The Clift hotel.  You want breakfast.  It's old. Surely it must be good to afford the lease on the space?
No. Mayday Ghost Rider.
They couldn't even get the toast right. 
I wish I were exaggerating.  
McDonald's would have been an upgrade.  I am loathe to say this.
Service- abissmal, though not unfriendly, 
Food- it's as if it was intentionally made bad.  We sent back pancakes.  We are not picky, and we were hung over, it is hard to disappoint people who are neither picky, nor entirely sober, and yet, here we are.
It must be a tax shelter and/or money laundering operation.
author: mike y.

description:
One star is generous. 

Came here with my family before a show tonight at the Curran. Should've gone elsewhere once we saw the inside but we were running late. It's old and dirty looking. 

Kids got pancakes, hashbrowns, eggs and bacon. The pancakes were the worst any of us had ever tasted. Bland and dry. Bacon appeared to have been cooked in the morning then reheated for dinner. Ew. I ordered a "fresh" turkey on a bagel. I received sliced turkey "loaf" on white bread with brown lettuce. I didn't want to send it back for fear of retaliation. Hubby ordered a burger on a rye bun which actually came on sliced rye bread. He said it was okay aside from the sliced bread. 

Purchased a chocolate chip cookie for my kids to share. It was terrible. Bland and stale with less than 10 chocolate chips in the whole larger sized cookie. 

$68!!!! Ridiculous. 

Now 6 hours later I'm up with a vomiting kid. I'm thinking she ate something which was cross-contaminated. 

Save your money and go elsewhere.
author: Elizabeth B.

description: Was a suggestion and not as good as stated. Somewhat disappointed because the potato pancakes were much heavier then expected and the mocha cake was a tad dry. Ambiance was nice and the desserts all looked lovely in the window. But I do not think I would go back.
author: Kristin M.

description:
Such a Shanda!

 This deli, like much else, was better 30+ years ago.

Now, its not even in the same league as Saul's in Berkeley or, the best in California, Cantor's, in W. Hollywood.

For these prices, they should also be providing good, genuine, "half"-sour "Bubbes"-style kosher pickles. Instead their pickles taste and look like _Safeway_ Kosher pickles. There ae far better corned-beef sandwiches in he SF Bay area - try ANY "MAX"s for instance....
....its also worth your while to go to Cantor's on Fairfax Blvd....a once-in-a-lifetime chance to step back 60+ years into  what real Jewish Delis were like in the good old days....
author: Dofaust D.

description: Very disappointing, this place used to be great. Went yesterday as I wasn't feeling well and wanted some chicken matzo ball soup like my gram used to make (who also had a deli when she was alive). Soup took longer than my sandwich, so took it to go. Last night I'm feeling really ill so I open the soup container which the server said was a bowl not a cup. To my surprise, there's not even soup to submerge even an 1/8 of this massive ball. When you're sick the broth is what you really need. Menu said with chicken too, none was present. Probably not even a tablespoon of broth and all I got was this gross giant ball. Really wanted to keep this old establishment in business, especially as I once heard David was a Holocaust survivor. I won't go back. Giving extra star as my meatloaf melt on challah was okay... Have a photo of the "bowl of soup". Trying to post via the app
author: Traci H.

description: I liked the long counter seating. The food was good. I recommend the shakshuka for breakfast. Service was slow for a diner.
author: Brad S.

description: Ok so made the mistake of coming here for 2 pastries and 1 cup black coffee...$20 later???? Not even fresh!
author: Denille L.

description:
I was working in the neighborhood and stopped in because my expectations were that of your traditional NYC deli feel. I, like others, wish I had read the reviews before eating because I would not have eaten here if I had.

First, the waitress was extremely unfriendly. I had the meatloaf that was advertised as all beef. I'm not even sure it was beef as the consistency was more that of a spam like product. The mashed potatoes were obviously and painfully a powered product. To top it off ,the food was so salty I was afraid I would need blood pressure medication after my meal.

The only thing good about the meal was the cookie..LOL. Don't go here!
author: Bradley V.

description:
I came here on Sunday for lunch, and it was very crowded. Unfortunately the table service was rushed, uncoordinated, and inattentive. The food was greasy and grey. Most of what was offered on the menu wasn't available. 

I'm not sure if they know what kind of restaurant they'd like to be: New York deli, classic diner, Italian restaurant, French pastry shop... This place seems a bit lost.
author: Eli L.

description: Well I should have checked with Yelpers. Nostalgia, years ago I loved this place. Coffee but you can't get cream! Bagel slightly burned. Service poor. I'll try to go back to my memory of David's as it used to be. Too bad.
author: Manuela H.

description:
My husband and I had to walk to City Target and decided to stop for brunch on the way.  We are both from the NYC area and love a good deli type restaurant, so decided to give David's a try.  WHY DID I NOT CHECK YELP FIRST?!  

Our first question to the waitress was "Are you cash only?" She indicated that they took credit cards.  My husband ordered an omelette which he said was not even close to good.  I ordered the Mediterranean breakfast (cottage cheese, tomatoes, toast, olives, 1 egg).  I was a little surprised that my $12 dollar breakfast consisted of things that were clearly scooped from a jar or container (except for the egg, but come on..).  

When it came time to pay (up at the front), the cashier indicated their credit card machine was broken that day and could only take cash.  Why not put a sign on the window that states that?  I had to stay in the restaurant while my husband found an ATM.  Not only will we not return, but we comment on it every time we pass by.
author: Meaghan P.

description: Great service, excellent coffee. Had the potato pancakes - 1st time ever eating this traditional food - tasted authentic. Ordered an egg on the side - perfectly cooked, came with light fluffy hash browns - I'm guessing fresh potatoes. My wife ordered the Mediterranean breakfast - very tasty.
author: Nick H.

description:
Old school deli spot, with way back feel!
We came here as a family of five and sat at the bar top. Service was good food came quick! And the lox with eggs was good bye me.
author: Christian P.

description:
Irish Fetish

You got me, with that twinkle in the eye.  Swearing Irishmen crack me up.  Not only do they utilize the F-bomb quite frequently, but they will straight up deliver it, ham-fisted and proclaim "jaysus mari' on joseph" when I mentioned my craving for corned beef sandwiches.  "f*cking pie retention"  

Huh?

My friend who is not embarrassed of the fact that I am constantly whipping out my camera when inspired, finished off my Irish lesson with a quick stop at David's for a late lunch.  Apparently this has been here for years and stopping by the dessert display with the lovely slices of cakes and pastry goodness was the final push for us.

I'm a diner kind of a girl.  Sure, I've done the whole white linen fancy pants dinners here in the city, but sometimes hitting a casual joint is right up my alley.  Match that with good consistent company and I'm in foodie heaven.  This is a classic diner, with the counter wrapping around the refrigerated cube protecting pop and various condiments.  Formica laminate tops.  Vinyl seats that swivel.  A step up to the counter.  I love it all.

The takeout deli counter is located to the right of the establishment and had a hearty display of typical deli accompaniments: potato salad, coleslaw.  We seated ourselves at the counter and flipped through the menu.  I've been craving meat lately (no surprise there given my cravings for a big beef steak) so I elected the hot Corned Beef Sandwich on Rye.  My friend had the salami sandwich.  

Okay.  So I've been to delis in New York and had to pay through the nose for my 6-inch corned beef/pastrami affair of  love ($22) for a sandwich.  Half-price on the West coast.  Cut that 6-inch to 3-inch.  Stupid healthwit Californians  :p  My sandwich came out thick, juicy and steaming.  Accompanied by a half scoop of potato salad and a pickle spear.  Not a bad sandwich.  I asked for a side of mayo and proceeded to accessorize with the spicy sweet mustard.  This smoothed the dish and I ate the entire thing.

My friends Salami sandwich was pretty thick with good slices of salami.  I could only imagine how rich that thing must have tasted.  During this process of mastication, we were initially the only customers.  Soon, a bunch of men started to take up seats around the counter. 

I like this atmosphere.  Old school.  Waitress leaves you alone but always around to ensure the coffee was kept level for the tourist at the end poring over a map of SF.  Total tab was around $20+ but what does one expect when so close to Union Square.  My sandwich kept me so full, I did not eat for the rest of the day.

The several blocks back to my car alleviated my full stomach and it felt nice to walk in the warm sun on Powell.
author: Miika M.

description:
Just plain bad.  I got the meatloaf dinner and no lie a frozen tv dinner from Safeway would have been more appetizing.

The food all tasted as if it was frozen/processed and just warmed up in the microwave.  The mashed potatoes were clearly instant mashed and they didn't follow the directions.  The gravy was likewise from a bag or rehydrated powder.

There was not a single redeeming thing about my experience here.  Steer clear are the only words of advice I have for anyone fool enough to consider eating here.
author: Max Jonathan S.

description:
If I could rate zero stars for this joint, I gladly would. I had the hankering for some sweets and noticed the assortment of baked goods at the window. The black and white cookie appealed to me the most (even Jerry Seinfeld enjoyed the notion of the cookie). Price of the cookie? $3.50!!! Yikes!  But if the cookie is good, I don't mind spending the money, but the cookie was below average with a stale taste and gritty frosting (as if the cookie was sitting in the display for days) I wished I upchucked the cookie like Seinfeld did. Shame on the owners for putting out an inferior product and overcharging for it.

Additional note: Happened to pass by this place on MLK day. The restaurant was closed , but all the baked goods were still sitting in the window case.
author: Mike L.

description: I was feeling under the weather and desperately needed a cup of chicken soup. Every other place was closed so I ended up here. I read the reviews when I got here and was very concerned. The atmosphere was very stingy as described. Service was adequate. The chicken soup was actually pretty good however. I would not go out of my way to come here but I would not avoid it either.
author: Scott J.

description: Way too expensive for mediocre food.  Nice service.
author: Tom D.

description:
Went in here for breakfast with my family on the spur of the moment, without reading the reviews. Glad
I didn't read them! The place is good - a very normal breakfast place with an Eastern European/middle eastern slant to menu. I had the med. b'fast: scrambled eggs, tomatoes, olives, cucumber toast and cottage cheese. Very tasty, and priced at 10$. My son had Choc. Chip pancakes - also good. I was sorry I missed seeing the special listed: Shakshuka - would have liked to try it. Large interior space, lots of tables, nice, old-fashioned breakfast counter. Service was prompt, but food did take 10 or so mins to arrive. Atmosphere quiet (a benefit after bustle of nearby Union sq.), wait pleasant and coffee (standard diner variety) was refilled promptly.
author: Marie O.

description: Very rude. Super expensive. Disgusting. The waitress was very short and rude when I tried to order. She treated me like I was trying to rob the place or something.
author: Mark I.

description: After looking high and low for a diner and not repeat a place we had already visited, we came across David's. We were met with friendly staff, quick service, and a nice brunch. I would say the prices are a little steep but expected being so close to Union Square. If you're in the area you should stop in.
author: Sam J.

description:
Been walking by the window full of pastries for years.  Today decided to stop w family.  Had a fancy chocolate cake, and strawberry shortcake.  

Sat down to eat....and tasted.  Well.  Blah.  Chocolate cake horrible.  Just overpowered by alcohol flavor. Strawberry thing just tasted old and bland.

Had to find someone to pay, after the guy slowly figured out the bill....came to over $8 each.

Dont be deceived by what looks good in the window.  Should have checked yelp first.
author: John D.

description: Excellent service, great breakfast food. Want to explore the rest of the menu when I get a chance!
author: Brendan H.

description:
This place has really declined in quality over the past couple years. Used to go there before a show, and had to get there pretty early because it was busy. 

Lots of empty seats an hour before a show should have been a clue that things weren't the same.  When we walked in, the hostess said "sit anywhere" so we sat at a booth, only to be told by a waitress "that section is closed". So we moved.

It took almost 10 minutes for a waitress to bring us menus, then another 10 before she came back for our order. Fortunately, the sandwiches were served fast, so we made our curtain.

In the past, I would always get, and recommend, the bagel and lox which came with a huge toasted bagel, a chunk of cream cheese, lots of lox, capers, tomatoes, onions, lettuce, coleslaw and a gigantic pickle.

Now, you get a small amount of cream cheese slapped on an untoasted bagel, with the cheaper (fattier, Atlantic Salmon) lox, a few onions, and maybe 1/8 of a cup of coleslaw and they charge $13 for it. No more capers, tomatoes, or lettuce. About half the lox you used to get, and half the cream cheese.

My friend had a tuna salad sandwich and fries, which was nothing special, for $13 also. The total bill for a bagel with lox, tuna sandwich, and two iced teas was about $38.

WAY overpriced for what we got. I understand it's a deli food, but there's "deli food" and then there's "DELI FOOD!!!" and this was definitely the former, not the latter. 

I don't know if it's new ownership, an attempt to save money, an attitude of "you have to eat here if you're going to the Curran because Max's is now closed", or what but I wouldn't recommend it anymore.
author: John R.

description: Stale black and white cookie with little flavor for $3.53.  I have no idea why they are still in business.
author: Angelique B.

description: Nothing fancy, San Francisco's take on a NYC style Jewish deli and it's not quite the same. (I'm from northern NJ). The eggs had bits of shell in them, the pancakes undercooked and rubbery (I took 3 bites and gave up) and the butter for my toast and pancakes was so cold and hard it was borderline impossible to spread (pet peeve of mine). Oh yea is like 50 degrees out and they have the front door wide open, it's freezing in here. Nice try San Francisco...
author: Chris K.

description:
When I entered this place the server, by himself and with the amiability of a coat rack, gave us menus. I figured the place must be good since one of the two menus had mustard smeared on the laminated jacket, a sure sign that someone had been ravenously eating something monumentally great. After my meal, I had changed my opinion: someone had wanted to escape the premises quickly, accidentally finger painted the pages, then bolted out the door.

Anyway, I ordered an Anchor Steam, which came with a pint glass. The glass had a bevy of lint and/or dust particles inside of it, leading me to believe that it had been dried with a wool sweater or a molting cat.

Nevertheless, the sandwich was decent enough. We also ordered eggs, which were propped up on the corned beef hash, that contained so much grease it could have slicked down the hair of an entire generation of 1950s kids. I sort of wanted to roll it up and use it as some sort of congealed ball of silly puddy.

On a good note, the meat in my sandwich was good enough to mash through with my teeth. The potato salad was fine. And anything else that wasn't up to par was easily remedied with a squirt of mustard. Lower the prices and stop creating nightmare corned beef hash that could double for paint ball ammo and we may have a deal.
author: Rob P.

description:
Shame on ANY jew who thinks you have to be jewish to eat here.  That would only be true if you are a sloppy, messy, lazy jew with no sense of cleanliness.

This is the first review I have given without ever eating at the establishment.  We stopped in for a quick breakfast on a Tuesday at 8:45am.  Wouldn't you think this would be the height of good service for breakfast?  Well, it seems that maybe a half hour before was.  Cause all the dishes from previous diners were still sitting around at all the counter seats.  We sat at a couple free seats, where some mysterious server must have replaced the menus but never cleaned the counter.  it was NASTY, and many other seats still had dirty dishes and unwiped counter area.  It seemed like the other patrons who were still there were from Children of the Corn, as they didn't look up from whatever they were staring at.  Hopefully it wasn't roaches.  Yes, I said it.  I wouldn't put it past this place.  

We sat there for about 5 minutes with no waitress in site.  Must have been in the back on a "I ain't cleanin the counter" break.
I had meetings to go to.  I went down to Max's at the end of the block and got a GREAT breakfast.

This place is just bad.  Plain and simple.  One star is One star too many.
author: Nate H.

description:
We should have consulted yelp before eating here. 

Blegh food, dirty dishes, and the rudest staff ever. 

The waitress refused to bring drinks before the meal in a very rude way and she waited a long time to take our order. When she brought the check, she instructed us to leave the tip on the table and she wrote out on the check 15% = $5, 18% = $6, 20% = $7 -- Which A) wasn't true, she really rounded up and B) thanks, I  can do math. I almost always leave a really big tip, but we couldn't bring ourselves to tip much.

So you might think our experience was because of one lame waitress, but no. I asked the cashier if we could split our check up on different cards. She gruffly said yes, so I turned the check around so I could figure out how much to pay. She grabbed the check, turned it around, and said "just tell me what you want to pay." Jeez, seriously? Then she got mean with my friend about the fact that she handed over a $20 bill to pay $10.05 and didn't have a nickel.

This place is full of greasy, nasty, way overpriced food and anger management issues. Go elsewhere.
author: Cecil H.

description:
Review for just the dessert section on the left.
I tried the orange cream chocolate cake? and the chocolate fudge? cake?

The orange cream chocolate cake? was very light along with the cream, the orange flavor was very light, I'm not sure if it was in the cream or the cake itself, but the texture very just as light.  If you like light flavors and a light fluffy texture, I'd say give it a try.

I was hesitant in trying the chocolate fudge cake because it's another chocolate dessert, but the lady said it was the best, so sure, why not?  I give her props, because its veryyyyy good.  The chocolate is super thick, but it's oohhh so smooth.  The cream, just like the other cake, is super light and fluffy.  The match of the heavy chocolate, and light cream is just heavenly.

For $12 total for the both, it is kinda $$, but I'd go back for just the chocolate fudge cake!  Definitely a must try if you're around here!
author: Bobby L.

description: If you are looking for a Jewish deli, this ain't it. Twenty years ago it was good.  You'd be better off buying Stouffers frozen. It's that bad. When a Jewish Deli gets bought by Chinese folks, un-Jewish things happen.
author: DUDE X.

description: I ended up here by accident because the place I wanted had a long line. Got seated here right away. It's a nice place. Lots of kosher options for people who need it. Lots of great and pretty unique food. I had an omelette with turkey bacon, it's pretty good. They even offer challah bread alon with the meal. My husband had eggs with frankfurter , I think his meal was better than mine, but both were pretty good all around.
author: Karina L.

description: NEVER NEVER NEVER eat at his place.  We stopped in for a quick bite before the theater across the street.  I hadn't been there in 30 years.  Back then it was a lively Jewish Deli.  Now it's a filthy, filthy dump.  My 5 year old granddaughter said it smelled like kitty litter.  I had what they called a pastrami sandwich.  It was some kind of fried meat on stale bread. Not something that any human should eat.  Days later I'm still nauseated by the thought of this place.  Where's the health department when you need them?
author: Artie F.

description:
I wish I would have checked the reviews before eating here.  We have walked by David's for years but were brave enough to stop this one time for breakfast. We should have kept going. We ordered omeletes and they were tasteless and oily. For the price they charge, I was expecting a nice deli breakfast with quality ingredients.

The pastries in the windows were really the draw. One customer came in for a pastry and highly recommended the pastries so we tried two and were pleasantly surprised.

Overall, I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Tiffany M.

description: This place has seen better days. Subpar service and food quality. The only thing it has going for it is the location. Can't believe it's lasted as long as it has with such mediocre food and service. Trust the poor Yelp! ratings and go somewhere else.
author: Ricardo R.

description:
The Haps:

4:49PM.
Cranky toddler in tow.
Everyone is hungry.

We enter the restaurant and it is completely empty.  We ask to sit in the dining room.  

The host refuses.  Our only option is to sit at the counter-- impossible to do with a squirmy toddler.  We explain our situation, and the host is unmoved.  The waitstaff doesn't arrive until 7.

Hubs looks at menu, which appears more like a generic dinner instead of a Jewish deli's and asks if David died.  He tells us David is still alive, he just sold the deli.  We are sad, and leave.
author: Carmen D.

description: Totally unmemorable. Mediocre service. And, a sandwich with proportions that were all wrong. No desire to return here again.
author: Danielle M.

description: If I could give this place zero stars I would!!!! We have been sitting and waiting for a waiter for 25 minutes and he didn't even acknowledge us! Worst service ever! DO NOT GO HERE!
author: Kate G.

description:
I've been coming to this place regularly for about 6 months, and I love it. I've always ordered the same thing - bacon, egg, and cheese on a bagel, and marzapan cake. I crave them, and this place delivers. It's hard to find a good egg sandwich in the city, but this place does it.

This place gets a bad rap on Yelp. I can only speak from personal experience, but I only have good things to say about it.
author: Phil G.

description: My iced tea came in a glass with lipstick on it and it tasted like soap. French toast was burned but wasn't too bad. Hash browns were also burned and tasted awful. Coffee was bitter. Fries were flavorless. Mimosa was ok. Overpriced and awful. I should have checked Yelp before going in.
author: Topher W.

description: Pure C*R*A*P!!!!  I had apple pancakes --- they were probably made yesterday --- very tough & cold.  The bacon was horrible.  My husband had oatmeal --- it's hard to screw up oatmeal, but they did.  Stay away from this place!!!!!
author: Marith H.

description:
Went for breakfast one weekday at about 10:30am.

Nobody told us whether we should seat ourselves or wait. In any case, we order 2 standard breakfasts.

Food taste was Denny's quality (edible), but the eggs & toast were almost cold.

They had 1 server and 1 helper for about 40 people, so the service was slow and they seemed spread way thin.

Go to McDonalds instead.  It will seriously be a better experience.
author: Sumo B.

description: Don't eat here.... This is the most basic place ever.  Coffee, not good, cinnamon rolls, not good other people's food..... Doesn't look good either.  Wish I could get my money back
author: Stephen E.

description:
Can't think of a worse meal I've had in SF.  The potato salad that came with my sandwich was inedible (how do you ruin potato salad?). 

And how authentic is a Jewish deli where the wait staff has no idea what you mean when you inquire as to whether they have knishes?
author: Jane D.

description: It's rare that I take time to see write a review but this place was great.  I had the Kosher Corned Beef Hash with poached eggs. The portion was enough for two. The Corned Beef Hash was fresh (not from a can). The service was great. Kay was my server and she was just there to help out. Her regular I obviously is at Google.  The cashier did a great job in selling me sweet pastry before I left even though I was stuffed and couldn't finish plate.  I definitely recommend and I will be back.
author: Kevin M.

description:
My friends and I came here because Katana-ya (which is awesome) was too crowded and they didn't want to wait:

Bad choice!

 Nobody had a smartphone so I couldn't consult Yelp and avoided this failure!

The pastrami was decently sized but pretty bland and dry.  I mean I'm not expecting it to be as good as NYC but still, flavor would've been nice.  One friend got some kind of standard jewish breakfast dish which ended up being 90% cottage cheese and not much of anything else.  And the third was a egg/toast/fruit combo.  This was probably the best of the 3 but the fruit looked like the syrup-covered variety you can buy frozen from the supermarket.

Service was pretty slow: water refills, taking order, bringing the check.

It wasn't crowded at all either--perhaps we should've taken that as an indication of what was to come.
author: Eric L.

description:
I'm a bit ambivalent about posting a 2-star review for David's because they saved my bacon on a chilly November night with hungry children who were denied balloon animals at the Union Square tree lighting.  Hell hath no fury like two little girls who were told to get out of the line for balloon animals.  And I love delis in general, so it bothers me to slam one.  But for a variety of reasons, I think most people would be better served spending their money elsewhere.

Food:
I ordered the chicken liver sandwich with fries and an Anchor Steam; lots of chopped chicken liver on toasted white bread.  Not bad, but should have specified rye bread.  The missus had a reuben with fries and a Blue Moon.  Both the sandwich and the beer disappeared quickly, but she commented that "it's a good thing I'm hungry because otherwise I might not order this."  Ordered a bagel with cream cheese and a side of bacon for the 3-year-old.  The bagel that was served was poppyseed (oh no!  possible meltdown imminent!) and the 6-year-old wanted a grilled cheese with fries (do 6-year-olds ever eat much else?!). Kids ate their meals quickly given the promise of "anything from the dessert case." 
Dessert items looked great; we ordered a coconut macaroon, a slice of chocolate layer cake, and a slice of 7-layer marzipan cake.  Marzipan cake was a home run; the other items didn't dazzle. Kids chose black-and-white cookies and seemed content. Dessert items seemed pretty expensive to me, too.

Service:
One server was managing the dining room as well as the U-shaped diner space.  He was definitely hustling, and that was much appreciated.  The food did not take long to arrive, which was paramount at the time, so during our experience, I have to say the service was the best part. It was a little weird that the bagel my 3-year-old got was poppyseed; I guess we just assumed it would be a plain bagel, but were not asked our preference.  I also wasn't asked about the type of bread for my sandwich, and until it arrived I didn't realize that.  Not terrible, just weird.

Vibe:
"Worn out deli/diner" vibe.  In an almost depressing way.  You halfway expect some old guys reading the paper and smoking cigarettes at their usual stool in the diner, but instead I only saw a Persian (?) guy playing a game on his iphone behind the counter separating the dining room from the diner. It's too bad, because this seems like a cool space that could be excellent.  And maybe not so long ago it was just that.

Family-friendly:
Yes.  Lots of menu items kids can eat, and they can make as much noise/mess as they want.

Summary:
This seems like a place whose best days are behind it.  The food is not bad, but not great.  Maybe new ownership would revitalize and lift it up again.  It is fair to say I probably won't be back.
author: Aneesh B.

description: Horrible service tried to get a sandwich to go.  Stood there for 10 minutes nobody in front or behind me in line.  No one would take my order or even say we'll be with you shortly.  Employees don't seem to care about customer service.
author: Mike B.

description:
It was a pretty pricey meal, but it was everything we wanted -- a big breakfast that filled us up all day long.  There are plenty of egg choices, and they make excellent hash browns.  The potato pancake is highly recommended.

I liked sitting in the long rectangular counter, and appreciated being close to our server, who was very friendly.

Even better -- the black and white cookie that I bought for later was incredibly good, even though I only remembered it a day later!
author: Joan H.

description: The service was terrible. After waiting 10 minutes to be acknowledged, 15 minutes for overpriced OJ and coffee, and another 45 minutes for simple breakfast sandwiches, we decided to give up and leave before the food even arrived.
author: Jim B.

description:
Listen to the reviews, this place was horrible.  

Corned beef hash came in the form of a mushy potato pancake with poached eggs and had absolutely no flavor to it.  

The babe had potato latke with sour cream and applesauce and ordered a side of bacon.  The latkes were also mushy with no hint of seasoning.  The bacon never arrived even after asking for it.  We could not finish our plates because it was terrible.  

Most amazing was the price $34 for what I just described plus a mimosa.  The mimosa was the most amazing thing we had and it wasn't even all that.  I wondered why I could not find the place to check in on Yelp while sitting in the restaurant and I realize now why, Yelp was telling us to "Get Out!  Get Out Now!!!"  

Some horror movies do have life lessons.  

Needless to say the service was terrible as well.  The dining room was filled with dirty tables and were cleaned up as people needed them.  

Gross
author: Lee L.

description:
3 words: Biggest.Ripoff.EVERR! (the extra R is for emphasis)

Today I was craving some matzo ball soup and a nice pastrami sandwich - like the ones I used to enjoy at Katz's Deli in NYC. Jewish deli's are few and far between in San Francisco so we went to the closest one downtown.  Unfortunately, it's in Union Square and even more unfortunately, it was absolutely, horrendously, stupidly awful and wayyyyy overpriced. 

We ordered a small matzo ball soup, pastrami on rye and corned beef with salami and rye - to go.  The matzo ball soup was just a spoonful of broth and a matzo, no noodles or carrots or any other goodness that's usually found in matzo ball soup.  Those couple of mediocre bites cost us $9.95. But that was the least of our concerns.  The sandwiches were the biggest joke I've ever experienced, even more than Tyra Banks' singing career.  Neither of them had any condiments whatsoever, it was just fatty pieces of meat between thin dry slices of bread; after removing all the fat, only half the meat was left. The crapastrami sandwich was $11.95, about $10.95 more than what it was worth. And the "corned beef and salami" turned out to be just corned beef; they even had the audacity to charge $16.95 for that piece of dog poo! 

Just when we thought it couldn't get any worse, the granny with the bad attitude at the register barked at us when we mentioned the highway-robbery prices, "didn't you see the price on the menu?" There were no prices on the sandwich board behind the counter from where we ordered, you ninny! 

DO NOT EVER EVER EVER GO HERE.  You will feel like a big sucker like we do right now.  They give all Jewish delis a bad name.  This is the problem when businesses are used to catering to tourists that will never come back anyway, they don't need to even try to be good. Seriously, for those prices, we could have gotten a couple delicious lobster rolls from Woodhouse Fish Co. (see my other review)
author: Connie W.

description: It's really unfortunate that this business is laying down for the count. It used to be so great. My main complaint is they're never open when I need them. The theater crowd would crawl all over this place, but it's NEVER open! The chopped chicken liver is good, they have all the right breads and mustards (I'd say horseradishes, but they seem to refuse to carry creamy horseradish and favor the red, instead, which is fine, but please carry all of the choices). The service is old school San Francisco, which is fine with me: curt, efficient, not on the warm and fuzzy side. It's just NEVER open when I want them to be. I could really use lox and bagel after the theater!!!! Argh!
author: Marty R.

description:
Tourist trap.  Don't eat here.  

If you haven't ordered anything  yet, then walk out.  If you've just ordered, see if you can cut your losses. 

Started Yelping after we'd already sat down.  While the food we received wasn't as bad as other Yelp reviews seem to indicate (there are references to feces in some reviews), we still paid $30 for an omelette and potato pancakes, a coffee and an apple juice.

The waitress was friendly enough.

The coffee was geriatric.  More like coffee concentrate.  $2.95

The apple juice was, well, apple juice.  $3.25

The potato pancakes were meh.  The sour cream was a bit off, you could tell even though they'd piled the apple sauce on top - presumably to obfuscate its age.  $10.95

The omelette was what you'd get at a Denny's.  $10.95

This is why you Yelp *before* you walk into a joint.
author: Putty B.

description: Took the family to breakfast. Food was great but the service was literally the worst I've ever experienced. 45 minutes into the meal my daughter still had not received her meal while the rest of us were finished (other than the fact none of us had yet received the drinks we ordered, the water we requested, or my toast or bacon). It's not that our waiter didn't care; he was working hard but the restaurant was completely understaffed. I'd gladly come back for the food but I would not want to go through the experience again
author: Brian S.

description:
Everything about this place is nasty.  The food, nasty.  The service, nasty.  The people, nasty.  Really wish I read yelp before going here.  Everything is way over priced, yet the food is just bad.  Locals should avoid!  If it wasn't for tourists this place would die.  
Go to millers instead.
author: Anthony P.

description: Had the Matzo and egg in pancake style. Weird combination! No flavor at all! Really disappointed and couldn't finish even half of it.
author: Q S.

description: We were walking by and just needed some breakfast and this retro place (not in a modern way, in a still-around-from-the-50's way) seemed like a good bet. It was fun to sit at the counter and order a $4.00 mimosa, which was delivered promptly. The service was quick and she was not overly friendly but nice. My hubby got a bacon, cheese, and mushroom omelette, which was packed with ingredients and delicious. I got the scrambled eggs and lox, which she offered a side of cream cheese with. They were delicious as well. My challah toast was yummy to eat with the eggs. We both had hashbrowns which were cooked perfectly and not too greasy. I would definitely eat here again. I was very surprised at the negative reviews.
author: Dana K.

description:
I'm quite upset that I couldn't Yelp this place prior to going in...my phone was being funny (not in a funny way).  

The food was overpriced for the quality.  I ordered the three egg omelette w/swiss and cheddar.  They only used cheddar, when I asked for swiss and cheddar, and they used REALLY low quality cheese.  The cheese was congealing as soon as I received it.  It was absolutely disgusting.  Ugh, thinking about it is making me angry. 

The service was slow.  It took forever for us to get our food and for the waitress to come by and take our order.  The only highlight was that the gentleman who served me coffee was on his game and never let my cup get empty.

Unfortunately, the coffee server was not enough to save this review from a one star.  If I could...I would actually give this place zero stars.  Never EVER am I going back again.

P.S...it feels a little dirty.  My first cup of coffee was served w/lipstick marks.  Yummy!
author: Pritika C.

description: I had a decent burger from here, but felt dirty when I was eating there. It's not my cup of tea, and I had a upset stomach after I are here.
author: Liz T.

description: I ordered French toast. It came with fruit--slightly brown chunks of apples and a cut up orange. I could eat it, but it wasn't amazing. Place was huge but not many people. The waiter gave us the bill and added his OWN generous tip! Pretty outrageous. Thus the 1 star. I'm sticking to Honey Honey.
author: Lauren H.

description:
I stopped by for lunch on my way home from an interview. I have eaten in many a Jewish deli having lived in Chicago for several years and dating many Eastern European/Jewish men. This is the worst deli and one of the worst restaurants I have ever eaten in. This place lured me in the promise of tasty Jewish food, but turned out to be such a sham.

I paid $15 for potato pancakes. Which is a bit pricey for potato pancakes even in high-end brunch places, let alone this bare bones diner. But I thought well, they must be good since they're charging this much and it's a Jewish deli. I was so wrong... They were greasy and not very potato tasting. I was served three pancakes but could only force myself to eat one and a small bit of a second. The sour cream that accompanied them was good, but the applesauce was tasteless. And that was all that was on the plate! For $15!!! Or that was all that was on the plate before the two fruit flies showed up. If you're going to be bare bones, then at least be clean.

Then they charged me an additional $3.06 for a can of Coke. Not one of their imported Kosher sodas, a can of Coke! That I could have walked half a block to Walgreens and gotten twice as much soda for $.99. 

The cashier had a bit of a chip on her shoulder. Maybe because she has to deal with people balking at the prices, but still that's no reason to be surly. 

The only redeeming aspect of my whole sad experience here was the polite and attentive server. I feel sorry for him that he has to work in such a horrible place.

If only i had remembered that there was an Osha another block up, or just eaten at the awesome Colibri... I could have spent less money for better tasting food and higher quality service.
author: Dani D.

description: I ate there with my family, three times last weekend. We also ate at two other diners near our hotel. I am surprised at the low rating. The other diners were decent, but terribly over-priced. David's was excellent, and reasonably priced. I wish this place were near my home. I would eat there all the time.
author: Daniel C.

description: I hate to say it, since I have a tendency to like my old haunts  - but the shift at David's is pretty clear. Three years since the change in leadership and the food just  isnt up to par as anover all exsperince. some highlights still exist - but over all  - it's lost the snap I expected. It sorta felt like a "white bread" version of deli. While most of the staff still were attentive, the food flavor and quality was uninspireing. We went on a recent Friday night aruond 6 for a pre-show dinner - as we entered all you could smell was the icky bleach/dirty mop water smell eminating from somewhere - it was only after I sat down I saw them moping the floors by the food line. with only 4 other diners in the room - it felt like we were holding them up from closing. I hear they still do a busy breakfast  but not thinking I will be jumping anytime soon to check it out.
author: Frank S.

description: The number of bad reviews here seems a little unjustified. We stayed at the hotel across the street and had breakfast here twice (once dine - in once to go). Staff seemed nice, and the food was great. Omelettes were good, and the pancakes were huge. Would go again if we lived in the neighborhood.
author: Tom V.

description:
This is just for the pastries part.

4.25 for the coconut macaroon with cream thing and 3.75 for the black and white cookie.  worth it?  maybe not.  the macaroon thing was good, but that black n white cookie tasted like it was burnt and the frosting was weak.  probably not coming back.  i feel tricked, although it looked good walking by it on my way to katana ya.....damn you for the trickery!
author: Vincent K.

description:
Man I wish I would have checked yelp before eating here!

I was on a short break at a conference, and the people I was with here hungry, so we just popped into here.

Mistake.

Place looked a little run down, although water came out quickly which was nice.

After looking at the menu the waitress came back and one of my friends ordered a turkey sandwhich, at which point she told us that they were out of turkey and chicken. Really?  A deli out of chicken and turkey?

She suggested the roast beef, which was ordered. 5 minutes later she came back and said the kitchen was wrong, they do have turkey but do not have roast beef.  Okay.  Communication should be improved.

I ordered fries instead of the potato salad, they came out cold and nasty, like they had been sitting around for quite awhile.  The turkey sandwhich itself was pretty good, which is why it gets 2 stars, although it didn't come with anything else on it, I had to ask for the lettuce and tomato on it.  

Oh, and overpriced.

Would not go back.
author: Tiffany G.

description: Boy, I'm glad I didn't see the reviews before I walked in. Impeccable service and DELICIOUS breakfast! I guess they heard the bad reviews? This is my new choice place for breakfast in SFO.
author: Pablo P.

description: I would not recommend this place; actually I recommend you stay away. Our waitress was one of the worst I have every had. She didn't know the menu at all, she brought our food out separately instead of all together, and forgot half my order which was just a salad and a bagel.  Complete space cadet. Food was sub-par nothing special. Not to mention, the cost, 3 meals for $50? YIKES! If I am spending that much on breakfast, get some qualified servers and better food.
author: Represent the P.

description: This place looks like a great deli, with a cool counter and baked delicacies in the window.  In about 2003, I had a nice sandwich here.  But whoever is running the place now apparently does not like or care about food.  The coffee was burnt, the black and white cookie stale, and the matzo ball soup tasteless and not hot enough. In a food city like San Francisco, there's no need to eat in a place like this.
author: J C.

description: One star as I couldn't give zero stars. Waitress didn't know there was corned beef hash available despite it being on the breakfast menu and on the blackboard. Had to wait 10 minutes for coffee to brew (in a diner?) and then we had to remind the staff to give us some (no subsequent offers of coffee refills happened although quality of coffee was reasonable). I ordered "bacon and soft eggs" as "corned hash and eggs" was not understood by the waitress. Eggs arrived - hard and without any bacon. By the time the bacon arrived it was cold and my wife had finished eating. Had this diner not been in a "tourist zone" I suspect it would go the way of the dodo. Spend your money and time elsewhere -- life's too short...
author: Wayne K.

description: I ordered a sandwich to go, the wait was ridiculous (even though there were only 2 other people in there besides myself), the sandwich was horrible (i.e. kaiser roll was stale, turkey wasn't fresh and the cheese was old).  I felt bad about having to throw it all away but it wasn't an option to eat it.  Not sure how they stay in business.  And it doesn't matter about the décor or prices; if you can't serve good food, you shouldn't be in the restaurant business.  Would a person who doesn't know how to cut hair be able to make a living as a hairstylist?
author: Sam M.

description: Used to go to David's in years past. Always could count on a great corned beef sandwich. Went today and was very disappointed when I received a dry piece of Rye bread with dryer corned beef between this bread. Then when we were through received a bill with a (i thought) exorbitant gratuity included for very mediocre service. This is the last time we will visit.
author: Gary M.

description:
This is a place that clearly doesn't care about what they put on your plate. We stopped in for breakfast this morning, and were treated to one of the worst meals in recent memory. Bland tasteless eggs, salty limp bacon, and stale dried out toast. Worst of all was my girl's "kosher corned beef hash," it was a $15 plate of disgusting pink goop. What a huge contrast from that served at Lori's Diner a few days earlier, which was delicious and freshly made.

About the only bright spot was their bagel, which was a proper NY style...large and soft but with a nice chewiness. Wish I could say the same about my toasted Challah, which tasted like Wonder bread.

I almost forgot about the coffee: it's brutally strong and absolutely awful. Now I prefer my coffee quite strong, but this stuff has an overwhelming acrid taste, almost chemical in nature. I usually take about a half-teaspoon of sugar, but I added two heaping spoonfuls and even some cream to try and make this vile cup palatable...to no avail.

Seriously...nobody cares here! Nobody with any sort of passion or interest in food would serve such slop. It's not cheap either, with most items a buck or two higher than other establishments in the area. Don't let the baked goods in the window sucker you in...just keep walking. I'd strongly suggest the Taylor Street Cafe as a vastly superior alternative.
author: Lars G.

description:
Can this be?? I am actually writing a ONE STAR review for a place stocked with yummy looking desserts!?! Something terrible must have happened...

And sadly it did.  I came with a group of friends for dinner at Katana-ya.  As we were walking there we couldn't help but notice the gorgeous looking display of decadent desserts in the window.  Katana-ya had a wait list, and so we decided to come back here for some dessert before dinner while we waited our turn.

Big mistake.

There was a very bored, curt, almost rude woman behind the dessert counter.  She told us to go sit down and we would have the desserts explained to us.  After she had delivered her little monologue, she seemingly decided she'd had enough of us and turned her back.  My friends and I went and settled in at the stools next to the counter.  It was an awkward situation because we were pretty much being ignored by both the lady behind the counter and the lone waitress.  Finally a man lumbered out to help us.  He brought a tray filled with desserts out and then proceeded to try and recite the items to us (his recitation sadly had only a small degree of success).  We should have been tipped off at this point, but all the desserts just LOOKED so scrumptious that we went ahead and bought some.  

Prices were fairly hefty.  Most items were around $8 for dine in.  We wanted our things to-go so that we could wait at Katana-ya for our table, and that ended up knocking the price down by at least half.  I bought an apple strudel for $4, and another friend bought a chocolate beehive cake (I don't remember how much, but probably around $5).  

The strudel was cold and slightly soggy.  The filling tasted okay, but the pastry itself didn't seem  very fresh.  I don't know if I would necessarily ever pay money to buy something like that.  The beehive cake was dry, which instantly killed any flavor it had.

Slow, rude service, high prices, and bad food.  I would give this place zero stars if I could.
author: Vi N.

description:
I made the mistake of not checking Yelp or Foursquare before coming in here. It looked pretty decent from outside.
- Coffee was ridiculously bitter in the smallest coffee cup I have ever seen, short of an actual espresso.
- The half dozen flies dog-fighting (or maybe mating) above my spot at the counter were unappetizing.
- The apathetic waitress was nice enough when she bothered to say anything.
- Everything on the menu was about 25% more expensive than I expected.
- I ordered a quick eggs and toast, and 15 minutes later canceled my order, grabbed an apple turnover, and paid as I ran out the door. No sign of my original order at that point, and there was 1 other patron who hadn't already been served. I had places to be, dammit.
Needless to say, I was unimpressed. Don't be fooled, the place looks decent enough, but you will regret it...this is the sort of place locals and regulars go because they have a specific affinity for something here. Tourists and non-locals beware: cross the street and go down to Pinecrest for better food, faster service, lower prices.
The bakery goods looked awesome, and the turnover I grabbed was huge and VERY good...but I didn't want a sugar rush, I wanted my over medium eggs and rye toast.
Very unhappy, I will not be back for any reason. There are other great bakeries in the area, and lots of other deli's. David should be ashamed.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I was lured in by the window display of desserts but boy was I sorry to have entered this horrible establishment.

Where to begin...geez:

I ordered the turkey dinner special but they were out of turkey because they had "a crazy lunch."  I asked for chicken and they were out of that too.  My Eurotrash server suggested the meatloaf as it was, "straight out of the freez---I mean oven!" Giving him the benefit of the doubt, I took him up on his suggestion.  My date ordered the goulash.  As a consolation for their lack of poultry, the server offered us two glasses of wine.  "Burgundy, from France!" he announced when he poured us the red, tasteless wine.  Seriously, I would've preferred two buck chuck, but I guess free booze is better than no booze.

Given the exorbitant prices (around $15-16 an entree) I was expecting a lot for this diner. Our food arrived and it looked like the contents of a Swanson TV dinner was poured onto a plate.  The veggies were clearly frozen bagged vegetables, the portions were measly and the piece of meatloaf looked like re-shaped dog food.  The server asked if we wanted rye bread and we silently nodded.  He pulled a couple pieces from a drawer and slapped it on a plate--didn't even offer to toast the suckers.

My date and I looked around and saw that all 4 people in the diner had dejected looks on their faces.  We felt incredibly sad that we had just dropped about $35 on this miserable diner, when we could have gotten Katana-Ya down the street.  Before I entered this place, I thought I wanted dessert.  But by dessert-time, I really just wanted to GTFO of here.
author: Sherry C.

description: As a few others stated - why did I not check Yelp first. Need to kill 30 minutes before a show and saw the great looking cakes in the window. 3 were OK but not great and one of them was bad. We had 4 cakes and 3 cups of coffee. It came to 48 dollars - a total rip off - even in SF. I'll never go in there again.
author: Jack F.

description:
My friends and I were planning to go to Dotty's, which apparently has a "world famous breakfast". Unfortunately, there was a line out the door and we were on a tight schedule. 

From the outside, David's looks old and rundown, which I mistook for being "charming". I have the Yelp application on my Blackberry (if you don't have it, get it) and I yelped this place right as we were walking in the door. I warned my friends about the low ratings and read off a couple of reviews--but they were hungry and didn't really care.

David's is an overpriced tourist trap. It would be a very long stretch to call this place a "Jewish deli". The matzo brei was called "eggs and matzo" and the challah bread was written as "twisted egg bread". Da fux? I'm not Jewish, but I know better than that. 

With the yelp reviews in mind, I went on the safe side and ordered 2 eggs sunny side up, with some hash browns and wheat toast. It wasn't disgusting, but it wasn't good. It was just eggs and toast. 

Do yourself a favor. You're in one of the best cities to get delicious food....skip this place. Don't even walk on the same side of the street as this place. It's just not worth it.
author: Amanda R.

description: Came here for breakfast. The wait felt like a thousand years and it was only semi-worth it. The Egg was decent, but the bacon in my sandwich sucked. The fruit on the side was also sour and inedible. For tourists, I do not recommend this place. The wait (and money) is not worth it. Never coming here again if I come to SF in the future!
author: Brendan L.

description: Not impressed at all. I read the review only after hubby and I sat down at the bar. Normally I prefer to experience the establishment myself but e reviewers weren't kidding. Hubby ordered pastrami sandwhich and I ordered the roast (fried) chicken. Even though hubby liked his sandwich, my lunch on the other hand sucked. It was obvious the chicken was deep fried because it was fried too long. The meat was So dry but the fries that came with it was mediocre. The sodas are not fountain drinks but came in individual cans. I visited the bathroom and OMG, it was obvious NOTHING at the restaurant has changed in the decor. Some places are great as they are but this place....ugh. When i walked back from the bathroom (upstairs) to my chair, I passed by a small dining room in the back of the restaurant and it stunk like pee. Will we come back again? Only if all the restaurants (including McDonalds) were closed that day.
author: Apit L.

description:
I origionally gave them two stars represents the fact that they exceeded my expectations. 

The food was pretty good in general. The pastrami was OK, not the best but not the worst either, but piled pretty high and no sprouts, mayo, or anything else. Potato salad was good, a bit bland but a dash of mustard cured that problem. Pickles were nasty sliced side offerings, not good. The "Cabbage Borscht" was just an OK veggie soup, no borscht about it! 

The menu gave me a Thursday special price of $12.95 and the bill was $11.95, which is kind of weird. Why not let people know it isn't as awful as it seems price wise. 

Service was awful, I don't think a staff could be found that could have cared less. The slowness might be from being invoved in a waking, walking nightmare. Good place for a time warp!
author: Tom A.

description: Worst matza ball soup ever. Just all around horrible. Frozen peas and carrots. Dirty water glasses. You have to try to be this bad.
author: Chet C.

description:
I went here after 10 am for breakfast because other places in the area had a long wait.  As soon as I sat down at the front, a waitress put down a menu and silverware for me.  I ordered coffee and Eggs and Sausage with hash browns and rye bread, which all came out within 10 minutes.  The coffee came in a small cup, but the waitress was good about refilling.  The food was nothing to be impressed about, but it was fast.  I paid $9.95 for the food, $2.95 for the coffee.

4 stars because 1. I got to sit immediately, 2. coffee was refilled quickly, and 3. food came out fast.


EDIT:
6/9/13

Note: both times I was there, I went to the to-go/bar area.

I stopped in again today, and I must have come in on a good day the other time.  The waitress seemed to be busy and flustered.  I saw another guy who had arrived before me ask the waitress to order, and she put up her finger, shook her head, and walked away as if to say hold on, I'm too busy right now.  Bad customer service... the same effort could have been used to say "hold on I'll be right with you."  The other customer ordered, but after a few more minutes, left.  He had ordered a coffee and hot chocolate to go, which he probably thought shouldn't take longer than 5 minutes (and I would agree).

In any case, my food took a little longer than the last time (must have been a slow kitchen day), and that particular plate seemed overpriced.  I don't plan on coming back.
author: Sam R.

description:
The only reason I will accept giving this place one star is because the lox sandwich I ordered wasn't too bad.
But everything else was.
We were totally craving a bagel and lox, a nice jewish delicatessen, and were excited to find this place....I just wish I had really looked at yelp first.  

There was confusion in ordering, the lox sandwich was $13.95.  I asked if there were options for the type of bagel, a few.  Asked if there was chive cream cheese, and that seemed to really throw the waitress off.  She said they just have the type of cream cheese that they put on bagels.  ok. plain it is. I asked for some soup, which the menu said would be $3.50 additional, if you got barley, split pea, or something else.  Well I ordered the barley, they didnt have any, so we decided on some basic chicken noodle (btw, totally bland and boring, a waste of $3.50).  Still, not hating the place - the sandwich was tasty enough.

We get the check, and it is all handwritten, no total.  We wanted to leave a cash tip and then go up front to pay, so I quickly tallied up the #s on the check, figured it would be around $40 ish, so we should tip off of that.

I get up front, and start noticing all of these numbers appearing on the register that i didnt see on the check!  Total comes to $58!  So I politely asked if I could look at the check again, and the woman instantly started to get on the defensive "well, the check says $13.95, but really its $15.95.  your chicken soup is actually $8, not $3.50...it went on like this for a bit.  I grabbed a menu and pointed to what we ordered with the listed price,  and was trying to to be pushy about it, but also wanting to let her know that i just saw her punching in random numbers - making our bill maybe $20 more!

We ended up just giving up, signing the credit card slip and walking out.

Horrible people, NOT at all a delicatessen - they dont make the bagels, they had no idea that cream cheese could come with chives, and they like to cheat people.
NO THANKS.
author: meg p.

description: Assuming the food is good because the Deli looks like it has been around for a long time was the wrong choice here. We had a uninspired, and even plain breakfast here that was overpriced. The only thing that I enjoyed and would get to go is the chocolate coconut maccaroons in the windor. Skip the rest.
author: Crystal K.

description: One star is generous! This place went down hill then fell off a cliff. Rude, slow and incompetent service. Terrible food and the dining room was filthy and smelled like spoiled fish. Don't eat here unless the health department goes in first!
author: Harry F.

description:
Hard to rate this place. I was there at an odd time  about 3pm - had skipped lunch so was really hungry. I ordered a hamburger and fries. They were . . . okay. Freshly cooked - for sure - I could hear them being cooked because the rest of the restaurant was empty. They were good enough that if I had been served them at someone's home I would complement them on how tasty the food is and not feel guilty - assuming i was a guest and not paying for the meal. Although, let us face it - when the food is free, you either compliment it or . . . decide the friendship is not worth it. 

However I paid $14 and change PLUS tip . . . not nearly good enough. Probably should have been closer to $10 with tip.  Service was fine, but not much was involved and I was literally the only customer in the whole place the entire time.

Again, not terrible, but not very good either.
author: Serena U.

description:
this place used to have better Sauerbraten, but the last time I was there the portion of sauerbraten and latke's was small and chintzy .  
The flavor was not as good either. Decor is 1950's cheesy along with bad coffee. The owner should take notice and improve this schlocky food.
author: Bert K.

description:
When I travel back to well-loved places, I tend to gravitate back to past experiences, almost in attempt to replicate previous successful trips. I'm a creature of habit, it seems, which is sad, and yet, I keep doing it. 

About ten years ago, I stayed at a hotel up the street from David's Delicatessen and basically haunted the busy deli for several meals, mostly for the delicious pea soup, amazing mocha cakes (think adult Ho-Ho's) and fantastic bread. I always meant to return, but life gets in the way, and hadn't until two years ago, when we went for a severely dismal breakfast -- and expensive! I apologized to my guests, who were trusting me to make restaurant suggestions on their first trip to the city. I didn't know what happened! Must have been an off day, I said in apology, because this place is normally amazing. Then I went back a year ago and had another "off day", forgetting about how bad our breakfast had been the previous year. Apparently it takes a year to forget a bad experience, because last week I found myself walking down Geary Street, hungry, and saw David's and thought "Hey, that place is really good!" 

Yes, I'm a bit stupid.

It's bad, you guys. It's so bad. The meatloaf was reheated and grey, the mashed potatoes had a hair in them and the veggie accompaniment was so overcooked that the broccoli had turned to grey green mush puddles. The challah bread, supposedly freshly made every day, was at least a week old, or had been left in front of a fan to expedite the staleness factor. Also, as other Yelpers have said, I got a glass that had someone else's lip prints on it. This suggests that the dishwasher at David's isn't using hot water to melt the waxes in lipgloss, which has more terrifying implications than just a gross lip print. It was like I had wandered into a "Waiter there's a fly in my soup" joke.

Don't do it, guys. Don't succumb to the previous glowing reviews of David's, because this place has definitely declined from "Heavenly" into "Run Like Hell."
author: Wendy B.

description:
My husband had the french toast - it came out cold and without any powdered sugar.  I had the special which was advertised as a cheese omelet with turkey bacon, thinking it would be like an actual omelet with you know, the turkey bacon in it?  Wrong - it was a giant swiss cheese omelet with three massive slices of turkey bacon on the side.  Gross.  The waitress forgot my toast too, which I needed to quell the feeling of nausea I had after eating a straight swiss cheese omelet.

The food might have at least been acceptable if the prices here weren't so awful. We got the bill and it was over $40.  $40!!!!  I'm not even joking. $5 for a glass of orange juice?  Double gross.
author: Kristen W.

description: I was drawn into this place for the desserts in the window.  This place is just plane dirty.  There were flies flying everywhere and hovered over our plates.  The place just needs a throuuuuugh cleaning.  The food was actually alright, but the dishes were way over priced.  Won't be coming back.
author: Clay C.

description:
Apparently this business was sold (again) in August of 2011 according to SF DPH records. There are no current health violations reported but if it's anything like the past few years' ratings - customers beware! I knew this place had hit the skids but needed a breakfast meal and every other place worth eating at was jammed. As to my request for decaf coffee, the reply was "We only have regular". The lox and onion omelette was - how shall I say it - not even an omelette, just burned eggs with a few chunks of salmon-y flavored fish. At least the rye bread was edible. The tip-off was that at 10 AM on a weekend the counter was not even half-full. Oh yes- and the instruction to "leave the tip on the counter" seemed presumptuous, to say the least.! 

If I could give the place no stars, I would. The owner ought to be arrested for trading on the good name of David Apfelbaum, who apparently was careless enough to sell his name along with the business years ago. I have fond memories of eating at this place starting in the 1970's, when the food was delicious and the portions more than ample. A sign pointing the way to  "Celebrity Corner, No Smoking" is the about only thing left on walls that as I recall were once covered with photos of the famous. The original menu board mounted up high on one wall has been partially covered over in a sort of disparaging way. The banners under the awning outside still proudly proclaim "51 Years!" - that was 9 years ago, when David still owned the place. Shame on these people!!
author: paul r.

description:
Worst Meal EVER!  $35 for a small bowl of matzoh ball soup, potato latkes and 1 cup of coffee. WTF?

The soup was literally broth & 2 flavorless matzoh balls-no carrots, no celery. I never use salt -ever- especially not on soup which is usually too salty & I had to put salt & pepper on it cause it tasted like bland dishwater & soggy bread balls.

Plus, when I asked the lady at the pastry counter for change for the meter, she wouldn't even give it to me, knowing that I was already half-way through my meal.  Not to mention she was asian, NOT Jewish, which explains why the food sucked-not authentic.
author: Shannanigans001 ..

description:
Went here on a recent trip to San Francisco with my boyfriend. Probably the best thing about the Deli is its authentic 50s diner interior, which probably only exists because the place hasn't been remodeled in 60 years. The main seating is comprised of barstools at a counter surrounding a drink and dessert island. Our server, who appeared to be the only person in there when we entered, was reading a newspaper at the other side of the bar for the majority of the time we were there. He was attentive enough, but didn't seem to understand my initial order of corned beef and potatoes, an item on the breakfast menu. He was convinced I wanted to order the corned beef hash, and after a long day of airports and homeless people, I gave in after two attempts at correcting him.

The menu is pretty expansive for what we took to be a hole-in-the-wall diner and our meal started out well. I was pretty excited to order some cream soda (I hadn't had any in at least five years) and my boyfriend got Russian cabbage soup. The soup was pretty amazing. It tasted a little like sweet minestrone and had lots of vegetables. I had high hopes for the main course, but I was let down pretty badly with my corned beef hash.

The corned beef hash was covered by three poached eggs, which were the only thing that made the meal at all palatable. The corned beef hash was mostly just finely-chopped fat and had the mildly offensive taste of old, congealed grease. The accompanying hash browns were almost as greasy and completely flavorless. I had to utilize a ton of hot sauce to make it through half the meal. Luckily, it came with a toasted bagel so I was able to fill up on that.

My boyfriend got a corned beef sandwich (we must have really been craving corned beef that day) which turned out to be pretty good. I'm pretty picky about corned beef and the stuff on his sandwich was tender, flavorful, and almost free of fat. Unfortunately, my own meal pretty much ruined the experience for me and the $20 it cost for my soda and breakfast plate really only bought me disappointment and a stomach ache.
author: Colleen D.

description:
Lox are good, deli counter service is slow and unfriendly, but pastries seem to be the bees knees.

Just wanted a quick bagel with lox to go. Had seen the badass-looking pastries in the window and was intrigued by the possibility of a NY-style deli/restaurant, at least with quick service or bombass bagels or...dare I ask...both?!

In the end, bagel and lox taste great but are a lil pricey at $14. Pickles they came with are regular old jarred pickles (my homemade pickles would kick their ass). The lox on the bagel get 4 stars. Bagel itself gets 2 stars for being smaller and not NY-awesome. Only choices were sesame, plain and onion. 

The service gets 1 star. Slow and unfriendly. Lady behind the deli counter was unhappy to take an order, walked away and left me hanging while ringing their counter bell a third time (since the sign tells you to) like a lost child. The girl serving the tables had to go get her back in the kitchen somewhere. After I asked if it includes tomatoes, onions and capers she seemed annoyed that I asked and that she would have to actually move her arms, legs and hands to add those on. But they tasted good in the end.

The other ladies working the tables seemed nice, the menu items "sounded" tasty (maybe a bit overpriced and apparently sub-par from other reviews) and the pastries might be the only thing worth it in there.

I'd go back to try a pastry and only if I'm not in a rush.

Oh ya, she wiped the cream cheese off the knife into a damp towel that lives in one of the stainless steel condiment trays  to "clean" it before directly putting my cream cheese on the bagel. This didn't bother me but might bother others.
author: Alex B.

description: Horrible customer service!!!!  DO NOT recommend!! I would give it a negative five if I could.  It was my husband and my first in SF.  Walked by the deli and saw all the delicious desserts in the window.  We went inside and were planning to buy several for our road trip.  As we are trying to decide on which ones to pick in the display case, my husband asked The lady behind the counter, Juliet, if one of the dessert was a filled croissant.  Juliet rudely responded, "We don't sell croissants here!  If you want a croissant, you need to go to Starbucks!!"  My husband and I were shocked, surprised, and taken back by that response.  He told her that he apologize, but was just wondering what the dessert was because it looks like a croissant.  She then barked at him that it was an apple turnover and not a croissant.  He wants a croissant, go to Starbucks.  At the point, I decided that no place who treats customers like she did deserves my money.  I was about to buy several items.  I told her she was rude when she didn't have to be.  I asked her if I could speak to a manager or owner.  She said there was no manager on duty, and that it was a franchise.  At that point, i went over to another employee, got her name, and the number, and left the restaurant.
author: Khailah H.

description: They deserve less than one star, actually. Had this been a greasy-spoon quick serve restaurant at budget prices, then two stars would have been my rating. But nah, they're charging fine-dining prices and delivering sub-standard food. I ordered the chef salad, full of wilted lettuce, some of which I had to pull out because it had started rotting. My wife's and son's soups were oily, bland and apparently full of corn starch. Ick! My other son's burger was passable, but the accompanying fries were soggy and luke-warm. Add the fact that we spent most of our eating time shooing away fruit flies and house flies, the end result was a very unpleasant experience. Stay away!
author: Alfredo C.

description: I have been going to David's for years.  Since my son is now eighteen, I can safely say at least twenty years.  I dropped in for lunch before The Christmas Carol, yesterday, 12/01.  Was throughly disappointed.  Salad was actually droopy.  Pastrami was dumped in hot water to warm, so read was soaked with water, but pastrami that did not hit the water was hard.  Burger was good.  The waitress was the most surly person I have ever met.  When we asked about. Out food which was taking an extremely long period of time, she said, " you ordered a burger."  After 20 years I am leaving.
author: Steven W.

description:
You know what I love? A Jewish deli. You know what I *really* love? A fine mothalovin' corned beef sandwich. Outside of those two things, however, David's Delicatessen failed miserably at every other aspect of my experience there today. 

I visited David's on a whim today because I was starving and wanted to grab a couple of quick sandwiches  to take back to my hotel room. I really should have Yelped this place first! I ordered the hot corned beef and cheese sandwich, asking the woman behind the counter to substitute wheat bread for the rye and use Swiss cheese. For the second sandwich, I ordered a salami and cheddar on wheat. 

First, the woman took 25 minutes to make the two sandwiches, with most of the time taken up by her wrestling with the meat slicer. By the time she was finished, I just wanted to get the hell out of there, so I quickly paid and quickstepped back to my hotel.

When I opened the bag, my corned beef sandwich had cheddar instead of Swiss. Grr. However, the omission was quickly forgiven when I took a bite. Damn, that corned beef is EXCELLENT. It was warm, not too fatty, sliced thin and piled high. YUM. If I could eat that every day and not keel over from a heart attack by the age of 35, I would.

The salami sandwich, on the other hand, was horrendous. It was Sahara-dry and flavorless.  The accompanying pickles were limp and sad. Conversely, the potato salad was good -- it had a whipped consistency that I like, and it wasn't too mayonnaisey. 

At least the woman behind the counter was nice and apologetic for how long it took for the sandwiches to be done. It's too bad that everything else other than the corned beef sandwich sucked, because this place seems to have so much history and future potential.
author: Avitania B.

description:
A shandeh! Should have looked it up before I forked over thirteen dollars for such a shameful sandwich. Three listless curls of warmed-over pastrami. Lifeless bread more knotty pine than rye. A thimble-sized Chinese take-out basket with potatoes au goop -- at essence, packing peanuts in wallpaper paste. A sliver of limp pickle, almost emo in its shrugging, demure listlessness.

All this for the same price as the same menu item at Katz's. Send a salami to your boy on the army indeed. David's could use a Jewish Deli boot camp, that's for sure.

Overpriced and underwhelming.
author: Steve D.

description: Good, solid breakfast faire, but rather overpriced for a diner type atmosphere. The affiliation with the Touchstone Hotel explains the price, but not the service which was rather poor. In fairness, my guess is that they were shorts tagged this day, and it was the waiter's first day on the job.
author: Mike G.

description: A rather cozy American "diner-place", where you can also enjoy the cakes and other pastries. Boring local and not so many guests. But the cake was delicious. But not the best I have experienced.
author: Jesper H.

description:
Sigh. I'll chalk this up as a lesson, that I should check Yelp religiously before trying new places.

We got in and sat down, and I looked at the prices of their sandwiches. $18.95? For a Reuben? That better be as good as a Pulp-Fiction-$5-milkshake. But, no. It wasn't that good at all. If it were $6.95, I would have written it off as a meager effort. At $18.95, it feels like robbery.

Also, my daughter wanted a fruit cup with cottage cheese. $9.95. Apparently, they were out of actual fruit-cup-style fruit, so they cut up an apple, stuck it in a bowl with an orange slice, and served it.

I'm surprised they're in business.
author: Charlie P.

description:
This is a gem in a city that doesn't have very many delicatessens!  The Hungarian Goulash was amazing!  The meat was soft, lean, and melts in your mouth!  The sauce was perfect: flavorful but not too salty.  The egg noodles were light and not too heavy.  Corned beef hash with poached eggs were also good with rye bread.  I can't wait to come back and try their split pea soup and corned beef sandwich.  mmm...yummy to my tummy.  If you have room for dessert and coffee, go for it!  You will not be disappointed by their wide selection of desserts!

Oh yes, don't be fooled by all the empty tables you see and sparse people eating at their counter space!   There are two rooms in the back that you don't see!  As I quote from a customer that has been going to David's since 1961, this place is an institution and a staple since its been around since the 50's.
author: Phuong T.

description: When you walk into David's you feel like you're going back in time to the 60s, with the wooden signage by the kitchen, and the counter style seating. However, I found the menu choices to be lacking, wished there were more options. The value wasn't too compelling.  The service was nice though.
author: John M.

description:
