Historic deli that used to be decent.  Sadly, it is now terrible for the most part.  The food quality is mediocre.  The staff is nice enough but service is off-the-charts incompetent.  Good luck getting served in a timely fashion regardless of how slow it appears to be.  Good luck getting your order correct as well: I can repeat nicely that I want the soup four times, but it still does not appear--and the waiter tells me I didn't order it because it's not on his receipt.  Just as well because the soup is so bland (used to be quite good even a couple of years ago).  

I wanted this place to stop its decline, but have to say it is a mystery how this restaurant stays in business now.  Sad.
author: Bill G.

description:
In short: "Don't do it!" The worst meal out I can remember eating this millennium. Bad food (you know how they describe food as cooked with love -- this was cooked with disdain), awful service, dreary environment. I'm not sure how this place stays in business.

In detail: Ended up here for Sunday brunch here with my husband and in-laws after two other venues we tried were either too crowded or didn't have eat-in options. My mother-in-law is fond of delis, how bad could a deli be? We were seated in a smallish side room, the waitress was somewhat slow to take our order, but so far nothing alarming. The room was frigid, uncomfortably so, but again I would overlook this otherwise. A few other tables were seated after us as we waited for our food. And waited...after about 30-40 minutes of waiting and watching other tables who were seated after us get their food, we inquired with our waitress. She told us that what we ordered takes awhile, apparently the corned beef hash was slowing the whole order down. Our food finally arrived...I had eggs with onions, with a side of fruit. It was the most pathetic plate of food I had ever seen...my eggs were cold, there were 4 or 5 chunks of fruit thrown on the plate. The "special" corned beef hash was old, dried corned beef cut up and mixed with mashed potatoes. The blintzes were clearly defrosted and topped with disgusting, processed blueberry sludge. There were no apologies for the massive delay in the food. When we left, my father in law (who is the most gentle and generous guy), went up to pay and said this was the most memorably horrible meal he has ever had. The cashier took his money and handed him the receipt. The whole experience was kind of worth it because as we were waiting in front of the restaurant for him to pay I noticed a young couple slowing down and peering in to the deli. I said "Don't do it" kind of under my breath. But they heard me and ran, and we got our laugh for the day.

So to all of you: "Don't do it!"
author: Bekki H.

description: Had the cornbeef and pastrami sandwich.  WOW!  Enough meat for 3 sandwiches.  And it was great!  Dr. Browns Black Cherry Soda.  I believe that they brought NY to SF.  I will be back to try some other things on the menu!
author: Kenneth G.

description:
The 4 stars is based on my experience w/ the dessert selections only.  I had a slice of the flourless chocolate cake.. a whopping $7.61 total per slice.  I admit, it was good but for almost $10 seems like such a rip off.

I still have yet to try their soup/salad/sandwiches.

The lady at the sweets counter was rude and unfriendly.  I almost walked out because of the snooty attitude I was given.  Me and my daughter were standing there trying to see what they have because there are no signage on the selections.. the lady was behind me waiting impatiently and said, "Excuse me" w/ a fucking attitude because she needed to go behind the counter.  Seriously.. you guys employ people like that?  

If it weren't for the cake.. I will give this place a 1 star.
author: Tram N.

description:
Short and simple. Don't eat here. Expensive, terrible food (cold, poorly presented, bad taste), and mediocre service.

I sat and wondered how they stay in business.
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Goodness, I wish I would have read the reviews before I went to this place. It was absolutely a waste of time and money.

Yes, they have a big selection...of extremely overpriced things around San Francisco, especially considering what they are.

My husband and I stopped by there for brunch, though both were really craving breakfast. The place was empty, which should have been a sign, but it still took us over 5 minutes to get a menu. Then another 10 to order. I ended up paying $8 for some eggs and hash browns. My husband ordered blueberry pancakes, which should have been yummy. It was an order of regular pancakes with blueberry jam smeared in between. Disappointed? That would be an understatement. 

The tea was a joke - $3 for a small pot which would amount to a regular coffee cup of your basic $2.95 for the entire box kind of a tea. The bagel was decent. But coming back for just a bagel... Don't think so.

Overall it was a terrible experience considering how many wonderful diners are around the area.
author: Yelena K.

description:
Tourist Trap is an understatement.  I wish I had looked at Yelp before making the mistake of going here for Breakfast.  After waiting 25 minutes for my poached eggs; they arrived raw and uncooked.  The corned beef hash looked like it was directly from the Hormel can and it wasn't well cooked either.

However I'll admit, their coffee was pretty good.
author: Ali S.

description:
Don't be drawn in by the delicious-looking baked goods in the window, it's a trap!

It's very run down. We sat in the back left diner area where there happened to be a random piece of plank wood just sitting under a sitting booth. Odd. Next, the chairs are worn down and it just isn't a great presentation in regards to the setting. 

We ordered the "twisted egg French toast," which I say was satisfying, not great, but satisfying. However the hashed browns  were absolutely horrible, almost slung onto the plate like they were hastily thrown there and they were COLD!

Finally, my glass of water had some black debris just randomly floating in it which means the cleanliness level is probably not very high.

This place was a waste of 32 bucks.
author: The Gentleman I.

description: We've eaten a delicious breakfast at David's more than once and loved it each time.  The challah is light as a feather.
author: Maury C.

description:
I went here with a friend for coffee and desserts late one afternoon after we spotted the amazing looking pastries in the display window as we walked past the diner. Once we got in, we could tell that this place had been around for a while. There were few people in the diner, mostly tourists.

We waited patiently as there was only one person working behind the counter, once he did decide to come over he brought a tray which contained all of the desserts that are on display in the front of the restaurants and was happy to tell us what everything was.

I ended up ordering some sort of hazelnut praline pastry and my friend got an almond puff or something like that. Our coffee was good, nice and strong and we were given real cream, none of that fake creamer in a pack stuff. The desserts were delicious, rich, and filling. Just what we were craving at the moment. 

All in all, the place could use a little sprucing up, but I would go back to try more of their pastries and maybe some of their breakfast items.
author: Vineet T.

description:
A friend of mine and I went here because this was my usual hangout when I went to the theatre on a regular basis years ago. Well, apparently time has not been kind. My g'friend wanted cheese blintzes but they were out. They were also out of two other items on the menu. It reminded me of the "I Love Lucy" episode where Lucy and Ethel open a restaurant, and run out of food, only this situation wasn't funny.
We both ended up getting a corned beef sandwich on rye. Both were good, but no dressing on the bread whatsoever. I had to ask for the mayo, the mustard, and the guy also gave us hot mustard and a dressing of some sort. The guy was in charge of the counter and the cashier. There weren't that many people (which is probably a testament to how bad this place is), so he wasn't overwhelmed. It looked like there was one cook.
Even if you're desperate for a bite to eat, avoid this place at all cost. There's plenty of other places on Geary & Mason if you really need to eat something. It's sad really, because I enjoyed going to this place years ago. Whoever owns or manages it obviously doesn't give a rip.
author: Diane F.

description: As I begin to write this review my husband says "it's hard to review a place you can't get food served". We went in at 10am on a Saturday. The bar seating had about four customers. We sat in the dining room. The lone diners. Well except for the swarm of flies overhead. We ordered juice and coffee, corned beef hash and knishes. We never saw the waitress again. We waiting about 20 minutes.  While we werewaiting I checked the Yelp reviews and saw how much the place had apparently declined. I got up, went to the cashier and told her we had been waiting for 20 minutes and assumed our server had left the building. She had no comment. I told her I wanted to pay for my juice and my husbands coffee. She just said $6.83.  I said "for a juice and a coffee?!?!  No response.  Of course we won't be back. But I'm sure no one cares.
author: Kelli A.

description: I was told by snobs not to come here after I said I wanted a deli sandwich. Walked around the block to the places they recommended - all super overkill expensive and disgusting sounding combos with tempeh. For a good old fashioned diner - this is it. Don't be mislead by stupid sf foodies trying to be cooler than a deli.
author: tt p.

description:
My husband and I popped in for breakfast before a long day of sight-seeing. It was close to our hotel, and was (presumably) better than Jack in the Box, so we gave it a go. I hadn't looked at the reviews for this place before sitting down, so when I Yelped it, I was a little nervous. But, I'm not sure what all the negativity is about. 

Our waitress was nice. Our food took a little longer than the people sitting around us, and she apologized for that. Not super friendly chatty, but certainly not rude. 

The place was clean. There were no dirty dishes strewn about. When customers left, the staff was quick to clean up, for the most part. It got a little busy right before we left and there were maybe two plates that hadn't been picked up. But, as far as I could tell, there was really only one person working the counter. During breakfast, there should probably be at least one more. 

Food was good - for a diner. Better than a Denny's. The corned beef hash was actually quite good. And while the blueberry pancakes weren't what I was expecting (blueberry jam folded into the pancake, instead of blueberries in the batter), they were pretty good. The hashbrowns definitely could have been crisper, but that's usually true wherever I order them. I like extra crispy hashbrowns, and should have asked for them that way. The coffee was strong, but not very good. Just your average Maxwell House-ish stuff.

I will agree on one thing: The place is expensive. $35 for breakfast is too much, especially if I'm not having the best breakfast in the world.
author: Krissi H.

description:
You come to David's for the food, albeit expensive deli food.  I ordered the corned beef sandwich that came piled with 2 inches of corned beef on rye with creamy potato salad.  Both were delicious!   The serving of potato salad was a bit stingy, but generous with the corned beef.    The sandwich is $11.95 which was one of the lower priced ones on the menu.  What you really want to order is the lunch special that includes beer plus the sandwich of the day for $13.95.  They have similar dinner specials.

The service is OK to bad.  My server did refill my iced tea without asking, but didn't ask how the food was, did I want dessert, etc.  That got him a 10% tip when I normally do 20%.
author: Scott S.

description: I'm staying at the Cliff in SF. So I tried David's deli. I must say this was the worst deli experience i Jane ever had. The service was terrible and the the food was not editable
author: Michael L.

description:
We went here because there was no line. Rookie mistake. But boyfriend was hungry, so ....

Summarized: Dripping cooler and a long wait. The waiter was friendly but the kitchen was very slow. We had to wait over a half hour for a bagel with cream cheese and eggs and sausage.  That is not USA style service. The food was ok, but nothing special.
author: Maaike V.

description: My daughter and I went there for breakfast yesterday morning.  The waitress asked us if we were ready to order.  I told her we were not ready yet but we would like to order something to drink.  She told us we could't order something to drink until we ordered our food.  She noticed the the look of shock on my face and said ok (not very nicely with some eye rolling as well)  I asked for a decaf coffee.  She abruptly told me that they did not have any decaf coffee (What breakfast place does not offer decaf coffee)  Bottom line she was rude and acted as if she was doing us a favor instead of us being the customers.  Needless to say we walked out.
author: Denise Z.

description: Wish I'd checked Yelp first. Corned beef sandwich was fatty, stringy and sad. Pickle inedible, fries hard. Looks nice from the outside. But be warned!
author: Joel S.

description:
If you look at my other reviews, you can tell I'm pretty lenient on a lot of things so the fact that I'm taking the time to write a bad review says a lot.

Anyway....

Some friends and I were looking for a new place to eat and found ourselves outside of David's Deli. What the hell, we thought. My husband approved of the nice selection of chocolate dipped pastries in the front window. I was really in the mood for some sandwiches. Our friends were hungry and didn't care either way.  

We walked in, and it was dark and scary. No one smiled at us or let us know where we could sit. The asian lady up front looked really angry and the handful of other customers in there were talking in hushed voices. 

Ok....

Since there were 5 of us, we asked if we could sit at a table instead of the bar. We noticed they had a whole room of pretty tables and booths to the right of the entrance. The angry asian lady gestured to the very back of the room behind the bar and told us TABLES IN THE BACK!

Ok.....

We went to the back, sat down, and waited. No one showed up. My friend went back to the front to ask for menus. She ended up getting them herself.

Ok.....

After looking at the menu, there were a couple of things we wanted to try but the room was cramped, the carpet was dirty, and NO ONE CAME TO TAKE OUR ORDERS. I mean, if we were suppose to order up front, we'd be happy to do that but dude, you could let us know what the procedure was. Yeesh.

Is a smile too much to ask?????

We walked out of there without purchasing anything and spent $100 at another restaurant. 

Nice going, David.
author: Susan P.

description: One of the worst meals I tried to consume in years, even though ravenous. Just terrible beef brisket. I doubt my dog would've eaten it. Canned veggies? Bread stale. Choc mousse cake old and grainy. Felt sorry for nice waiter. Should've been alert to near empty seats.
author: Curt H.

description:
Do not set your expectations too high.  The place is old, expensive for what you get, but for me it brings back memories of coming to this place with my Uncle in the early 60's.  That and if you hit it just right the experience can be worth it.  Many pan it on Yelp; maybe their expectations were too high going in.  I don't know.  I love the joint.

You just can't find a NY style pastrami on rye with a good pickle west of the Mississippi these days unless you are in the City (SF) and stop by David's for lunch.  They used to have pickled beef tongue also, but they don't serve it any longer (I guess it is a lost taste along with mountain oysters and sweet breads).

Yes; I was in the City yesterday and could not resist the temptation to indulge myself on this culinary masterpiece, hot pastrami on rye.  I got everything I bargained for; the sandwich was over 3" thick on corn rye, yellow mustard, the pickle had full pucker power, and the server was as surly and impatient as any NY deli waiter.  It was like I was sitting right there at the Stage Deli having the same meal.

Some things never change and David's since 195? And David's is one of those things you can depend on.
author: Gary J.

description:
DON'T ever go here unless you want a $17 smoked salmon bagel!
Here I was, hungover, wanting a nice bagel with smoked salmon in it. When I looked at the place I knew it was more expensive than usual. 
They had a lot of yummy looking pastries on display and the inside looks cozy. BUT THEN........
as I was lining up for my order I noticed they didn't put any price on their sandwiches. If i know their bagel is $17, I'd scram immediately!
author: Miss C.

description:
On my walk back to my car from shopping in union square, a delicious looking black and white cookie caught my eye in the window of this place.

"That will be $3.61."  I thought that was pretty pricey for 1 cookie, probably the most expensive cookie I ever purchased.  

And guess what?  It was the most disgusting cookie I have ever tasted!  I couldn't even finish the 'chocolate' iced side - it tasted NOTHING like chocolate, just plain nasty.
author: Ali G.

description:
Horribly disappointed.  

Where to begin?  They were out of knishes, cole slaw and the menu had not been updated in years.  And $18.95 for a sandwich is robbery, especially for such subpar food.  I am from the east coast (NY) and may be a bit of a snob when it comes to this stuff, but in San Francisco, we have certain standards as a whole, and this was very, very disappointing.

Oh, and i hate to dog the people who work there, but the service was crap and the cooks were all clueless.

Don't waste your time or your money.
author: David C.

description: I'm not quite sure why the bad reviews? We were in the city for a couple if days and had lunch twice here. I've had the pastrami and the corned beef and both times they were great. My wife had chicken soup and an egg salad sandwich and was also happy wither the meals. Service was great and the waiter really nice and attentive. Prices too high? This is the city! The prices were inexpensive, if you want cheaper go eat at Jack in the Box down the street!
author: Photog M.

description:
Did not realize Dottys' was closed on Tuesdays. 
Did not Yelp for a back up. 
Fell for the bait and switch that is the display of deserts in the window. 

We ordered eggs, bacon, hash browns, the bacon was old and overcooked. 
The blueberry pancakes were absolutely disgusting. They consisted of two pancakes rolled and filled with about a half a pies worth of canned blueberry pie filling that was cold straight outta the can. 
Coffee was old and undrinkable.
We refused to pay for the pancakes and there was some atitiude while she attempted to jack us for an extra coffee.

Avoid at all costs.
author: Jason S.

description:
I would love to I ate here, but it seems like the lady behind the counter took pride in telling me no to every request from "do you serve knishes" onward.  

Honestly if a Jew from queens can't find something to eat in a Jewish deli what good is it?
author: Alexander B.

description: So awful.  Tasteless food, expensive, and it comes straight down from the top.  Avoid like the plague!
author: Gabriel D.

description:
Maybe you have to be Jewish to appreciate this place.  I go in on an early morning, a little weary eyed.  I get a nice breakfast -- eggs, hash browns and bacon.  And coffee or tea.  I'm gluten intolerant and highly sensitive to soy product and I always feel good when I eat here.  Most diners use crappy vegetable oil and I feel sick just eating a few bites.

The service is fine.  They are not all over you and they are always genuine and friendly.  I definitely recommend the seats around the bar rather than the tables if you want faster service.

I've been here 3 times and counting, and I've never left feeling unsatisfied.

Sure the price is higher than other cheap diners/delis nearby but the ingredients are much higher quality, so you get what you pay for.
author: Evie S.

description:
Skip it. 

$16 for the worst (read: no flavor / small portion) corn beef hash I've ever had. The eggs were cooked perfectly and the bagel wasn't bad, which is why I'm being friendly and giving David's two stars instead of one. 

The place could use a good scrub. I had to hold back the urge to start cleaning the counter top and the floor right then and there. The service was okay but nothing extraordinare. 

Prices are ridiculous for the lack of quality. $3.95 for one egg. REALLY?
author: Amanda R.

description:
I've worked in the Union Square area for six years without ever eating at David's. Should have kept it that way...

Newsflash: the key ingredient in gyulash is paprika!!
(And friggin' learn how to spell it, it's GYULASH, it's got nothing to do with mythical monsters)

And with prices being as high as they are at David's (even for this area), I'm not going back to see if anything else on the menu is better.

Meh.
author: Tatjana G.

description: Went here for breakfast.  Their breakfast offerings seemed to be simple items, excellently prepared but overpriced.  (The one surprising exception was the fresh orange marmalade served with the toast, a definite plus).  It was uncrowded, and service was okay.  I enjoyed my meal, but I don't think it was a good value.
author: Samuel F.

description:
Wow, if I'd looked at Yelp first, I wouldn't have gone near this place. 

Walked past this spot on the way to my hotel and later I found myself hungry after walking all over the city.

I went in later afternoon and the place was empty. I sat at the counter and looked over the menu. Prices kind of high, but I figured I'm in downtown SF, so overhead is a little higher. 

Finally decided on a tuna salad on rye with some cabbage borscht.  The soup was piping hot and really tasty. It definitely hit the spot.

Next came the sandwich with potato salad and a pickle. Tuna salad was quite good, pickle was so-so, and potato salad was pretty good. The rye bread was not that fresh or tasty. The mustard sitting on the counter was really spicy and livened up the meal, not to mention my sinuses.

Dropping a $20 for soup and a sandwich is a little much. Maybe I'd try it again for the pastrami and see if it really is less for take out.

I'd say it was a 2.5 star experience. I thought my service was adequate, not really attentive with "how is everything?, etc", but kept my water full the entire time I was there.
author: Danphi V.

description:
David's Delicatessen is such a poor facsimile of a Jewish deli.  It is a grim looking place and I was hungry for some old fashion chicken liver on a hot bagel.

The space is large and airy but not well done.  Basically, I was hoping for great chopped chicken livers and got the worst.

What a poor dish it was.  I really should have left as it wasn't worth paying for.  The chicken livers had nary a bit of schmaltz or sauteed onions, it tasted as it it had been made with water, not silky as usual.

The wait staff is not on their toes and I waited to pay my bill until I had to flag someone down.

Max's always had great chopped chicken livers, I heard they no longer made it at their Geary store.  Boo Hoo..

La Regina E
author: ELINOR H.

description: We had the Ruben, great sandwich, old school environment, like it!
author: Joe F.

description:
It saddens me to see the horrible review this place gets, but if we are to rate David's on service alone, the place would definitely get 1 star.

However, every time I come San Fran, I make a stop at David's to order the reuben sandwich. It's piled high with the most delicious corned beef, it is really, really good. 

I usually end my visit by ordering a few desserts to go from the weird Asian lady. Her desserts are awesome, but i just don't understand how the two establishments work. Is she renting the space or is she part of David's Delicatessen. Regardless, order the sandwich and desserts to go, and you will have a fabulous experience as well. 

And if you're thirsty, go down a few blocks to the Clift Hotel. Best hotel and drinks in San Fran. LOVE IT!
author: Hina K.

description: The service level varied amongs the staff. It took a while to get the order, the hashed browns where a bit cold when served. But the coffe was ok, fresh restrooms and the rest of the meals was ok!
author: Agnes N.

description: Terrible food! We ordered a bagel, toast, bacon and a cinnamon roll. Everything was cold. Cold and tasteless. Coffee was ordered but not served and our meal cost 24 dollars. Avoid at all costs.
author: Tommy W.

description:
This is the first and last time I go somewhere before yelping it. I should've known better. David's was completely empty at lunch despite it's location in Union Square, save two sketchy customers. And it seemed a little dark and really dingy. How did I end up here?

My friend and I had just stuffed ourselves silly at Colibri Mexican Bistro, but we couldn't go back to law school hell without dessert. We noticed some good-looking desserts in David's window. Unfortunately, they were good from far but far from good--much like the people you meet in bars or clubs after one too many drinks.

My friend had the Napoleon and I had the Chocolate Mousse Cake. They were so underwhelming and so overpriced ($7-8). I felt gross after a few bites. It wouldn't be a surprise to me if the desserts had been sitting there for a week before we stupidly bought them. NEVER AGAIN.
author: Liz T.

description:
Matzo Ball soup just like Nana used to make!

....if Nana sucked balls at making matzo ball soup.

ps. not good!
author: Gabe b.

description:
Worst experience of my life. If I could type a novel about how horrible this place is, I would, but instead I'll write a 2 paragraph yelp review.

Their menu is very cryptic - on the wall is says "ask for prices". I should have known this meant "expensive".. .but how much could a bagel and egg be?

Went in here, not expecting to pay 9 dollars for a bagel and egg (8.77). 

The service was rude as well!

I feel raped.
author: Cal C.

description:
I used to go to David's years ago when I lived in Berkeley but Boyfriend worked in the city.  I remember having roast beef sandwiches and chicken soup that, while expensive as most other Jewish delis, didn't leave me feeling cheated and filled with rage.

Fast forward a few years.  My Dad is visiting me for the first time in my new big-girl apartment.  I'm having a hard time thinking of a mutually acceptable place to eat within walking distance, when I remember Davids.  We go there, only to be served the nastiest, shiestiest, overpricetiest corned beef sandwiches on Yahweh's green earth.  I was left angry and embarrassed that my dad should think that David's is how I spend my money.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I agree, Eek! MeThinks Not! 

Had breakfast here 5/27/2010 food was below average.  We wanted to sit at a table but we were directed to a very busy counter populated with bread crumbs and dirty dishes.  Asked if we could close the front door as is was cold/raining and we were sitting very close to the door.  Told no do not close the door???  
On a positive note I will say the coffee was very good.  
I would suggest do not eat here.  Dirty, slow  service, below average food, indifferent to the customers.
author: Peter C.

description:
Stopped in here to get some breakfast to go and I can't say I'll ever go back. The portions were TINY and everything is ridiculously overpriced. 10 bucks for a palm full of scrambled eggs and 3 strips of bacon is stupid. Also, the woman at the counter seemed irritated the whole time she was helping me and all I did was order. 

You're better off getting breakfast ANYWHERE ELSE in the city.
author: Mel P.

description: Walked into this place for breakfast. Should have yelped it first. We walked in and didn't even know what to do. We just stood in the front and realized there was a separate dining area besides the counter. Stood around for another 2-3 minutes and saw empty chairs at the counter. All in all like everyone else said, waitstaff friendly but having to wait for the food took over 20 minutes for a cheese omelet and corned beef hash. Food was okay, have had better. Should have gone to dennys or ihop and would have saved more money and time.
author: Angela D.

description:
Waddling home from Katana-Ya I passed by David's and immediately stopped short, backpedaled and went inside to buy one of the chocolate covered macaroons that scandalously propositioned me from the front window.  That naughty macaroon had a little trick in it's pants that I wasn't expecting.  It's base was actually a little cookie with chocolate whipped cream between it and the macaroon that was dipped in chocolate.  You little vixen!  I'm going to have to lick that cream sooooo good!  And then give you the eating you deserve!  Macaroon bukkake love!  
For $4.61 I expected you to last longer than THAT. 

*****

Okay so I'm REALLY missing my boyfriend and right now food and booze are the only things that I can find joy in.  So maybe my review is a little less than PG but whatevs.  That macaroon cookie sandwich is the only thing that's going to be creaming on MY face for a while.
And YES I realize I'm pathetic. AND horny.
author: Jill D.

description:
14.99 for 2 cups of coffee and 2 pastries?

I've given it an extra star for the delicious horseshoe pastry they have.

But the atitude of the host (or the person by the pastry counter) sucks. Smile and be nice to the other people. 

The price is ridiculously high. It is nice trying it but I don't think I'll be back again. 

The deli area is dirty. Their tomatoes looks like its about to rot. 

DO NOT BE DECEIVED BY THE DISPLAY WINDOW. 

Those pastries are not made by Hermes nor Louis Vuitton. Though in pastry standards they are priced like such minus the quality. (B+ for taste)
author: Ron T.

description:
I was in the city by myself and staying in a hotel nearby when I figured I'd bring a sandwich back to my room. The place was empty but I figured they were closing since it was about 4:30 in the afternoon. 

I had the warm pastrami and cheese sandwich on rye with pickle and potato salad. 

It really is a half pound of meat on the sandwich, with really nothing else. You couldn't taste the mustard with all of that meat and there was only one slice of cheese!   It also was very oily/greasy.

The potato salad was their 'specialty' sour cream potato salad. Ugh. It was not good. May have been bad but after those first initial tastes I didn't dive back in to figure out what was wrong with it. 

The saving grace was the pickle, nice and crisp. 

The total was about $15 for the sandwich, which I took To Go. I understand the concept of the Jewish and NY delis an the pricing, however this one did not live up to anything remotely warranting that price (unless it was the half of pound of pastrami). 

Nope, will not be back to this place the next time I'm in the city.
author: Debbie E.

description:
My friend and I waited nearly 30 mins for two pathetic, EGREGIOUSLY overpriced sandwiches. My corned beef was so dry it was hard in places, the pickle was limp. I was never asked for a refill. There were little gnats flying all around the place, and the bathroom was broken.

I told all this to the "manager" who said nothing but "thank you" while he rang up our $30 bill...up until I was walking out the door, when he said, "oh, by the way, you're right."

Oh...my...G*d. 

Calling David's Delicatessen a Jewish deli is an anti-Semitic slur.
author: Jason B.

description: Writing this review while sitting in the restaurant. We have now been here for 90 plus minutes. For breakfast. It's a toss up which is worse: service or food. The prices are fighting for 3rd on the "Simply Awful" list. Avoid at all costs.
author: Justin S.

description:
Big stupid me forgot to check out this place on yelp before we stumbled into the place. It looked totally new and legitimate on the outside, and of course ..... once we walked inside, like everyone else stated, the atmosphere was old, but not classy old, it was pretty much "we only had money to revamp the outside but had no money to simply clean up the interior" old .... and then the menu came ... me thinks STICKER SHOCK and also think the food better be good if they dare to charge so much .... (I mean I understand the location prolly be the way they charge so much but still that was a shock)

basically .... i didn't wanna mention about the food we ordered because regardless of what we ordered ..... it was terrible and that it was like they only hired food heaters in the kitchen but not chefs ..... everything didn't look and taste fresh and to charge this kind of price made me felt being robbed by this restaurant ..... the only upside to this was that this place should feel lucky that your ONE AND ONLY WAITER ON A SATURDAY was as perfect as he should be .... the cashier was grumpy to say the least ... like they don't want us to come in to eat or something like that ...... ARE YOU SURE ? An almost empty restaurant on a satruday should have told us better. 

David's ... you might have been good for the past 50 years ... but your not anywhere near ACCEPTABLE right now ..... feel lucky that you probably are the "designated" restaurant to the hotel or something like that ... that's how you survive i guess .... but pls ... don't bother operating a restaurant if you don't think about improving.

my GF was basically saying to me ...... "why don't you close your restaurant?" ... .grrrrr
author: David C.

description:
I think giving this place one star is generous.

1. Gross
2. Dirty
3  Creepy
4. Serves breakfast all day, but ran out of pancake batter...hmmm 
5. EXPENSIVE

Absolutely Horrible. Just thinking about this place makes me feel sick.
author: Jessica M.

description:
I was so excited to try a real Jewish deli, but sadly it missed the mark. I had a Ruben and at best it was reasonable, the meat while plentiful as was the sourcroute it was just not tasty. I was just disappointed, maybe I built it up in my mind too much but no where near in the same league as Dittmers. 

Also a word of warning, the spicy mustard is just that! Wow, nearly gave me a nose bleed and completely overpowered the otherwise rather bland sandwich!

2 Sandwiches and a couple of beers, over $50! Never mind the quality feel the width....
author: David G.

description:
"Zero" stars is too many.  I give this place MINUS 5 stars.  

Scary in so many ways.  There is nothing left to say.
author: Trisha T.

description:
I'm preaching to the choir when I say... holy fucking overpriced!!! As we strolled past on a nice day, the macaroons in the window caught my eye. I *almost* walked past, but no... I am a sucker for a well-made macaroon.  I ended up buying the macaroon and a marzipan "horseshoe". How much did I pay?? $9.22!! Good lard, that's a lot of money for two sweets. I saw the sign on the window saying prices were 55% lower than I would pay elsewhere-- are you KIDDING ME?! That means they believe macaroons cost  *$7.15* elsewhere!!! I'm not sure what kind of pixie dust these Jews are snorting, but keep it far, far away from me!!

Anyhow, the horseshoe was damn good and the lady was friendly but the restaurant looked creepy and the macaroon had some weeeeird chocolate frosting shit on the inside...?! 

So yeah, the marzipan horseshoe would be worth whatever ass-raping cost I paid for it maybe once a year, but I consider myself lucky having found it and won't be revisiting too often.
author: Jen S.

description: Worst dining experience I've had in years. Waited 40 minutes for order, waitress didn't even offer us a coffee refill. When the food came it was stone cold. Sent back twice, still cold. Not even an apology. Do yourself a favor, cross the street and go to pine crest diner. David's was TERRIBLE
author: Jeff G.

description:
I stumbled past David's from a Doctor's appointment and thought I had a perfect opportunity to get some home-made chicken soup to soothe my antibiotic-required strep throat and flu.

Being the nice girlfriend I am, I thought I would order a pastrami sandwich on rye with swiss cheese for my BF since I was there, as well as a small container of chopped liver (comfort food for the sick!). 

I got home and opened my $9.00(!!!) container of chicken soup to discover thin, watery broth, two chunks of cauliflower and one chunk of chicken. One taste of the flavorless broth and into the trash it went. 

Needing to eat *something*, I opened the chopped liver only to discover it was completely turned -- you can smell the smell of rotten food immediately and this definitely had that putrid, sharp aroma. 

Lastly, the BF opened his sandwich to discover that no only was there no cheese, but that the meat (while piled quite high), was mostly fat. 

How does this place stay in business?
author: Carolyn T.

description:
Food: I've only tried their deserts and they're usually pretty good.  I guess all the terrible reviews must be for their food. 

Price: The first slice of cake I got was $4, which is pretty standard.  A few days later I get the same size slice of another cake and it was $10!  She said that their prices vary by flavor!

Service: Always friendly and quick but nothing amazing.
author: Mack D.

description: Just ate here.  The lox sandwich was delicious, but the prices were outrageous! We were over charged for everything and the manager was entering random prices for the food.  We were charged and extra $2 for cream cheese on a lox bagel sandwich!!!!  Ridiculous!!!!  I'm never going back!  It deserves less then 1 star!
author: Chef S.

description: HORRIBLE!!!! Want to waste ure time in SF in a deli??? If u do come to this place. Bad service took an hour to get a omellette. I couldve made a faster one ! Seriously walk right past this place. Very rude staff!!!!
author: Smiley P.

description:
Don't even risk going in here.  Not even close to being a Jewish Deli.  Extremely over-priced and clearly a "tourist-trap".  Do not try any of the prepared salads (Tuna, Potato, etc.) they are terrible.

What are these people thinking?
author: Jerry G.

description:
The hubs and I stopped by here for a quick bite to eat before we were off to see a show at Curran.  Most of the places around the theatre were packed and we weren't going to make our show if we stopped at one of the other places.  

The hubs had the pastrami and I had the corn beef, both were decent but not worth the premium they were charging.  I believe both sandwiches were $14-$17 and the fries were not good at all.  

Will I be coming back, probably not.  I would rather go to Jack N Box on the corner.
author: Susie S.

description: Wow.  This review is based solely on the customer service due to the fact that we felt like the employees literally did not want us to eat there.  We walked in, no one helped us, they kept pointing us in different directions.  I've never ever had this happen to me before, these guys REALLY did not want us to eat at their restaurant.  We actually left laughing at how crazy that experience was....
author: Jacquelyn M.

description: decent food poor service. I think they had 1 server for the entire restaurant. lucky we didn't have a plane to catch.
author: Sam S.

description:
Looking for breakfast in Union Square, every place had lines except Davids. We went in, thinking you can't really ruin breakfast. 

Wrong. This was maybe the worst breakfast I ever had, despite a nice waitress. Cheese omelet with cheese that could probably never melt. Hash browns that were greasy, raw and burned at the same time. Untoasted toast. 


A no-eye-contact casher rang up the bill, 25 bucks for two. Avoid Davids Delicatessen, even if  you are extremely hungry.
author: Roger B.

description: While staying across the street at the Monaco -which I have an excellent review for, we ate here twice.  The first experience was ok...VERY slow impersonal service but it's breakfast and it was good.  Great coffee.  So we returned...and that's when bad service met bad food.  I was still happy with my scrabbled eggs and hash browns but my Mom ordered the blueberry pancakes and they came out undercooked and topped with nasty canned blueberry gunk.  The server never checked back.  This place is in a great location and could be making $$$$ and maybe they are.  But it's only on tourist. And with sites like Yelp, I don't know how much longer they can operate in this poor manner.  Either they are going to get "it" or lose it.   So, don't go in a hurry, and don't order the blueberry pancakes.  Or just don't go.  Cheers!
author: Lana S.

description: Ehh. So my coworker and I walk in and are looking at the pastries trying to decide what to get. And some lady who is seated at the counter eating keeps shouting "need something to go?"?? I thought she was a customer, she kept repeating it and finally came to help us. Spent too much on 2 pastries: a napoleon and a apple something or another. Huge turn off: she used her bare hands to package my food, didn't thank us. The napoleon wasn't good, dry and nasty, apple on is for the hubby. UGH maybe I should have checked the reviews beforehand.....should I take this pastry home to my husband or donate it to someone on the street?? Decisions..
author: Nicole B.

description:
I can't believe we paid $40 for breakfast.  When the cashier rang us up we both looked confused.

I ordered scrambled eggs with lox.  Not knowing that the lox was thrown in with the eggs.  I thought it was gonna be separate so I could make myself a little bagel sammie.  My meal didn't come with hash browns so I ordered a side of it.  There was barely enough for a bite.

My honey ordered a basic two egg breakfast w/ bacon.  They were out of this type of bread or that type of bread.  Why not just say, "We have wheat toast"  instead of asking, "what type of toast would you like?"  

I'm glad we weren't the only ones left walking out thinking WTF????!!!!
author: Jeanne L.

description: God-awful food and priced. Avoid at ALL COSTS!!!!!!
author: Andrew K.

description:
If I could give it zero, I could.

I love Jewish deli, but I'm realistic enough to understand it's never going to be Carnegie or Katz's (or Canter's, since Jewish deli just isn't an East Coast thing). But jeebus, Max's  isn't even really Jewish anymore and their pastrami looks like Carnegie's compared to David's. Heck, the pastrami you buy in Safeway looks like Carnegie's compared to David's.

And the worst part is it did used to be pretty decent. My folks are from the East Coast, and apparently 20 years ago it wasn't half bad. A shame.
author: Flynn H.

description:
Went in on a Saturday morning after celebrating my husband's birthday in SF... I ordered a rueben sandwich on rye, he ordered a bagel with lox and cream cheese.  pretty basic stuff right?  I go to pay at the cashier and she tells me $33.15 !  Really?  30 bucks for a bagel and a sandwich???
My husband and I just looked at each other and handed over the money... we thought maybe we were over charged, but Nope... we weren't.
The menu is on the wall, but the prices aren't... but really, it's a deli so I'm not usually worried about how much a sandwich is going to cost me.
It wasn't even good & they forgot my swiss cheese, even after I reminded the creeper who was making it.
They should consider remodeling a little bit too with all that $$ they're rolling in.
author: Madeline G.

description:
The staff was super friendly!  I forgot my jacket, and the waitress chased me down the street!

The food was honestly great!  I had the stuffed cabbage, which was DELICIOUS!  My co-worker had the Frankfurter, and he really enjoyed it.  

Yeah, the place has a throw back to the early days environment, but I think it lends to the experience.  I found myself wondering what the place used to look like.  

Oh, and they were a bit on the pricier side, but the portions we very well sized.  My stuffed cabbage was HUGE, and the potatoes and gravy took up 1/2 the plate!   So worth it!
author: Jason M.

description: This is place is great!  My hotel was on the same street so it was a convenient place to get good unfussy Jewish food. The corn beef sandwich rocks!  It's also a haven for Curran Theater goers.  I love the location, service, and interesting folks you meet.  I'll definately be returning!
author: Val B.

description: You don't have to be Jewish to enjoy this place, because as a Jew I didn't care for it. Service was so bad our waitress got canned during our lunch, patrons fought with the manager, and a simple order had to go back. The food wasn't horrific, but it wasn't great either. I won't return.
author: Josh R.

description:
only come here if you enjoy waiting 25 minutes for a $13.95 (plus tax!) bagel and lox. 

yeah.. didnt think so!
author: Lindsey F.

description: Don't eat here. Don't eat the potato salad or anything that can spoil. The place is dirty. The food marginal. It's not friendly. They shouldn't be allowed to advertise because the ad is quite good, and people from around the world come here expecting one thing and getting another. It is my ethnic group and you never find any local Jewish newspaper saying anything good about this place or even mentioning it. We all wish we could hide it and it would go away. It is an embarrassment.
author: Primo M.

description:
This is only a review for a take-out hot pastrami sandwich - and we had coupons so we didn't pay full price by a long shot.

So - it was late on a Sunday morning, the theater across the street was nice enough to let us park in their white zone.  We dash in, order, wait 10 minutes, grab bag, sprint  back to car, zip down Geary to a parking space while our tummies rumble now that the aroma of hot pastrami is filling our nostrils.  

Rye bread good, lettuce & tomato fresh, pastrami warm, garlicky & fatty enough to give proper flavor without being gross - and it's piled high just the way it should be!  I never got to the potato salad because the sammie filled me up.  

I do wonder where my crispy pickle went?  It sure wasn't packed along with the sammie!
author: Lxs S.

description:
"World Famous" is clearly their branding and not their actual reputation. My Shiksa mother makes better latkes and they don't cost anywhere near $12 a plate.

This place is misrepresenting everything I hold dear about Judaism. The food.
author: Rachel B.

description:
I was really pumped to try out a Jewish Deli in San Francisco.  I left never wanting to come back.  Both my meal and my lady friends meal sucked.  Her omlette was pooor and my pastrami sandwich was terrible.  AK Subs and Bay Cafe in Marina make way better sandos.  Also they did not give pickles like every other Jewish Deli in the country and when I asked for some they charged like 6 bucks or something for some medicore pickles.  The Waitress was rude and the food was terrible.  I am only giving it one star becasue when we got our check for overpriced food they gave us a sample cookie that was pretty good.  I wish SF had a Canters Deli like in LA.  Now that place is the bomb. 
 Let me know where to get a good Black and White cookies in the city.  If we cant look to the cookie where can we look?
author: Harry E.

description: Walking past... Hey the have a bakery.. Nah let's try that shit tomorrow.. Ok so we went in.. Ordered coffee and left,.  Yeah, not.. Went to olympic flame diner across from the adagio... Not a very good bfast morning...
author: Robert F.

description:
One star is too much.  The front room counter is nice and friendly (nice waiter), but the food we had was ABYSMAL - they deep-fried the latkes *and* the matzo brei!  Everything just tasted of cheap oil and was dripping with it.  Worst of all was when the bill arrived: the cost of 1 OJ + 1 tea + 1 matzo brei + 1 corned beef hash with a side of latkes was $49 before tip!
Just a tourist trap - DON'T GO THERE!
author: Susan B.

description:
To think this place put the best Jewish deli/restaurant out of business.

The Stagedoor Deli was truly authentic. Reminded me of Chicago deli's with the atmosphere, the poeple and the food.

David's in my opinion, stomped out the tradition of  SF theatre actors late night great knish or latke cravings. I'll never forgive them for takling those blintzes out of my life! they opened really small right next door, and eventually took over the space years after Stage door closed.

I'm really not that upset about it, but nothing can replace Stagedoor. I'll eat David's blintzes...but I won't forget!
author: Marz W.

description:
Lesson: Never go to a new restaurant while starving.  Always give yourself the choice to walk out and go somewhere else.

I went here with a Jewish friend who specifically wanted to try out one of the few mostly kosher restaurants in the city.

While I try to be accommodating of other peoples cultural and religious beliefs, I should have said no as soon as I opened the menu.  This place is not just overpriced, it has absolutely no connection to reality.

The simple surrealness of it and my willingness to try anything once led me to stay and order their $13 roast beef sandwich.  Their menu claimed all their sandwiches were "BIG!", so maybe they serve a whole cow on bread?  Instead, I received a mediocre sized sandwich and a ultra small serving of potato salad.  

I feel like I must now apologize to the community of Union Square for supporting such a lame excuse for a restaurant.  I have always before believed that there was always something special to be discovered in any restaurant in San Francisco.  And while, being the absolutely worst restaurant I've ever been to is certainly "special", it's not quite what I had in mind before.

I'm sorry Union Square community!  Please forgive my innocence!
author: Miller H.

description: Really really F#$%ing disgusting AND expensive.  Just thinking about this place makes me depressed.  I tipped the waiter out of pity.
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
If you look up GAWD AWFUL in the dictionary, there will be a map and a big picture of David's next to the entry for sure.

I have passed this place a gazillion times in the 9 years I've lived in the TenderNob and have drooled over the tasty-looking desserts in the window every time.  Now I know better.  Do not, under any circumstances, eat at David's...EVER!

Everything we tried on the menu, from the pastrami to the goulash was subpar and overpriced.  But the desserts were the worst.  My partner and I both have serious sweet teeth so we ordered 4 or 5 desserts to share.  Every single one was old, dry, gacky and generally tasteless.  Little Debbies would have been a step up.  This was especially disappointing due to the false advertising of the giant dessert window.

I could have eaten at House of Prime Rib for the $75 we paid for lunch at David's and would have gotten 3x as much food.  If David's was the last restaurant on earth I'd take up fasting.
author: Jon B.

description:
It takes a lot to piss me off.  I've been to a lot crap places in the city but this place takes the cake.  

I'm ok with cheap, crap food.
Expensive, crap food, makes me livid.

A friend asked me to pick her up a soup and sandwich at David's.  No worries.  

The place is dirty.  Not a good, down home dirty, a bad, I'm gonna shit my pants after I finish my sandwich dirty

I run in and order a pastrami sandwich and some barley soup.  The sandwich lady grunted to me that they never received the phone order.  No prices are on the wall so I place my order.  Sandwich lady, dressed like a broke ass FlyGirl, tosses me a wrinkled up crack bag with a scribbled piece of paper.

Somehow the cashier is able to read the paper.  I think it said, take this fool for all he's got.  $24.  Soup and sandwich.  To go.  I said "Excuse me, how much is this?".  $14 for the sandwich and $8 for the soup.

Damn, ripped off in my own city.  Not even a happy ending to show for it.
author: J L.

description:
Where else in the city can you get a nice kosher sandwich?  My favorite is their Hot Pastrami sandwich. Next time I go though, I'm going to try their Ruben. My friend had the Ruben and it looked yummy!  You can't leave Davids without trying one of their deserts. I had a hard time selecting a pastry (they all look so good) , so our server, who was very helpful, asked me about my taste and selected a pastry that she knew I was going to like. She hit the nail on the head, whatever it was she picked for me it was deeeelicious!

This deli may seem expensive, but don't forget everything is kosher! Kosher food is typically more expensive because you are paying for quality. 

David's Deli, I'll be back soon to try that Ruben!
author: H J.

description: I had the lox with eggs and onions and challah bread. I have to say, though a little pricier than I would have liked ($13), the place had a nice feel to it. I love that New York deli feel it has in San Francisco. I did oversee and hear what other people had to eat. The best story is this one small guy who came in and ordered not one, but TWO hot roast beef sandwich places. I mean, I sit down at the counter and he say, "WOW. That was soo good I think I'll order another. " The servers were a bit in shock and the other people looked impressed. It almost made me want to break the food wall and say, "I think I'll order what he's having". I didn't-because that's crazy-but I did enjoy the fresh cooked lox and felt like I'd like to go back and order a colossal sized sandwich next time.
author: Crystal V.

description:
They get a couple of stars for having a good black and white cookie, but docked because for one of those and a chocolate chip cookie, my bill was over $6.75!!!!! WTF???  I know prices are inflated around Union Square, but this was ridiculous.
My advice:
Ask about the prices on baked goods, then get out your credit card if you want to buy more than two items.
author: Suzanne L.

description: Over priced. HORRIBLE service. I feel like the blonde lady would rather stick a fork in her eye than serve another table. Did I mention OVERPRICED for not AMAZING quality food?
author: Pamela R.

description:
2 bad experiences 10 years apart.  Now we've learned.  Never again. The first time was very unusual--coming in with little kids after Chinese New Year's parade, after 9 PM, our waitress overwhelmed with crowd, many diners grumbling about poor service (actually one shouting), but basically OK once served.  We chalked it up to unusual circumstances, late in the evening, maybe a couple of waiters called in sick at the last minute, something like that.

Last night also unusual.  Christmas Day, late afternoon.   Very few places open.  (But those open near Union Square were really busy.)  Almost no one seated at tables in side room.  After 15 minutes, as we stood up to leave, waiter finally ready to take our order.  He politely, but meekly, told us food should be pretty quick.  We ordered, he brought tea and water.  Another 15-20 minutes after ordering, nothing else (including soup) had showed up.  We paid for tea and left.

Kind of freaky.  In the 30-35 minutes we were there, we saw one large family group get dessert for kids, but it appeared no one else at a table got anything and no one got hot food.  Was there even a real cook on site?  No sign of life when I glanced at the kitchen as we left.  The table next to us never had used dishes and tip picked up in the 35 minutes we were there.

The cashier was polite as we paid for our tea and complained quietly.  She had earlier said 'sit anywhere you'd like.'  
If there was something weird going on, like no cook on site,  or they really didn't want to serve us, why didn't they let us know?
author: Frank M.

description: This was the worst place we ate on our vacation! One night we walked by and the desserts looked amazing so we thought would be good for breakfast. My husband and I didn't even finish our breakfast. $5 for a glass of orange juice and it wasn't fresh squeezed. Ordered the swiss and mushroom omelet and the mushrooms were canned not fresh and the cheese had to be a cheap swiss for how greasy it was. Wish I would of read the reviews but it was not worth a $30 breakfast. Just gross!
author: Rosie M.

description: Horrible. Slow service. High prices. Average food at best.
author: Doug K.

description: My husband and went to David's this morning (9 a. m.) for breakfast.  Food was OK, but the food delivery was very slow, and since there weren't many customers in the place at that time, i am  not sure if there was a problem in the kitchen or if this was typical.  And they leave their front door open and in the early morning hours in SF, it's cold!  It was also hard to get the wait staff's attention to get our check..I would not return to this place!
author: Maureen H.

description:
The service was poor. The only good thing was the poor guy who was only in charge of getting people their drinks before the hopelessly slow and depressed waitress came and took your order (we were sitting at the counter...seemed a safer bet than one of those side rooms/caves off in the back corner).

A glass of apple juice was $3.95. Yes. Three dollars and ninety-five cents. As in, I could have walked down the street to Walgreen's and bought enough apple juice to last me a week for the same amount. Also, a little sketchy that the drinks aren't listed on the menu.

There was nothing twisted about the "Egg Twist French Toast" (egg twist bread = Challah bread? since when?). But, if you put enough butter and syrup on just about anything, it'll taste good.
author: s m c.

description: I went here a couple of months ago just to get one of the baked goods I'd seen in the window.  It was a slice of chocolate torte, which was pretty good.  However, the price was high and the credit card machine was broken (which, reading Yelp write-ups, seems to be the case more often than not).  The outside of the building & window displays are their real strengths: pretty sure this is how they get most of their customers.  I'm looking for a nice place to sit, study & have a coffee and had been considering David's.  After reading the MANY terrible reviews I will give them a pass.  Starbucks is meh, but they are reliable.
author: Margret C.

description:
Yeuuuuuuk - avoid at all costs. Surly waiter, crap food (my friend's meatloaf was flavorless and lukewarm, the gravy was clearly out of some packet and his veg were soggy defrosted crap. My egg and onion sandwich was, I guess, an egg and onion sandwich - two pieces of bread with a fried egg and a one inch thick slice of raw red onion. Gross, and heartburn for the rest of the day), way over-priced, dirty, dingy - yeuk. At least I wasn't the lady in front of me paying at the cash register who was being charged 6.95 for a slice of tomato she had asked for on her sandwich.

Avoid at all costs. If you need to eat hearty and cheap nearby try King of Thai noodles on the same block. Cheap, hearty and delicious (though probably not the most exciting atmosphere in the city).
author: emily c.

description:
Amazingly overpriced.

A reuben sandwich for $18.95?

The food isn't even that great.

I mean, I had a cinnamon roll for $4, and it was a good cinnamon roll, but not for that price!
author: Al Y.

description: Wished I'd checked the Yelp reviews before eating here. I am a big fan of Jewish deli's. The food here was overpriced and stale, like it had been sitting under a heat lamp for a week. The staff couldn't have cared less.
author: Dolce S.

description: Slow service, mediocre food, and too expensive.
author: Keith L.

description: Stay away.  The food and service is sub par. Speaking of breakfast, toast and eggs and hash browns were cold, coffee was bitter, no cream or half and half, canned juices. Server overtaxed. Management is indifferent to complaint.
author: Alex G.

description: Having lived near by for over a decade, i can say that this is where i come to get my desserts! my favorite is the apple strudel, while sometimes too sweet for others, the real apples inside gives it a tartness that balances everything out, not to mention its layered golden crust. yummy. A bonus is that its all fresh made right upstairs in their bakery. Yea the woman behind the counter is a little on the quiet side, but she was very helpful on which desserts were good. The apple strudels here are like no other in the city I've tasted or anywhere else!
author: Mindy X.

description:
The hot pastrami sandwich is very good as is the hot spicey mustard. The pickel was not a Valsek and crunchy so I let it be. The potatoe salad was average.

I would have done 3 stars but the price couldn't be justified for what was delivered.
author: Chad N.

description: Oh horrible. I'm amazed this place is still in business. Depressing interior, surly staff, terrible food, really terrible, and really, really overpriced. I think it must have the lowest rating of any restaurant on Yelp, and they deserve it. Yuck.
author: susannah b.

description:
I'm reviewing this place based on the marzipan cake and coffee I had there last night.  The marzipan was layered thinly under the pretty chocolate deco on this triangular treat.  My friend and I shared a piece, and it was plenty for two.  We also shared a $3 cup of coffee, which to its credit was mellow and nice for desserts.

Service was also nice, so for around $13 we had a nice dessert experience.  Wish they weren't so expensive so we could've tried one each.
author: senna c.

description:
The sandwich, while okay (just "okay", not great) was NOT that big, and for the better part of a $20 for said sandwich and an iced tea (which tasted weird, and cost like $3 itself) I'd really expected to get something better (and more generous) than what I did. Coleslaw was okay. But WTF? I'm paying $14 for hot pastrami of middling quality on store bought rye and you can't throw in a freakin' pickle?

Guy behind the counter was moving in slow motion, no one seemed to know how to take orders, decor was just plain dated, not nostalgic, and many of the patrons looked like they had passed away, been sealed in wax, and propped up on their sticky stools at the lunch counter so as to give that illusion of "old school authenticity" that all the hipster kids are on the hunt for these days.

Still... $20 is a pittance for a 15 minute ride in a time machine back to 1953. It is, however, still too much for a sandwich from this place.
author: Ian K.

description: This is one of the worst places I have ever ate. Not only was the service bad, but the food was awful and cold. I guess you need to be stranded on a deserted island for a month with no food before u try this place.
author: Tracy H.

description:
The David's bashers don't know from real deli.

Not only can you get home spun favorites at Davids (like the brisket, very bubbe-esque), but you can also get a real thick deli sandwich, with pickle, made out of kosher meat, right in Union Square. 

HELLO? You can't make a kosher pastry with dairy, bacon brain!

Skip dessert (unless its the hamentaschen, shortbread triangle cookie with fruit inside, available in the early spring) and go for a phat turkey on rye with hot mustard. 

We had our wedding weekend sabbath dinner in their shabby side room: everyone felt at home. 

And the menu? Written by a hilarious genius!

David's gets 4 stars only because the physical building needs a serious upgrade. The food, on the other hand, is tops.
author: Shira L.

description:
4.21.2007
3:00PM

Ever been to The Carnegie Deli in NYC?  Awesome.

I wanted this place to be good...even mediocre would have me coming back...unfortunately, this place is a total rip and I'm not coming back.  

I ordered the pastrami sandwich and a side of sauerkraut.

The Sandwich was OK for $11....fatty...but good....served on a Kaiser Roll...hmm....no rye....

Their deli mustard sucked; it was watery,sweet, and wasn't spicy at all.

The small plate of pickled cabbage cost an additional $5.  

Fah-Q David.  

This place is depressing as hell...
author: William R.

description:
To be fair, I didn't have a very bad experience with food at David's. Their Lox is excellent and fresh, I like their Blintzes, and the pastrami, while not the best in town, is pretty tasty. I like their Napoleon cake and other sweets. At one point I bought Lox and other meats in bulk. 

My issue with this place is that it IS DIRTY and lacking atmosphere, while charging white tablecloth restaurant prices. It's hard to get out of there without paying $20+ for a meal (even their breakfast is ludicrously expensive). If I am going to pay that much for a meal, the service, decor, and atmosphere needs to be up to standard.

You don't get much service there because none of the servers are ever around and the public that dines there is unpleasant and rude. 

 The place is always full of judgmental middle-aged Midwesterners who stare at me with unmasked disdain because I am dressed well and obviously biracial. I am half Russian and half African, so I'm used to being a bit out of place in ethnically Jewish/Russian stores and restaurants, but this place just has a bad vibe. 

During my last visit a tourist family with three tired kids was so noisy  that a few patrons stood up and walked out. They kids were obviously tired and screamed non-stop to the point where you couldn't hear yourself think.  I sat there thinking, I PAID MONEY FOR THIS? I haven't been back since. 

For their kind of prices I can get a delicious fresh meal anywhere in the city and there are better places to buy Russian/Jewish Deli products as well.
author: Sophia G.

description: Stopped in tonight to get a sick friend some matzo ball soup...I really hope it is good for $11 a bowl.
author: Lena H.

description: Waaay too overpriced for what you get!!! We came to visit SF and have been perfectly fine with all the restaurants we've been and paying their price but at least we got a good quality meal. This place is very dirty also and looks like they've neglected basic cleaning. Also the staff are not friendly and very slow. This was my first and last visit here. I should have looked on yelp first before coming to this restaurant. If your looking for a good breakfast, I would spend good money elsewhere.
author: Mars D.

description: I wouldn't expect anything fancy but they are consistent and courteous.  Great Matzo Ball Soup, Lox Bagel, Reuben Sandwich.
author: Kattya B.

description:
Well Dear Yelpers--I did not check reviews before we ventured forth and lo and behold we did not have a good experience.   When will I learn.   But the pastries in the window were so deceiving. The service was slow and lacking.  The coffee was cold and burnt.  The food was over priced,  flavorless and presentation was awful.  You could see in other patrons faces the lost look of trying to decide to walk out or not.

Bottom LIne not worth the energy or price....starbucks is better.

papayala
author: carlos a.

description: Potato pancakes from the box are so much better than David's, the 'fresh squeezed' orange juice was Minute Maid concentrate, and the Black & White cookies are overpriced and dinky. This place is one to avoid.
author: Peter M.

description: breakfast #fail... This is a trap.
author: Jonathan R.

description: Just kidding: this place is bad as it gets. I thinks most of the food is made out of the rain banner outside the windows. Did not get sick, but scarred of throwing up all night.
author: J B.

description: Not sure what the draw is, but it is expensive and not that great.  Orders of latkes and a pastrami sandwich was over $26.  Drank water.  Seemed like only one waiter for the whole place so service was very slow.
author: Magic M.

description:
Their motto is something like, "Our idea of great Jewish food." Yup...if you were raised in Antarctica by penguins. Otherwise, not so much.

I stopped in recently and ordered a corned beef sandwich on challah. The sandwich arrived relatively soon thereafter, having been so enthusiastically microwaved that my glasses fogged up. The bread was not only stale, it was barely big enough for me to pick up the sandwich, and it was mostly crust. What was supposed to be a nice crunchy pickle was four mushy slices that tasted like the jar had been left open since the Bush administration. 

I'll skip past the absent waiter and the incompetent cashier, and head for the bathroom. Now, even if the food had been magnificent, I wouldn't have ever come back, since it's my policy not to return to places with bathrooms that are wheelchair inaccessible. And David's actually set a new standard for accessibility problems. The bathrooms are up a flight of several stairs, and the ladies' room is a tight maneuver. But the clincher is that they have NO TOILET ROLL HOLDERS. Not just absent holders, but no holes indicating that there have ever been holders. The toilet paper is kept on a shelf about 6 feet high. If I were just a wee bit shorter, I never would have reached it. I'm hoping that my inflated bill will let them cover that last little bit of cash they need for such an expensive and exotic item. 

Bleech.
author: J V.

description: This place has been around for a long time and, as I recall, used to be very good. We had a Sunday brunch there recently and it was quite mediocre. We were really disappointed. The place looks dingy, really awful. The food was all right, nothing special, and the prices were high. Service was so-so. I'd recommend walking down to Max's, instead.
author: Joanna S.

description: made the mistake of not yelping. Went in, paid almost 4 bucks for a cookie that tasted like CRAP, the chocolatechips tasted weird and the flour was too, it destroyed my craving but i still woundn't go back. The lady that helped me out was nice which is WHY i wouldnt mind giving it one star. SAVE your money GO BUY COOKIES AT THE SUBWAY NEAR BY!
author: stanq b.

description: One afternoon before we go to the theatre we will be able to passed to this jewish delicatessen. As we entered to the restaurant the male waiter was so friendly and i have had notice that he was the only server working aside from the chef maybe. I'm impressed to their authentic counter it was kinda old but so unique!! When it comes to food it was good but the priced are way too expenssive compared to other DeLi ,but who cares we had a good and tasty food anyways!! Plus the non-stop pouring of coffee in our cups that was very awesome!! The waiter was checking us time to time if we're ok or if we need anythingelse.  Thumbs up to you!! :-)  I will recommend this place for you guys to eat and try their foods!! We will definitely visit this place once again!!
author: Franz H.

description: Cold bacon, bad jazz music, servers that stand over your table as you're paying the bill. Not sure how this place survives in San Fran.  Should have been clued in when the place was mostly empty on Labor Day morning.  Food is pricey considering how bad it was.
author: Jason R.

description:
We went here for breakfast since we were staying right next door at The Warwick. 
I'm pretty sure this place would be great for lunch, but breakfast was awful. The coffee was like motor oil, hash browns were stale, our toast wasn't toasted... it goes on. There was only one waitress and she was clearly in over her head.
I'm not saying don't go there, just don't go for breakfast.
author: Amanda M.

description:
Out of everything I wanted. Cold schav. Cream white concord. Meat blintzes. Refused to do the 'split bottle' of wine from the menu. Finally ordered the latkes. 
My bf got the meatloaf dinner. I tried his and wasn't impressed.slightly greasy but texture was ok. Potatoes were marginal, and it was basic nrown gravy. The veggies are frozen mix of peas carrots and freezerburned green beans. I tried mine I barely choked down one greasy, bland bite. How old are these latkes?? From the war?!? I would never go back here. The service is polite, but useless. 
The waiter noticed that I had pushed the latkes to the side, and took them back to the kitchen, and took it off the bill too.
The bakery case looks tempting, but not willing to risk it. 
Skip this place for eating, but stop by to look at the interior. Very cool lunch counter setup makes me so sad the food is so bad. This place needs new ownership/management/recipes.
author: Char Z.

description: We stumbled in here because it was late morning and we needed breakfast and coffee. All I will say about the place is...GROSS!  I'm just thankful we didn't get sick.
author: Mark G.

description: No senior citizens or walking impaired need come in- the bathroom is UP a steep staircase. Getting my 86 yr old dad up and down was scary when he HAD to go. And - NO KNISHES!!! Vas is das, dahlink, NO KNISHES? And they were out of matzoh balls for the soup. And the fryer was down the day we came. So many items on the menu.. but so many are fried (even the "baked chicken" leg). The meal was almost a huge flop... until we got the Huge pistrami sandwiches. We all took 1/2 a sandwich home, the sandwiches, and the super nice great waitress gets it 2 stars instead of 1. The waitress was really sweet. So not a complete disaster, but not what we wanted (to give my NY Jewish dad some old-style cooking, and a Chinese friend an intro to NYJewish food.) Go to Saul's in Berkeley instead.
author: Ira H.

description: Not too good, and for the last reviewer, since when is any rueben sandwich considered kosher? David's is by no means Kosher
author: robby m.

description:
OMG this was the most expensive, rude place.  I blew it and did not read the reviews before going.  Wanted to call 911 for being robbed.  Will make sure i read next time before going anywhere.  We thought we would try some of their desserts and it came to $56 for 6 tiny desserts.
WOW what a rip off.
author: Patrick Z.

description: I'm always hoping to find a Jewish (or Jewish-style) deli in CA that comes somewhat close to those in NY.  In SF, so far Moishe's Pippic comes the closest (even though they are "Chicago style").  I tried David's for lunch because we were going to a show nearby.  The corned beef sandwich: meat okay in quality and quantity (you can get extra lean for an additional dollar); rye bread rather a small piece, and tasted a tad dry.  Cole slaw okay, if somewhat limp.  But a bottle of cream soda for $4?  No way!  Dessert offerings seemed the classic variety, but I didn't try any.  On the whole, a tad pricey for what you get.  My friend's bagel didn't look that authentic. The decor is straight out of the 1950's, which I guess is part of its charm - a taste of an older San Francisco.
author: Judi G.

description: I walked by this place last night and saw that they had borscht! So I went back today for lunch. The sweet and sour cabbage borscht was delicious and so was the reuben sandwich. The waitress suggested I order 1/2 a sandwich unless I was really hungry, I didn't see that option on the menu. The soup and 1/2 sandwich was just the right amount. Helpful waitress, good food, reasonable prices for the neighborhood.
author: Sue A.

description: I work across the street, and we all want it to be good so bad. To no avail. Le sigh.
author: Ron A.

description: I walked by this place and saw their "looking-good" pastries, decided to drop by after lunch to get some dessert. The lady who worked there is beyond awful, she might be having a really bad day. She obviously had no intention to serve us, after sitting down for a minute, we decided to have some cakes to-go instead, but her attitude was so bad we just wanted to get out of there. Randomly chose a slice and ran away. We did not eat in and we only bought one cake not because we have no money, the service just turned me off. I felt bad for writing such a bad review.
author: Marlis T.

description: Reminded me of Katz's in New York, with less people and less atmosphere.  But, I had a giant turkey sandwich that was good -- huge slabs of turkey, mustard, and that's about it.  Counter service was good too.
author: DH H.

description: I had a very fatty reuben here and it was huge.  But when it's not good, huge is not good either.  I love deli sandwiches, but David's is not the place for a great meal.  New York style deli's are hard to come by in San Francisco.
author: Honey L.

description: Food was very poor. Some of the worst quality breakfast food I've had. And all I had was pretty much the go-to standard. Eggs, bacon, and hash browns. Somehow they were able to make it pretty unsavory.
author: Peter C.

description: I love the strange atmosphere here - it's too bad you can't eat here without feeling ripped off. When this place makes chicken broth, they must get about 20 gallons from one chicken (carcass). NOT rich. I had a bowl of matzo ball soup (one matzo ball floating in aforementioned "broth," a hamentaschen cookie and a cup of coffee. $20
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
SHORT: Below average food, depressing ambiance, high prices

~$20 for a gigantic but truly horrible Reuben sandwich. 
Depressing, dirty and somewhat smelly seating area. 
Pickles are horrible at best. How can you call yourself a Jewish deli if you don't master the pickle? Very very disappointing!
Macaroons are some of the worst I have ever tasted.
author: tuncay c.

description: As I walked out of David's today (my second visit), I felt as though I had just been physically violated. Mainly, my wallet is what was really violated. I have never felt worse about paying $30 for lunch in my life. The food here is average at best. I grew up eating deli...this ain't it. $16.95 for corned beef hash, it better be good...or at least average. Its not. The service was slow. The bread served with the meal was day old rye, and a god damn Dr. Brown's soda is $3.50. Save your money and go to East Coast West. The cabbage soup was fine, but you can do better at Max's (if that tells you anything). The worst part of it all is that atop my $16.95 corned beef hash were poached eggs that were not runny, which makes them not a poached egg at all. This place blows.
author: Adam F.

description:
The worst Black and White Cookie EVER!!
Even worse due to their chutzpah of charging over $3 for it!!!

The cookie was so bad, 
I created an account on Yelp just to let all you Black and White Cookie lovers be warned.
author: Casey D.

description:
K, I've only had ONE meal from this place but that's quite enough.
I wanted a quick sandwich on my way to a job and, well, its' a deli right?
I go in & the place is big & empty - shoulda left there & then. 
I waited around... behind the counter there were a couple of open salady things looking rather sad... I suddenly noticed there was a little lady behind the door because she made a noise. I waited some more. Eventually a guy came out from the back and asked me what I wanted. I said a cheese & egg salad sandwich. 5 minutes had already passed.
When I finally got a sandwich it was wrapped in lots of paper & weighed about half a pound. The bill came to $15!
Apparently Davids makes really BIG sandwiches, only they don't tell you this before you order and so I ended up with a huge (really huge) rather tasteless pile of egg,cheese & mayo with 2 slices of bread trying to contain some of it. It was unhandleable and mostly inedible.
thumbs down!
author: Peter C.
