description: My wife and I liked the dingy, '50s atmosphere at first, but the food was just so-so, and WAY overpriced. $30 for a couple eggs and toast, bagel w/ lox and two coffees. It was edible, but think high school cafeteria. How does this place stay in business? Probably from stupid tourists like us. STAY AWAY.
author: M W.

description: Worst meal I've had in a long time! At noon, they were out of their lunch special of the day and most other things we tried to order. Finally settled on matzoh ball soup and tuna sandwich. The soup was not soup at all, but the water they boiled the matzoh balls in! Unbelievable! No taste whatsoever and matzoh balls tasteless, too. Coffee stale.  Day old challah. And the waitress never asked how the meal was! Maybe it's bec she already knew! I will never go there again. Never! And u shouldn't either.
author: Lori M.

description:
I can't speak for much else other than the pastrami is excellent here and the potato pancakes are very good. That's all I ever order here.

 I have had pastrami in New York at Carnagies and had it shipped overnight from Katz's. I also tried the Millers East West Coast Deli a few blocks away after reading the rave reviews here last weekend. Disappointing pastrami and rye @ Millers. Decent but I would call it a 'vanllia' pastrami and rye. Nothing stands out about it.

Kat'zs pastrami was excellent except the lousy rye bread loaf they shipped can't compare to what I can get at some local stores.

 I immediately went to Davids after getting the Millers pastrami and compared them head to head. Millers use Boars Head Brand meats, which is not my favorite. The meat had more spice and less fat, it was dry. David's uses Sinai -Kosher brand and it's more fatty but juicy and so tasty and spiced just right for me and the rye has a nice crust. This pastrami and rye has personality!!!

I have been going here off and on for 23 years and it's always been the same. Service has been decent but if you go in 3-4 people you might not get your food all at once. I recommend a pastrami to go. In my opinion, Katz's really isn't a better pastrami...at least not much better enough to have it shipped out here. I'm happy with this and so far I am not impressed with people's tastes on Yelp regarding pastrami and rye.

And for all the east coast transplants complaining about the food here, order it online and get it shipped.and stop whining. The 'grass is always greener' atittude doesn't fly........but online orders from Katz's and Zabars in New York do.
author: gary c.

description:
Wish I could do zero stars.

About ten years ago I went to David's on a fairly regular basis when I spent much of my time in San Franciso.  It was expensive but very, very good.  It was those fond memories that clouded my judgement today.

My wife and I went into David's at noon on Saturday.  We should have been concerned when we noticed the place was only about 10% full.  When I ordered the lunch special that comes with a 'Schooner of Spaten,' they had no draft beer.  But they have wine?  Then I asked for potato salad instead of cole slaw.  They had no potato salad?  Ok, cole slaw then.

At last the food comes.  The rye bread was day-old and falling apart.  The pastrami was dry and minimal.  Then there was the chopped chicken liver sandwich my wife ordered.  That was the deal breaker.  I don't know what was worse, the appearance of the sandwich or the expression on my wife's face.  "No way am I going to eat that."

Now the dilema.  Do we dare return the chopped chicken liver to the kitchen and play a round of food poisoning roulet.  Do we dash?  (because there was no dine)  Instead we paid the check and left our food untouched.  This was an awful, ugly, gross, bad, $34 experience.
author: Derrick W.

description: I think I had about 5 different cookies from here and they all tasted like shitty-ass macaroons. My parents had some non-cookie items, and gave them a resounding EHHH. I feel like I should mention that I sort of trust the people who fed me for the first 18 years of my life.. especially in the sandwich department. Coconut, Yeesh.
author: katharine s.

description: Crappy in every way possible. Yelped while waiting 45 minutes for a simple egg order. Saw what other people were being served. Walked out.
author: Roberto M.

description: Is it possible to give negative stars? Ok, hands down, this is the WORST breakfast place EVER.  I've had comparable breakfasts at Denny's at 4 am, but at least then I knew what I was getting myself into, and I paid a fraction of the cost. All around terrible experience; the food, the service, and the insanely high prices. Not sure how this place is able to survive.
author: Janelle M.

description: I came with girlfriends after shopping in Union Square.  Unfortunately, they had bad reuben sandwiches, but I didn't.  I had the corned beef and it was ok.  It was the prices that made me not want to come back.  It's way too expensive.  For the three of us it was over $35.
author: Jin W.

description: Used to go here with my parents as a kid, and sadly, they have not updated it since.  Had brunch there recently and service was great but food was meh.
author: A B.

description: This is not a delicatessen. I don't know what it is. Sure you can get a sandwich but not chips - they don't stock any chips :-) Seriously, a delicatessen without chips......but I digress and this is just one of many reasons why I give it one star. I have a feeling that current ownership bought the place without really understanding what a "delicatessen" means. They did have some yummy looking pastries in the window that I may try someday - but that's it.
author: M D.

description: This is when Yelp needs to let us put a ZERO stars for a place! YES this place was beyond horrible food wise. The people working there were nice but the food was HORRIBLE!!! I had the potato latkes, how can you go wrong with that right? Uhh they were tastless mashed potato patties, not latkes! My friend had the Matza Ball Soup, it literally tasted like bolied water! I was ready to spit it out of my mouth! I was ready to not pay and leave if the waiter was not so weirdly calm and seemed nice.
author: Karen T.

description: I agree with negative reviews by Gourmet Guru and others -- this venerable place may have been okay once but has had a long slide downhill as far as food, facilities, ambiance.
author: Gil S.

description: I'm a big fan of Jewish delis but I have to say this place is over priced, could use a good cleaning and employees who can actually muster some energy and smile. I had the lox and bagel and a small tomato juice and the tab came to $20+. This was my first visit as I just happened to stumble on it while walking but I know I can find better for the money. I did leave a tip but sort of didn't want to because the counter waitress, while not nasty, was very mechanical and certainly not welcoming.
author: mark z.

description:
David's Deli had good food.  Every time I have gone there, it has been a solidly good experience.  They have an old-diner U-shaped style counter.  The service is relatively quick.  It is across from ACT and the Curran, which makes it a great stop for pre- or post-theater knoshing.  My favorite is their pastrami sandwich.  My friend had a ruben.   We had to order half because the portion was huge.  Their menu has a host of diner/comfort food that makes the choice hard.  You should see the desserts in their display window!  I saw a fruit salad float by in the arms of the waitress- you get a good value for the money.  It is not cheap, but it is very fairly priced.  Also, they are nice.  I asked for a pastrami sandwich to go to put together later, the guy gave me extra rye bread and packed it well.  It was my first time there.  If you want a table, there are tables in the back.  The dining room to the side is not always open.  It is clean.  Free refills on the coffee, which is good.
     My friends that come with me didn't like the way it looked when we walked from Mason up to the door.  Once we we were served, their tone changed.  They loved their food.  They liked our waitress.  They liked the coffee.  If we go to the theater together, they request that we go to David's for lunch or for a dessert after.  You should see the pastries! They have a menu that can accommodate all kinds of diets.
author: Chris E.

description:
While walking down the street I saw Coconut Macaroons dipped in chocolate in the window and went in for one. I asked for one chocolate dipped Macaroon and the response was it's 4.50 do you still want it? I asked for it didn't I? Do i look poor? so I paid with a 100 dollar bill. 
I got weak in the knees and I had to sit down the Macaroon was so heavenly. 
Great Macaroon 4stars
author: jake b.

description:
way way way overpriced.  i know nobody has said that yet but why on earth do they charge so much.  to bad i live close.

i'm a jeresy jewish girl high standards and go figure, cheap.

the food wasn't unedible but i've had a thousand times better at my grandmas...for free
author: kiki b.

description:
In all aspects of my life I keep learning the same lesson. Well, maybe "learning" is the wrong word. "Learning" impilies that you are adapting your behaviour from past experiences. I still keep making the same blunder over and over. I keep refusing to accept my first inclination and I question myself and take another path leading to disaster.

  So is my experience with David's. I had every intention of going into Katana-Ya for a bowl of one of life's great foods: fresh ramen. The sun was shining, it was warm, verging on hot and for some reason the thought of a piping hot soup and the sweaty college students crammed in there was turning me off... and I walked past David's. As much as I love ramen, love a good Jewish deli... and I haven't been to one in YEARS... Still haven't.

  People kvetch that this place still looks like a 1960s, pleather and formica ensconced lunch counter. True, and to me that reminds me of being a kid in SF and it also reminds me of Zim's (RIP *sniff*), so as far as I'm concerned I'm so down with the decor. What I'm not down with is the crap food, the ridiculous prices and the apathetic-cum-hostile service.

  I had a pastrami on rye with swiss, a bowl of pea soup and an iced tea for $25. The iced tea was like making love in a canoe, it took 15 minutes for me (the only patron) to get a small bowl of watery, flavorless pea soup (with not even a single packet of saltines), the potato salad was room temp and completely flavorless (small pieces of potato coated with some dry, tacky sour-cream residue and nothing else), the rye bread was freakin' stale, the cheese wasn't melted and the pastrami was strangely dry and lean while dripping with grill grease. Oh yeah, and I expect a good brown mustard at a freakin' deli fer cryin' out loud. They have the yellow stuff and a "hot" honey mustard out. I asked the waitress if they had any brown mustard. She pointed at the honey mustard and said "yeah - that's brown mustard." I asked her if that was the only mustard they offered and she got irritated and said that was it and stabbed her finger at the honey mustard and through clenched teeth said "BROWN. MUSTARD." Riiiiiggghhht. It *is* a brownish color, I can't argue with that! Sheesh.
 
  Is there such a thing as a good Jewish deli any more? Have the chain grocery stores and Subway's and Quizno's put them all out of business? I really wanted to like this place, but damn, I'll never set foot in there again. That's what I get for not trusting my first instinct. Maybe some day I'll actually learn.
author: Thomas S.

description: $20 for a cream cheese and lox bagel and a can of diet coke.  Nothing justifies this extreme cost.  Go to Kat's bagels  or the House of bagels if you really crave such a thing.
author: Food F.

description: I've walked past this joint a million times and never walked in...and this weekend, I thought, "Eh, it's raining, I feel like a nice heaping bowl of matzo ball soup."  Well, it teaches me to go anyplace without checking YELP first!!!  Damn, this place SUCKED!!!  Giving this place one star is a major overstatement, that's how bad it was.  Not only was the soup inedible (the broth tasted like water straight from the tap in HELL), the prices were laughable.  My friend got a side order of cucumbers with sour cream (literally!) and was charged $10.25, initially, and when we brought it to their attention, they changed it to $6.25.  What I want to know is, where were these cucumbers from??  England?  Straight from Her Majesty's garden?  All in all, the lesson here is: CHECK YELP before you go anywhere new...period, end of story.
author: Pilar P.

description: I went here despite the awful reviews because I've been craving a black and white cookie and this place is around the corner from my work. I noticed in the window that one tray of the chocolate covered treats were sweating and had been refrigerated. That probably should have been a sign but I was already there at that point. I got two cookies and the woman warned me that they were more than 3 dollars each since no pricing was posted anywhere. I thought that was nice of her. She was nice enough. I wonder if she is the same woman all the other people dealt with.  I took a bite of one and sure enough it was cold and tasted of industrial refrigerator. Awesome. Now that the cookies are room temp they taste much better but are overcooked. They taste almost burnt and are dry. The cookies in the NY deli at Atlantis in Reno are way WAY better. This is better than no cookie but not by much.  For almost 4 dollars each I expected more.
author: Kristyn K.

description: I've had mostly good experiences at David's. Killer Hot Corned Beef sandwich & killer Hot Pastrami.
author: Walter W.

description: Wow, these reviews really astonish me.  I've eaten here twice and had two very good, very massive Pastrami sandwiches.  For lunch today I ate at Katz's Deli in NYC, so I have some idea of what a good Pastrami sandwich tastes like.  I even like that it's all old and run down--when you walk in it's like stepping back into the depression-era 30s.  Yes, it's overpriced, which is a good thing because it keeps me from eating artery-clogging sandwiches everyday.
author: Nobody M.

description:
We ate here once before, a number of years ago, so while we knew it was overpriced and kind of dumpy, nothing prepared us for the incredibly poor service.  On the up side, the food - when we received almost 90 minutes after sitting down - was good.  There was one waiter, seemingly for the whole place, and one busboy.  We were asked if we wanted coffee and/or water when we sat down, but 1/2 hour later, nothing had come and no one took our order.

That should have been our first clue.

While we sat and waited (the waiter said there was no cashier and that he was having to fill in) we saw at least 10 groups come in, sit down and mess around with the paper place mats and silverware, and then get up and leave.  The busboy would then come and change the paper place mats and silverware, and the next unsuspecting group would come in and sit down.

At one point a woman at a neighboring table got up and began serving coffee and water herself!  And then, she began going to the kitchen and getting the food and bringing it out!

Our food was good, but not worth the wait.  We won't be back unless we read better reviews.  Forget about it!
author: Judy M.

description:
Why aren't there any good Delis in San Francisco?
i've been missing great NY delis since i left.
i was really excited to try David's Deli on geary street ... 
i was always a little funny about it because  everytime i walked past it was empty. 
But i decided to give it a go!

when i walked it was super cute - oldschool Jewish Deli - i walked over to the counter and was helped by... an old Asian man? that was my first sign of strangeness - but he was actually incredibly helpful and sweet. So i ordered: a bagel with lox and cream cheese.
Yup - super basic. Toasted on a poppy seed bagel. 
i waited while he made it - about 5 minutes.
It was huge - and looked delicious. It also came with a pickle and coleslaw.
This is where it all went horribly wrong....
i was so excited for this bagel... i went over to the counter and was rung up....
it was 18$ !!!!!!!!
no wonder they're empty all the time?
that is astronomical!
i don't know how they'll be able to stay open - how they've been able to stay open. with prices like that? in this economy?
and by the way - my bagel was great - but the not big enough nor delicious enough to justify the price tag. 
i will never be back.
and yes - the place was empty when i was there.
author: Beatrice G.

description:
David's is massive disappointment. As a New Yorker I loves me some Jewish Soul Food (I'm actually Irish, but NY ethnic identification gets blurry around food) but David's is the worst example of a jewish deli I have ever come across.
The place is dingy, the service is offhand, the portions meager and the taste peaks at "meh." I had a pastrami sandwhich and chicken soup. The soup was not flavorful and lacking in non-liquid content. The sandwich was tiny by jewish deli standards and lacked flavor or any kind of pizazz. It was simply  low/medium-quality pastrami on bread.
The final kicker was the price. When I saw the  price on the sandwich I assumed it was going to be a NY style heaping pile o' meat that automatically comes with a doggie bag. I can't believe they charge so much for such poor quality food. 
I don't care for sweets so I can't comment on the quality of the dessert stuff.
I live up the street and cannot fathom how this place stays in business. I can't imagine ever coming to David's again. When I need my jewish deli fix I hit east coast west deli on polk.
author: bill d.

description: Went to get a corned beef and chicken sandwich for lunch and it cost $18! The price for this item wasn't listed but other sandwiches were listed for around $10 (still steep but I didn't have time to go anywhere else). When he rang it up he said $18! For a sandwich, a tiny cup of coleslaw and some soggy pickles. Will never go here again.
author: Alvin P.

description: It is a very authentic East Coast Jewish Deli that you can hardly find in this town.  I decided to go back there because I had breakfast at this place years ago when I visited the city with my parents, and now this place has carried that memory for me.  However, THEY DON'T HAVE MATZO!  Then, I tried to order sardine sandwich which was also listed on the menu.  They didn't have that either.  Why not just update your menu?  It was also expensive.
author: Vivian H.

description: Feh.  Agree with the other reviews here - there are better places to go.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Had been wanting to visit David;s   Delicatessen on Geary st. in S.F for some time. On sept 15th went for lunch before an ACT matinee.  Waited 10 min for water and service and ordered Matzo Ball soup and a salad  my partner also ordered Matzo ball soup and the Meat Loaf.. After 20 minutes the waitress reappeared and told us there were no Matzo Balls  ( It was  12 pm Lunch Hour)  How can a Jewish restaurant be out of matzo's even before  lunch??  So odd.   So I substituted the Pea soup and my partner ordered the Chicken broth soup with chunk chicken. After another 10 min  the pea soup arrived ICE cold I had to send it back . Although the rye bread (toasted)  to accompany the soup came 10 minutes before the soup. After another 10 minutes passed while they were microwaving  my soup it finally arrived and the bread was ice cold.  My partners  chicken soup was so bland it could have passed for warm water. .  My salad arrived pleasantly appealing but arrived at the same time as my re-warmed pea soup.  My partners meat loaf came with instant mashed potatoes that had  to be cut with a knife and the meat loaf was obvious yesterdays  ( or last weeks for that matter) as it had been warmed on a grill and looked like fried meat loaf. I had asked for some more bread ...and it arrived after I had finished my lunch and was visiting the restroom before paying my  bill.  This restaurant is am embarrassment to the trade.  we found out  that this restaurant caters to the bus tour trade and for a reason no food lover would ever visit this restaurant twice.  Bad service and lousy food.
author: Ross V.

description: I am surprised at all the negative reviews, I think sometimes, when one person starts in with the negativity, people forget to experience on their own and they just go on with all the negative stuff. And so, with that said, i am really surprised, because my experience was positive. I tried the desserts and although, the lady at the counter was reserved, she was in no way rude. Just that, reserved. Was it pricey? Yes, but do we live in San Francisco? Yes, we do and it costs money to run a deli in this town. And besides, $5 for a strudel? Come on now, you spend $5 on some too sweet, overpriced, chewy, mass-produced, piece of crap from Starbucks every day.
author: Mala S.

description:
we made it a point to come back for lunch the next day after we walked by the storefront.  i've always been sad about not having a good deli in the south bay (maybe i haven't looked hard enough??) so i was excited to try David's Deli.

we went for lunch on a sunday early afternoon, and the place wasn't crowded.   i was happy to see that they offered "big" sandwiches, because i was really hungry.  i ordered the hot pastrami with swiss on jewish rye with mustard.  to me, it looked like a normal sized sandwich, and i got a pickled tomato wedge.  a tomato wedge??  i felt that the sandwich was below average; there seemed nothing special about it at all, and i even felt that i could make a better one myself.  as hungry as i was, i took half the sandwich home with me, but ended up forgetting all about it and throwing it out a few days later.  i usually never forget good leftovers.      

however, i am comparing this deli to some of the best i've had in NY and Detroit.  on the bright side the wait staff was very nice.
author: Della Q.

description: I really like deli food, but I have found David's is wayyyyyyyyyyy  too expensive!  My breakfast was $40.00 and even though the quanity and quality were good, it certainly wasn't worth $40.00.   Anyway, not much else to say on this.
author: Bernie B.

description: I had a matzo soup. It was expensive and tasteless. The matzo balls had a good consistency though.
author: Heidi P.

description:
So I was starving and couldn't resist making a convenient detour into whatever food establishment was going to turn up on my walk back to the apt (5 minutes from work rocks).  Luckily for David's it was that next place so in I went; out I came with a pastrami, soup (was it pea? - no pun intended!), salad, and some feeling of despair over what had just been debited from my check card.  

I cheered up a little knowing that my taste buds were happy with my food choice.  The pastrami was pretty good and the pea soup was not too shabby.  I think my tab for lunch was $18, which is about twice what my maximum budget allows for!  

In the end, David's is that place you've got to try just once to break the monotony of eating at all the other places within a 3 block radius of the apt.
author: John C.

description: This review is for their dessert only. This might actually be my first Yelp review but seeing David get 1.5 stars only prompted me to write this. Their dessert is absolutely fantastic. Don't remember the names, but their chocolate cake, the Napolean and other pastries are just fantastic. I've had dessert at Stella'a and Cafe Greco and David's is definitely comparable if not better with some of their cakes.
author: Shayak B.

description: I was visiting San Francisco for a few days, and needed somewhere to eat for breakfast. I thought the place looked good, oh but boy was I wrong! It took ten minutes to get a menu, after we sat ourselves, and only got a menu and water after waving a waitress down. There were only two waiters, who both seemed to disappear into the kitchen often and for long periods of time. It took us 30 minutes to get our food, and cost $23 for 2 people ($9 for an omelette!)! The omelette were overcooked, the hash browns barely cooked, and the challah tasted stale. For a Jewish deli, the waiter not knowing what challah is is crazy! He knew it as egg twist, uh. They included the tip, (the waiter took 10 minutes to bring the check after we requested it) and the cashier was rude and gave me a mean look when I requested to not pay the tip. It was the most awful breakfast I've ever had, and was glad to see the many many other bad reviews of this place. I feel bad for the people working there, the place is awful and way overpriced!
author: Rachel S.

description: I felt it was extremely pricey for a not so good cup of soup. Also ridiculous prices...I have never paid more than $10 for a cup of soup in my life. Definitely will never go there again!
author: Katie W.

description: I used to come here in the 70's and 80's when I lived in SF, and enjoyed the restaurant and food. This evening my husband and I were staying in a hotel in the area and stopped in for a light dinner. The first clue something was wrong was no one was in the place. 2nd clue -- everyone working here is ASIAN, not Jewish. ??? I should have walked out right then. But, no. I ordered Borscht, though it wasn't like any borscht I've ever had -- it was more like some kind of generalized kitchen sink vegetable soup, no beets, no flavor, no sour cream. My husband ordered stuffed cabbage -- not good at all, and the vegetables on the side were distinctly frozen mixed vegetable medley. Also, the service was awful, and it doesn't look very clean. Never again. Whoever owned David's before must have sold it and these new owners don't have a clue about Jewish cuisine. This is really bad, trust me.
author: Christine K.

description: Do yourself a favor, skip this place.  Went here today with the family, total disappointment.  My dad has been telling my brother and I stories about this place for the last, well, forever.  Apparently he used to live a block or so away "back in the day," when he was first out of the military and living at the officers club on Post.  This was their weekly, if not daily, haunt.  Couldn't tell whether I was disappointed for myself (having to eat the food, worry about the cleanliness, etc.), or felt worse for my father who was clearly dismayed to see what had become of the place.  The food aside, I really think they should just ditch their extensive menu and run off the few things they actually have on hand verbally.  I was embarrassed for the servers who had to repeatedly explain that almost every item we wanted to order they didn't make anymore (at all apparently) or didn't have the ingredients for.  How this place stays open I really don't know.
author: maria z.

description: Any resemblance between this and a New York deli is purely accidental. Over the years, David's has deteriorated from a passable source of Jewish delicacies into an insult to those who know their kishka from their knishes. Sky-high cakes and oversized pastries fill the windows and lure diners into the dingy interior, where a U-shaped counter dominates one side, with booths and formica-topped tables surrounded by rickety chairs filling the other. The sticky floor suggests that a mop is used less often than it should be, or perhaps gets a daily workout without the advantage of soap and hot water. If you stick to the sweets, you may get a sugar rush, but at least you'll be satisfied with your selection. (That's not to say all baked goods are a winner - the ridiculously overpriced bagels are a disgrace.) The preparation of real food appears to stymie the kitchen. Sandwiches overloaded with meat may look like their Manhattan cousins, but the corned beef was dry, the pastrami fatty and greasy. Platters of cold fish - sable, salmon, and herring - looked appealing but tasted less than fresh. Brisket of beef was accompanied by frozen vegetables and obviously canned gravy. Horseradish short ribs were tough and bland. Our grumpy waiter looked like he was one of the originals from the early '50s, and he moved accordingly. After an unexplained overly long wait - the place wasn't very crowded - our orders were brought to the table haphazardly, first two, then one, and finally - about five minutes later - the last. The only saving grace was the variety of Dr. Brown's sodas - including the traditional Cel-Ray - available.
author: Gourmet G.

description: across the board pretty horrible.  service, food, dining room temperature - it was freezing.  $10 bowl of 2 matzo balls and chicken broth, come on.  out of 3 things i tried to order.  rob got the daily lunch special, quite lackluster.  and the filipino lady who chased after us, thinking we didnt pay the bill, was rude as well.   so sad to see a junky place take up so much real estate in sf.  :p
author: Kimby T.

description:
gross

unconscionably expensive for the grossness

my friend and i were walking by and were encapsulated by the cakes on display at the glass window. "best baker in sf" signs piqued our interest.

we were swindled.

i should have suspected something seeing how there was NO ONE inside. first test for quality restaurant: is it brimming with people?

food: i got a napoleon and couldnt finish it. and i ALWAYS finish dessert. it wasn't flakey... kind of soggy actually. it was probably made the week before. the chocolate mousse cake.. had this alcoholly flavor.

ambiance: dark. probably to cover up the dirtiness. didnt wanna stay too long.

service: lady was nice, but didnt make up for the food

gross

they should stop serving food
author: Christina L.

description: Such a disappointment!  A friend and I wandered in here for dinner since we were watching a show across the street at the Curran.  I have wandered past this place for years and wanted to try it since it looks like the infamous Jewish delis in NYC.  I was really looking forward to some yummy matzo ball soup.  It was like $11 but I gave it the benefit of the doubt.  It came out and was absolutely tasteless.  I had to salt it after nearly every bite and I am not a big salt-eater.  My husband thinks my tastes are bland and this was even too bland for me.  I don't know if Jewish food is usually this tasteless but I don't think it is since I've had wwaaayyyyy better matzo ball soup before.  I had thought I'd heard good things about it before but heard the guy sitting next to us at the counter talking and he mentioned that the food used to be way better under the previous management.  I wish I had come here to eat back then.  Yep, never going back.
author: elsa w.

description: This place is a rip off.  I went here searching for a good deli and this was not it.  I had the turkey and pastrami on rye.  What I got was something like a half pound of meat on store bought rye bread.  Be ready for sticker shock when you check out.  My crappy sandwich was $18.75.
author: Ian E.

description: I know its bad but when I checked the SF Environmental health score it was only 68 out of a hundred.   The score was issued from 12-18-08.  There were violations of unclean surfaces, imporper storage of toxic substances, employee practices,  inadequate  handwashing facilities just to name a few!  This place is not only bad but a major health risk.  How dose it stay open..yuck!
author: Roby R.

description: Oh Vey, where do I begin.   First off...I walk by this place everyday, to and fro to work.  It is empty half the time (red flag).   I have been craving a  hot turkey sandwich...some how I got lured into the joint.  I am sitting waiting for my plate, It is freezing in the place because the door is wide open...I kindly ask if they wouldn't mind closing the door, the waiter says "oh NO the owner likes it open.  Well...I sit there for a few more minutes and then ask the robot at the front register if I can close the door, she responds "The owner likes it open"   I respond and say....it is apparent the place is open the lights are on, I am here and I am the freezing client....please make my food to go.  I get my food home and it is cold and bland and I will never step foot in that place again.  If I could I would give it  ZERO stars.   Avoid this place at all costs.   A frozen TV dinner has more substance.
author: David R.

description:
i here by delcare david's the WORST restaurant in SF.  i mean this place is the most overpriced POS restaurant i have ever been to.  i feel bad for the 'jersey boys' crowd that thinks this is the only option for a meal before the theatre.  come to think of, i feel bad for them for going to see jersey boys!
back to review....  i got the rueben and it was the worst rueben i've ever had.  yes it was big, but almost entirely inedible. how on earth do they think that giving you MORE terrible food justifies the price?  
also, WHERE do they get off charging $12 for Maztoh Ball soup??!!  are they crazy?
decor and service are bland just like to food.  also, i'm adventurous in my food but i was repulsed by some of the options on the menu.

Davids = YUCK.
author: Karl H.

description: ordered two sandwiches today, which were good, but then we got the bill. $33, NOT including tip for a mere two sandwiches. thought they were only $10--didnt look closely enough at prices. RIPOFF. SF native went here for the first and last time today! had to eat somewhere before seeing a Christmas Carol at ACT across the street and thought it would be reasonable.....NOT.
author: steve w.

description: Doesn't compare to Kat's Deli in Austin or Carnegie in NYC.
author: Phi N.

description: From the sidewalk the restaurant looks promising.  However the interior is another coffee shop.  The service was good, the waitress enjoyable and prompt.  I ordered a cheese blintze.  It tasted like it was cooked on a dirty grill.  The cheese was very sour and had lousy texture.  The jam was flavorless and overly sweet.  Nice service...bland atmosphere...lousy food.
author: John H.

description: One of the worst meals I have ever had. Both the chicken soup and potato latkes were greasy and tasteless. Avoid at all costs!
author: Shana M.

description: My husband & I were in town for the Outside Lands Festival and wanted a good breakfast so we came here.  What a terrible experience.  We sat at a table waiting for anyone to come to our table and after 5 minutes of not seeing a single employee we moved to the counter in the other room.  The waitress clearly didn't want to be there and was rude.  We ordered our food and it took a very long time to get to us.  It was OK, but nothing to write home about.  While we waited for the food 3 sets of couples came in and were ignored and left without ordering.  As we were leaving I noticed some cheese on the counter that had been sitting there a while - there were 2 bugs on there!  I was horrified.  I told the woman at the register and she did NOTHING.  I wouldn't step foot in here if I were you.
author: Robyn A.

description: The food is as expensive and as bad as people say. I had a chopped liver sandwich (not very thick, not very tasty), a glass of milk, and a pastry. My bill was in the vicinity of $30. This place is deplorable. I actively discourage people from eating here.
author: Bruce P.

description:
I grew up on the East Coast so I've enjoyed really good deli. I've lived in Southern California for 35 years and go to San Francisco generally twice a year. I always made David's my first stop for lunch. But never again. It's obvious that it has taken a nose dive, and you want to stay far away. My last visit was a real shock.
My wife and I went in, and the first thing I noticed was that the window full of what was once a wide array of delectable baked goods, is now pretty meager looking. We then took a table in the dining room. There was one waiter for the dining room and the counter that you would not call "Flash". I never had to look at the menu. It was always pastrami sandwich and a knish to share. First thing he told me was that they did not have knishes. I'm Jewish. Jewish delis have knishes.  When we ordered the sandwich, I asked the waiter to bring us some kosher dills (pickles).
The sandwich that arrived was inedible. Pastrami is not a lean meat, but this was so fatty, I couldn't look at it. So I asked the waiter if he would exchange it for an extra lean (as described in the menu) corned  beef sandwich. This was not much better. It too was fatty. And seemed like it was heated in a microwave that dried it out before placing it on stale rye.
When he brought the check, I noticed that I was charged $4.95 for an "order of pickles" (what was one, maybe two pickles sliced). Real delis bring you some pickles for the table when you sit down. I asked the waiter if this was right, and he smiled and told me yes. When I went to pay the check, I complained to the lady at the cashier, and she told me she was sorry. Jewish delis have a relative at the cash register. And Asian restaurants have Asians at the cash register. The lady that took my cash was Asian. I'm not making any statement other than I have to believe that the place changed hands.
Now the absolute worst part. Despite the bad meal and being overcharged, I left a $6 tip on a $32 (after tax) meal. Once outside, I heard a tap on the window. I looked at the window, and it was the waiter flipping me the bird! No kidding. I went back in, and he took off out of sight, so I told the cashier, who again acted like I was the problem.
If you go into David's thinking you're going into a good Jewish deli, you will have made a big mistake. I too wish I could give negative ratings for the food and service at David's.
author: Jeff M.

description: I like the *idea* of David's presented on their huge storefront sign; it's blue and orange, like some school pep rally sign, and has a big, photorealistic challah on it.  The dining room itself is a bit dingy with a few tables and a large U-shaped counter in the front room, and more seating in a back room.  Their menus are huge, in size and in the number of items offered.  The food here is mostly a resounding "meh"--I think the sandwiches are tastier at Miller's East Coast West.  The pastrami was sliced thin to the point where it was more like "chipped" meat, and it was greasy (as oppsed to fatty and good).  I do like David's sour cream potato salad, though.  The front window showcases their tempting pastry items and those are pretty darn good, in an old fashioned way.  I would skip the deli and stick to the baked goods.  That's probably the reason why they put a huge challah, and not a pastrami sandwich, on the sign.
author: maiko h.

description: It kind of breaks my heart to slam David's -- but someone has stolen the place I loved. Something was terribly wrong with the cheese blintz. It was an entirely different recipe. Unrecognizable glop with a sour, truly unpleasant taste like old cottage cheese. The cabbage soup was passable, but has lost its authentic taste. High points for our waiter -- an earnest and attentive fellow -- who removed the blintz from our bill without my asking. The Asian cashier was bored, curt, and impatient as we selected pastries on the way out. The apple strudel was unrecognizable as strudel -- hard crust, gloppy and overpowered with cinnamon. What has happened to those middle-European tastes I love? Ah! It seems that that it is no longer a Jewish kitchen. No wonder.  Sadly, I will not return. My great affection, though, to David and his dear wife, for so many delightful blintzes and warm welcomes over the decades.
author: vicki d.

description: DON'T GO HERE!!!  WALK, NO RUN AWAY FAST!!!!  One Star too many~This one star is for our waiter that was working hard to make up for what was coming.  Walked in off the street as it looked like a fun diner to have a Sunday "Father's Day" breakfast.  First of all the pancakes are $7.95 for three pancakes "nothing else" we wanted eggs which were $5.95 and bacon $6.95 and milk $3.95. The blueberry pancakes where rolled up in blueberry pie filling, right out of the can.    I ordered eggs, which came with a two finger size of hash browns.  For 5 people, our bill came to $92, yes, $92!  I couldn't believe my eye's.  How could this be?  If the breakfast was great, I would have paid this bill happily and satisfied but we were robbed!!! The girl at the register said, "I'm sorry" with an attitude that made me want to throw up my breakfast on her counter.  I should have been more proactive and had another gulp of their old, thick coffee to induce the gag....
author: anna B.

description: I've never been here (so i guess you can stop reading this now =/ )but I was about to go here today because I've passed by it a couple times and always wondered about it .. but i never set foot in. When I stopped to look at it, the place did look old, outdated, kinda weird and just kinda gross looking and dirty and lonely and smokey and smoggy... no one was in there (went by around 4pm today) but the workers seemed busy at the sandwich counter. I was thinking... I should Yelp this first and maybe i'll come back tomorrow. Thank goodness I came here to read reviews about it.  I can just imagine the gross sandwiches everyone described here. If I were rich, I would give you Yelpers who thought this place was groddy your money back. Everyone who wants to go here might as well just go to a Subway near by for $5 Foot longs!!!!!!! I'm pretty sure they are way better than David's Delicatessen. They should really close this place down. Just because it's surrounded by expensive hotels and that it's downtown doesn't mean it should be ripping people off that way. You disgust me David's Delicatessen... even though i've never tried your crap food. Hmph.
author: Mila B.
